output: Thank you, Mr. President. I very much welcome the approach we describe in the White Paper, that we are addressing the causes of malnutrition and obesity and the resulting diseases.
Unfortunately, in European food policy, whether we talk about nutritional profiles, food labelling or in some places in the White Paper, we are falling into a very one-sided approach.
We are trying to solve the problems we have in Europe through product policy.
I believe that it is a fundamentally wrong policy to assume that there are good and bad foods.
Many amendments show that this does not exist.
There are only good and bad, or even balanced and unbalanced diets.
That should be our approach.
The causes of malnutrition are multifaceted.
To fix this by trying to guide the consumer through product labeling or even by providing advertising bans or regulations or even different VAT rates will not lead us to our goal.
I believe that everything we do here should be a bit under the heading: What can we do to motivate the consumer to think about their eating habits?
In my opinion, a traffic light label that suggests I am now facing a good or bad product is more of an instrument of disinfection than an instrument of education and enlightenment.
That is why I would like to see a more balanced approach and the realization that the path through product policy alone will not bring us anywhere. Thank you.
Mr. President, Madam Vice President, dear colleagues. Budgetary control is not a new issue.
We are satisfied with the old ones and would also be satisfied with the progress on the old topics.
Five points First of all, our urgent request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in the development of the rule of law, the judiciary and financial control.
We don't want to be where we are today in two years, and that's why this point is very, very important to us.
The second point is the statement of assurance for the overall budget according to the step-by-step control procedure, involving the national audit offices.
It would be nice if we could make decisive progress in the last six months, which the Commission only has left, or at least agree on a common path.
As a budget controller, you will be modest.
The third point would be simplification.
We need to help the lower administrative levels of the member states more with the implementation of EU law.
It turns out that they are completely overwhelmed with large parts of EU law, hence the high error rates.
The fourth point is foreign aid. Here I would like to address Kosovo and the question of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Budgetary Control Committee has been in Kosovo. I would like to announce now that Kosovo will play a certain role in the discharge of the budget.
I believe that we have fallen far short of the European Union's possibilities so far and that we urgently need to work on this.
The fifth point would be the improvement of cooperation between member states in the fight against fraud.
We have homework here, especially for the ladies and gentlemen of the Council.

The Parliament will vote on the legal basis for the regulation on combating fraud in November, and then we must consider together how we should proceed if we want to achieve better results in this area.
That was at least our common wish so far.
Mr. President. India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other at all levels, especially at the level of so-called normal people.
Business travelers, tourists, students, etc. A brief remark on this: It also has significance for the Commission's legislative program, which we have discussed before.
In global air traffic, we need good safety regulations, ones that bring something, and not just alibi measures.
It would therefore be a reasonable, really necessary measure to finally lift the pointless liquid regulations and come up with something better.
I voted for the resolution because it is a clear call to the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled with the questionable, yes, fake parliamentary elections in September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of the opposition and civil society.

At the same time, we have called on the Council and the Commission today to facilitate and intensify contacts between the peoples and to democratize the country by seriously considering the possibility of a
Consider reducing visa fees for Belarusian citizens when entering the Schengen area and thus preventing an increasing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
First of all, I would like to warn against the spirit of a statement made a few minutes ago that foreigners would flood our labor market.
Secondly, I would have liked a clearer, more precise report from the Employment Committee.
Confidence in the social binding power of the European Union can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States and the ECJ and not be satisfied with just demanding a balance between fundamental rights and internal market freedoms and free movement.
This doesn't change anything. Social fundamental rights are just like freedoms, human rights, which must not be restricted by the freedom of movement of the internal market.
It is about defending and improving the European social model, and it is high time for the introduction of a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU treaties.
It is time to change the Posting Directive so that wage and minimum standard requirements are not limited as minimum requirements.
Mr. President. I would like to join the thanks to the rapporteur Doris Back, which have already been expressed quite rightly by many colleagues.
We have someone with her who actually hopes not to shed blood, but to invest a lot of blood in this room.
I am pleased with her and the colleagues who have also said that there has been some progress, also in the area of police cooperation.
This is important so that the actual life on site can function in a sensible way.
But I still believe that we must always point out to our partners in Bosnia and Herzegovina that a lot still needs to be done on their part, probably more than is currently being done in some areas.
The willingness to cooperate internally within ethnic groups is something we must constantly demand.
It is not the case that everyone tries to go their own way.
And the integration into regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is also important.
Madam President. The distance between the European Union and its citizens must not become as great as it has become.
We have to make sure that it is reduced.
In this context, the Ombudsman has an important task, especially when and where he does it well.
It is also about the fact that we have to expect the commitment and reasonableness of the Ombudsman.
It is about not raising too high expectations that nobody can cover.

But on the other hand, it is also about the fact that wherever there have been abuses in the administration of the European institutions, they are addressed and, if possible, reasonable solutions are sought that can then ensure and satisfy the citizen.
The current practice has shown that the Ombudsman takes this task seriously and well.
We can hope that this will continue to be the case and thank him and the rapporteur for this report.
Yes.
Dear colleagues, ten years after the realization of the monetary union, Europe is in a severe crisis.
Banks are collapsing or are being supported with billions of euros from the state budget, sales are collapsing, and millions of people are afraid for their jobs and their future.
But it is not only the market that has failed, the ruling politics also seems unable to learn from its mistakes.

We are of the opinion that even with such interim remarks, you do not want to profile yourself in any particular way, we are of the opinion that serious mistakes were made in the construction of the economic and monetary union.
One such mistake is the structural disintegration of monetary and fiscal policy. One cannot create a common currency without harmonizing tax and expenditure policy at least in approaches.
I think the economic imbalances in the Eurozone have become enormously worse.
What we need now is actually better coordination of economic and, above all, tax policy.
We need effective measures against tax dumping, and tax havens must be closed and capital flows must finally be controlled again.
The second serious mistake is seen in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

Anyone who considers budget consolidation to be unavoidable in times like these is obviously living in a different world. Nothing would be more fatal than to respond to this economic crisis now with public austerity programs.
The Stability Pact has clearly demonstrated its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our opinion, an investment offensive is necessary to renew public infrastructure and improve the situation of socially disadvantaged people in Europe.
We see a third mistake in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is only committed to the goal of price stability.

We are in favour of democratic control of the European Central Bank, and we also demand a correction of the ECB's monetary policy mandate, in which growth and employment must be promoted at least on an equal footing with price stability in the future.
The current crisis also offers an opportunity for profound reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This chance should not be wasted lightly.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council, esteemed colleagues. Indeed, the automotive industry is in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
In particular, the financial crisis has once again forced the crisis in this sector, and in the member states, solutions are currently being worked on.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
And that is why we also need European solutions for this key European industry to overcome the crisis.
Almost all car companies have European structures.

In order to make the necessary investments in environmentally friendly cars, which have been mentioned several times today, in order to be able to make environmentally friendly and low-consumption technologies, car manufacturers need public guarantees or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
But the supply industry, which is very important to me, must not be forgotten here.
It is precisely in the supply industry that small and medium-sized enterprises are the places where jobs are created and where innovations take place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
At the last plenary session, the President of the Council made a proposal to protect key industries.
A good suggestion, I think. If you think this idea, this suggestion, through consistently, it means a Volkswagen law for the entire European automotive industry.
This would certainly be a good instrument.
But this protective instrument is currently being fought by the European Commission.
And that is my question to the Commission: Will the European Commission stick to a lawsuit despite the crisis in the automotive industry, or will this course be changed now in the face of the crisis?
Mr. President of the European Court of Auditors, Mr. Vice President of the European Commission, dear colleagues. In fact, it has become a tradition to establish that
We are not allowed to repeatedly deny the reliability statement in the ratio between expenditure at European level and administration at national level.
I remember talks with the former president of the Court of Auditors, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that due to the structures it is not possible to give a statement of assurance at all.
That is why we should think together about how this instrument can be filled with life so that the goal of the reliability statement can be achieved if justified.
Of course, we have to differentiate a few things from each other.
Firstly, a household that includes around 95 percent subsidies is much more susceptible to fraud than a national, regional or municipal budget.

A subsidy budget, which is essentially managed by the member states, which have demanded much more independence from us in the new financial period, because the accusation of the last funding period was that it would be too much centrally controlled.
This also means that responsibility for the money must be taken on regionally and nationally.
I would like to briefly address a third topic.
We also have to learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These are also things that are always liked to be thrown together.
I am also annoyed when things are promoted with EU money that are not necessarily necessary.
But that was not fraud, that was a waste.

That is why those who are responsible for the projects, especially in the area of structural policy, the member states, also have the responsibility that money is not wasted and that only the projects that really develop added value for the region are promoted.
That is why I think we should also think about converting parts of the structural policy to interest-free loans.
If member states have to pay back, then they only promote what they really need. Thank you very much.
It is not only difficult for me to agree with this emerging self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to managing the financial market crisis.
If this EU were a functioning democracy, one would have to first ask the question of responsibility and how all this could have come about.
It is simply not true that all the problems we have now would be a tsunami, which is natural, but it is made by human hands.
And with all the regulatory anger that this Union has caused, one wonders why no action was taken when banks began to cross national borders to a significant extent?
Why didn't they act despite the corresponding warnings when the derivatives snuck in?
I remember well that your Nobel Prize winner Josef Stiglitz was here and addressed all these points.
There was silence, there was a taboo.
This is where we should start, because the only key to solving the problem in the future is to recognize our own mistakes.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen. Mr. Commissioner, my question is about what you think about Iceland and Hungary introducing the Euro as a second currency.
Do you think that could solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is Do you think it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which would then be used to strengthen the banks'equity?
My third question is: Don't you think that a VAT reduction would support imports, especially from China and India?
Wouldn't it be more sensible to think about tax reduction for our companies and for our employees, that we pay investment premiums, that we pay the progressive depreciation accordingly in the
The focus is on increasing low-value economic goods by a factor of ten, so that no short-term profits are taxed, so that the money stays in the companies and wages can be paid better.
Madam President, the comprehensive report illustrates how many human rights violations occur in the world every day.
This is particularly frightening sixty years after the declaration of the human rights charter and calls on us to increase our efforts.
For this reason, I would also like to advocate for the establishment of the current Subcommittee on Human Rights as the main committee.
Today we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Anhu Jia, who is fighting for human rights and the environment in China.
But because he is in custody, he couldn't take him in person.
Shame for China, and tomorrow there will be a debate on human rights violations in Russia.
In our relations with these two countries, we must give not only economic interests, but above all human rights, a higher priority.
We demand freedom for Hu Jia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, Commissioner, dear colleagues. As rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, one has interesting experiences, such as the fact that everyone talks about anti-fraud and then no one does anything.
or the experience that the member states calculate their payments to the European Union with a sharp handle, but pull on their shoes when spending this money
and even make it easy for fraudsters, for example by the fact that it still takes an average of six and thirty months for irregularities to be reported to the European Union.
The European Parliament does not agree with this.
We want an efficient fight against fraud that also includes prevention.
We want the member states to make the fight against fraud a topic and for us to discuss the necessities and problems together.
We want a greater interest of the national judicial authorities in the follow-up of OLAF investigation results.
There must no longer be legal areas for the Kromenturen as there have been so far.
We need to equate European money with national money.
We want an independent office that has the necessary resources and legal basis to fulfill its tasks.
And we want an office that can work together with the member states quietly and efficiently.
Our statement on the legal basis 179 provides for all these points.
We plead for this regulation to be further developed as the core of the Anti-Fraud Office together with the Council.
We call on the Council to incorporate our statement, we call on the Council to start talks on the further development of this regulation.
We want to bring OLAF's problems to a solution.
I thank all the factions of the House for supporting this in a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech Presidencies to take the ball back from the Parliament.
We have also taken up solutions in our proposals that the Council working group has developed and introduced.
From our side, I can tell you our interest in a quick conclusion of this regulation and assure you of our constructive willingness to talk on the basis of our proposals.
Consolidating all OLAF legal bases, as the Council has envisaged, means another considerable time loss with an uncertain outcome.
Olaf will soon be celebrating his tenth birthday.
Consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
That is why we take the fight against fraud seriously.
We want to make the feasible happen now in cooperation with the Council.
Thank you very much.
Mr. President. I would like to pick up on a remark that my Austrian colleague Paul RÃ¼big made earlier.

We spend less than one percent of the European gross domestic product for Europe, and at the same time we demand that more and more tasks for more and more member states are handled by the European Union.
This calculation cannot be made. It is therefore really unbelievable that we have been on the austerity course for many years, but not only in the thrifty

The use of our funds is not only about the use of our money, but basically about the fact that the finance ministers collect money again at the end of the year and let it flow into their budgets at home.
We would have enough new tasks for which we should spend our money.
We also have tasks that we have not really budgeted for for years.
I believe that the European Union's information funds need to be significantly increased if we really want to bind European citizens to Europe.
And there are many tasks in the area of student and apprenticeship exchange that Europe could use here.
The situation is also advancing in the justice sector, a previously state-owned reserve area.
This corresponds to the changed living conditions of the people in our Union.
But this remark has already been made several times: Integration must not interfere too much with traditionally grown and, above all, functioning structures.
Not everything can be done over one rope.
Public documents and public document persons are quite differently designed in many member states.
In Austria, but not only here, the notary's office as a public document office has a long tradition and a high level of security and trust.
This must not be put at risk without necessity, just because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore, integration and mutual openness, yes, but with reason.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues. Plant protection products were and remain essential ingredients of the agricultural economy.
Farmers need a minimum selection of plant protection products, because it is about protecting the local cultural landscape, high-quality nutrition and the protection of resources.
We often have discussions about chemicals on a very irrational level.
But in order to get reasonable results, we have to think and act rationally.
The effects of the original position of the parliament would have been fatal: a broad ban on plant protection products, thus lower yields in agriculture and ultimately rising food prices.
Therefore, I am glad that a compromise that is still acceptable has been found in the trilogue negotiations.
It is welcome that we have maintained the three-zone regulation, albeit with significant exceptions for the member states.

A courageous step towards a consistent internal market solution would look different here. In addition to acceptable compromises, we should not anticipate a final definition of endocrine-disrupting substances, but also give the EU Commission four years to present a scientifically based definition.
Otherwise, we will exaggerate the precautionary principle at this point.
And lastly, I find it regrettable that we are not allowed to initiate an impact assessment of the agreement that has now been reached. Thank you.
Mr. President, when the last time a head of government or head of state visited, the President of this house intervened massively.
At that time, it was about a concern that was one of his own, namely the Treaty of Lisbon.
If today the president, the sovereignly elected president of a country, speaks and is massively interrupted by the socialist side, the president does not intervene.
Do you know what that is?
This is not democracy, this is arbitrariness, and I demand that appropriate measures be taken.
Mr. President. Children and politics rarely divide the interests of citizens and politicians so far.
The topic of children is at the top of the agenda for citizens all over Europe.
For politicians, children's concerns are among distant lives, as we can see here again.
I don't know of any country where there is a separate Ministry of Children, and there is no representative of the interests of our youngest citizens in the Commission either.
The topic of children is scattered across all committees in the parliament.
Therefore, I would like to particularly emphasize to the Commission that it is dealing with childcare facilities and the Barcelona objectives today.
In our parliamentary working group Equality of Childhood we have established the following: Our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here, now and today is completely uncertain.
A child of today can climb up the social ladder or fall down a lot.
It can remain in its own cultural circle or look for a new one.
It can take a life path similar to that of its parents or do exactly the opposite.
Someone from the other or the same sex can get married.
All of this was completely different more than fifty years ago, when we raised the United Europe from birth.
The diversity that distinguishes us Europeans has become a decisive factor in the lives of children.
The concept of diversity must therefore be incorporated into the pedagogy of children's educators and teachers.
This is still not taken into account enough at the moment.
The childcare facilities and schools in Europe are breaking down on the challenge of integration.
In integration issues, we have to press the reset button, back to start.
Let us once again approach this topic completely unbiased, according to the motto Unity through diversity.

Furthermore, I ask all the MEPs who follow me to not only advocate for gender mainstreaming, but also to fight for child mainstreaming, especially now in the time of the global financial crisis, because otherwise we would be imposing immeasurable debts on our children.
Thank you, Mr. President. I will make it very short.
I am very grateful for these constructive contributions to the debate that I have heard here.

I would like to send out just two messages in conclusion. Firstly, I would like to expressly thank the Commissioner for not speaking out against the concept of minimum requirements of the safety net in principle.
This proposal is not a devil's trick, nor is it a bureaucratic monster.
It is an instrument for solving problems, which we should give a chance.
That is why I would like to advertise for this once again.
The second thing I would like to say is directed at my British friends, and that is across all parties.
My dear British friends, I understand Caroline, I understand your problem.
I can understand that the energy security of a country is set above the compliance with a limit for air pollutants for a certain period of time.
I have great understanding for that.
I am also the last one who would not give your majesty extra time when it comes to building new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it.
The problem is that we didn't do exactly that.
This conversation never took place during the last four months.
I would like to ask you to be open-minded again at this point, and to say, Let's talk about a compromise at this point.
to give up the fundamental opposition against the minimum standards, which in my view is completely irrational, competition-politically and environmentally unjustifiable.
I believe that this is the point where we can reach a compromise, which I hope we will also get in the second reading.
Incidentally, I don't think we shouldn't look for a compromise in a first reading.
This legislation is too complex for that.
I do not want to end this legislative period as rapporteur and leave the next Parliament with legislation in which a legislative text is discussed that is not consistent, illogical and contradictory.
That is why I ask for support for the compromises when we vote here in an hour.
Mr. President, dear colleagues. The crucial question in all the economic stimulus programs that are being launched throughout Europe is of course who will ultimately get the money?
More blank checks are being issued to the banks, although rapid nationalization would ultimately be much cheaper for the taxpayer.
And should corporations and high-income earners be relieved even further, even though they have been fattened for years in all of Europe through tax gifts?

The more money is wasted for such purposes, the more likely it is that such programs will fail, and the more likely it is that the European economy will sink further and further into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The years-long policy of privatization, deregulation, liberalization, this very policy has increasingly concentrated income among the top ten, and it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis we are in today.
Who believes that he can overcome this crisis by continuing this policy with minor modifications, I think, has simply not understood anything.
The exact opposite is necessary.
Instead of buying rotten papers from banks, tax funds should be used for the renovation of schools, hospitals and for the ecological restructuring of the European economy.

As long as private companies receive public funds, no tax money must be paid without employment guarantees and, above all, no tax money without the acquisition of public property rights, so that the state and, above all, the general public of citizens can also be involved in future income later on.
The best economic stimulus program that would currently exist would be a radical redistribution of income and wealth from top to bottom.
The starvation wage sector in Europe must be pushed back instead of being further promoted.
We need higher minimum wages, we need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that the millionaires and profiteers of the past financial market party now also bear the immense losses that have arisen, and not the vast majority of citizens who never got anything from the whole financial boom.
I think that social justice is currently also the only economically sensible thing.
And it is the only way to break the devastating crisis dynamics.
Mr. President. In early March, the political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev from Chita in Siberia were transferred to Moscow to be charged again due to unsustainable accusations.
The first public negotiation day was scheduled for March 31st.
The human rights consultations between the EU and Russia should have taken place on the same day.
These important talks have now been postponed by the Russian side for an indefinite period of time.
Russia is showing very clearly how little importance it gives to human rights.
The judiciary is still not used for justice, but to eliminate regime opponents, and the EU is being deceived.
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for once again mentioning the ban on animal testing.

I pointed this out because it reminds me that this is the third change to the cosmetics legislation that I was allowed to accompany, the sixth change, the seventh change and now the change to a regulation.
We have indeed managed to ban animal testing.
We have managed to get consumers to know, for example, how long a product is still durable by seeing a small dose with a number that says how long it is still valid.

I also say this to some colleagues, especially to colleague Reuthofer, who unfortunately could not be here at the beginning. Labeling is never a warning sign, at no point. If a product is not safe, it should not be on the market, it should not be marketed.
Every product on this European market must be safe and unconcerning.
But the labeling gives consumers the opportunity to choose.
This is democracy, and this is your freedom of choice.
I believe we have very good legislation.
I tried to make the procedure very transparent.
I tried, as Mrs. Kostet also said, to bring together different opinions.

Because I want us to make legislation that is good for everyone, for the consumers in the European Union, for the industry that has to work with this legislation and ultimately for all those who benefit from it.
I say again to my colleague Schnellhardt, yes, DEO works differently for everyone, but the statement keeps it sweat-free is still made.
Therefore, it is important that the statements regarding my folding depth around my eyes after a week in Strasbourg are also somewhat real and reliable.
I would like to thank the Commissioner again, also with regard to the explanations he has given, my colleagues and my staff who have done most of the work.
Thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. The report by Mr Van Nistelrooy on the Green Paper and the future form of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most important reports of the Committee on Regional Development in recent years.
And we agree with the basic concept of the Green Paper, according to which territorial cohesion is about the polycentric development of the EU.
to ensure the overall sustainable development of the territories with different characteristics and peculiarities while maintaining their diversity.
It is right that in the next planning period a more comprehensive system of step-by-step assistance for transition regions, which reach the threshold of 75 percent, should be introduced.

The creation of a new regional policy that will exceed one percent of the gross domestic product must be created so that these regions receive a clear status and thus have more security in their development.
And in the report by colleague Kreh on obstacles to the initiation of structural funds, the most important shortcomings are rightly listed, which applicants face when
The use of the structural funds is such as excessive administrative burden, too many complex regulations, slow and complicated centralized administration in the member states.
Many recommendations are made to the Commission on what effective measures should be taken to remove these obstacles.
I would like to highlight and confirm two such measures.
Firstly, currently project managers must store their project documents over a period of ten years in order to have them in stock during inspections carried out by the Commission if necessary.
Especially for smaller projects, this is an excessive bureaucratic effort.
It is right that this should now be reduced to a period of three years. Secondly, the EU Commission's evaluation standards for innovative projects cause considerable problems.
Innovative projects must not have the same evaluation standards as other projects.
It is simply necessary that something else happens here.

Madam President. If Europe takes money into its own hands and if the member states take a lot of money into their own hands to help the automotive industry in its crisis situation, then it can't just be about securing the stock and the status quo and preventing bankruptcy, but it's about a number of other concerns.
The most important ones have been mentioned.
It is about the people who are looking for employment, they need to secure this employment, and in the long term.
For this, it is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation and above all sustainability in the transport system more than we have done so far.

Therefore, we should link all our measures to these objectives, so that we do not have to accept the accusation in a few years that we should have thought about all this many years ago, then we would not be in the next and new crisis.
Madam President. It would be nice if you could give me half a minute extra, as my green colleague Mrs. Breyer has just been given.
The Commission had submitted a good proposal for updating the regulation on novel foods.
Unfortunately, some amendments try to supplement this proposal with requirements that are not compatible with the objectives of the regulation or even want to interfere with existing jurisdiction.
The obligation of food companies to monitor novel foods with regard to animal health and welfare would simply overburden the traders.

And once again there is an attempt to undermine the existing GMO laws, namely the demand for special labeling of such novel foods, which are obtained from animals that have been fed with genetically modified feed.
We just heard it.
Basically, everything that affects GMO legislation should not be addressed in the Novel Food Regulation.
I say this even though I myself, for example, had made the request to specifically distinguish the corresponding new plant species from the definition of novel foods.
But it cannot be that interested parties in this house misuse the Novel Food Regulation for election campaign purposes.
Apparently, this is also the case with amendments 62 and 90, for which the Greens have requested a roll-call vote.
Who, dear colleagues, do you want to put to the test with this?
My group has also always advocated for the consumer's right to know what is contained in food.
Why shouldn't the declaration of ingredients point to a nano-origin?

And although Amendment 260 tries to anticipate my report on food labelling in a somewhat clumsy way, I must tell you that I consider this labelling of novel foods to be quite compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend that my group agree with the mentioned motions and will include references to the part of the regulation on novel foods that deals with labelling in my report on the food labelling regulation.
This is possible because we have postponed the first reading on food labelling to the next legislative period against the will of the Greens.
But now it is clear to everyone how beneficial this postponement was.
A brief comment on cloning: that is animal torture.
We are against it.
Nevertheless, food must be included in this regulation, because otherwise it would be a waste of time.
Madam President, it is quite simple.
Who does not want this man to lead the solemn opening session of the European Parliament, should agree to my request to change the rules of procedure.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. One thing is clear: the provision of food to those in need, especially in these economically difficult times, is not up for debate for me in the upcoming vote on the report by our colleague Sikerski.
Therefore, I would like to make it clear right at the beginning that it was not easy to find a common line within our group.
I therefore respect the personal decision of each group colleague to deviate from it and not to agree to the rejection of the report we have planned.
Why can't I agree with the result of the committee vote in this form?
There are a number of reasons for this, which have nothing to do with helping those in need in the European Union in these economically difficult times.

On the contrary, the amendments submitted by my colleague Nils Busk on behalf of the ALDE Group, but unfortunately not deemed admissible, should serve to put the existing system on a sustainable basis.
Because the current system is an anachronism from the times of agricultural overproduction, which fortunately belongs to the past.

Thanks to the successful decoupling of direct payments, intervention stocks have steadily decreased in the past years, so that today up to eighty-five percent of food must be purchased on the free market.
But this has fundamentally changed the character of the program and led to the loss of the agricultural policy dimension.
But since we are now dealing with a social program, we must create a corresponding legal basis for it.
Hereby we share the assessment of the Council's legal service, which instead of Article 7 and 30 of the EC Treaty on the Common Agricultural Policy is merely
I believe that Article 308 is possible as a legal basis, because otherwise it is clearly an interference with the national competences of the member states.
The only solution can only be a new draft of the European Commission in view of the inadmissibility of our amendments.
This should also continue to take into account the principle of co-financing, because only on site can such programs be assessed satisfactorily in the sense of all.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, we also welcome the proposal of the European Commission and this Green Paper of principles.
There is a mass phenomenon, which has been described by the various speakers, where relatively small damage occurs to a large number of those affected.
The damage is small for the affected persons themselves, but overall it is great.
An instrument is needed to deal with this problem.
In my opinion, it is also right that such things are thought about.

I also welcome, in order to remain positive, that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has placed a very crucial emphasis in its Green Paper on the issue of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.

This is a big difference from the White Paper of the Directorate General for Competition, which was also discussed here in the House yesterday, which has completely ignored this possibility of out-of-court dispute resolution mechanisms so far.
I think that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection is further ahead in its Green Paper than its competition colleagues.
But I want to make two things quite clear, which in my opinion can be understood as critical remarks.
The Parliament will decide on my report on the White Paper of the Directorate General for Competition in a few minutes here at 12 o'clock.
We will demand from the European Commission with an overwhelming majority in this House that a horizontal approach is chosen when dealing with this issue.
It can't be that we have sectoral instruments at the end, one for the area of consumer protection, one for the area of antitrust law, another for the capital market, maybe one for the environment.

Perhaps one more thing for social affairs, and they all contradict each other. They all interfere with the legal systems of the member states and ultimately lead to a legal confusion that can no longer be handled by any practitioner.
We have had such examples in the past many times.
I only think of the debate about the Professional Qualifications Directive, which we later also summarized in one instrument, because this fragmentation was no longer possible.
The Commission should not make the same mistake here.
It should promote the horizontal approach from the beginning.
This is the clear position of the Parliament, and this will become clear here in a few minutes.

One last point I also very much welcome the fact that we have reached a consensus that we want a lawsuit industry in the American style with a turnover of two hundred and forty billion US dollars per year, from which only lawyers ultimately benefit and the consumer does not want anything from it.
We want real rule of law in Europe and to stick to our traditional systems and our understanding of law.
Mr. President. There are many ways to deal with the sustainable consequences of the unexpected financial and economic crisis.

This revision package, this legislative measure within the framework of the European economic stimulus programme, is designed as a good response, although not entirely sufficient, but it is first of all a good response to this temporary, although exceptionally critical situation.
This also leads to the promotion of a stronger simplification of procedures and greater flexibility in the application of existing
Dear colleagues, this is a demand that the European Parliament has repeatedly made in the past years.
It is also to be welcomed and I would like to emphasize this in particular that by amending Article 7 on the eligibility of expenditure, the Member States and regions of the EU should be enabled to
to invest structural policy funding in energy efficiency and renewable energy in housing construction, and that these measures should not only be eligible for households with low income.

The relevant amendment therefore rightly deletes the line Households with low income and instead adds an upper limit of four percent of the total ERDF allocation for each member state for such expenses.
This is just one of the many proposed improvements.
In short, this overall package will be realized, it is an acceleration of expenses and thus further liquidity for the implementation of necessary
There have been requirements from the structural funds, from the ERDF, ISF and cohesion funds, and a simplification of the provisions that enable the rapid implementation of the programs.
an effective contribution, although not sufficient, to dealing with the current crisis situation.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues. In principle, I welcome the European Environmental Label.
It is right that we take a new approach to spread this environmental sign of the community further.
I also think it is right that we stick to voluntariness in the future.
The sign will only prevail in the future if there are clear criteria and standards that require the acquisition of this sign.
Here I appeal to the EU Commission to develop reasonable, clear, understandable criteria.
The incentive idea must be the focus.
It would be regrettable if the establishment of the eco-label fails due to bureaucratic hurdles.
The consumer decides whether to succeed or fail in the end, because it must be accepted by him.

Even though I personally am very attached to the blue angel we have in Germany, it should not be a matter of taste in the end, but it is important that the consumer is informed at once of the special properties of a product.
Added value for the consumer is only created when the member states renounce their respective signs and there is a uniform sign at European level in the end.
A mess of symbols makes the consumer unsure and does not inform him.
A sign, a statement. We should work together for this.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I think that in this legislative period, we have achieved a lot together with regard to the discharge procedure of the European institutions.
But I regret that it took so long, because we have basically only now worked through everything that was already apparent with the Commission's resignation in 1999, so ten years ago.

This shows that we still need to improve our working methods and procedures and ensure that the necessary transparency is introduced more quickly when it comes to citizens finding out what tax money is being used for.
I would like to thank my colleague Mr Kasaka in particular, with whom I had the honor of working on the discharge of the Parliament for the EPP Group.

I am very sorry, that is why I have now quickly looked around again, that a colleague who expresses himself very intensively through the press on various things of the European Parliament neither participates in the committee consultations nor in the votes in the committee nor here in the plenary debate.
I want to say this very clearly here, so that it is preserved and remains for the future. We know very well that there were a number of problems here.

We have and are, and it was the members of parliament who are here now who have ensured over the last five years that the necessary reforms were achieved in a variety of places in the interest of the members of parliament.
And for that, a very heartfelt thank you to everyone. We did what was necessary, and we didn't make sure that everything was widely publicized in the media, but that no one was involved.
Thank you for the serious cooperation.

Mr. President, dear colleagues. The AUDI report, thank you to the rapporteur, really brings us forward because it contains innovative elements, such as naming and shaming, a milestone in budgetary control.
Targeted criticism instead of blanket accusations.
That the socialist group is now making a retreat and rather wants to sweep the truth under the carpet is a scandal and a disservice to our control tasks.
The credibility of the Parliament is at stake, and I appeal to my colleagues not to allow this.
A word about our biggest concerns, Romania and Bulgaria.
The Commission's failure to prepare for accession is most tangible here.
We lost a lot of money.
The Commission has been watching for a long time and only frozen funds in 2008, for Bulgaria now over one billion euros, for Romania around one hundred and forty-two million euros.
Freezing money is not a solution to the problems.
The cooperation and verification mechanism, for which the Commission President himself is responsible, is a paper tiger, and the progress reports do not deserve the name.
Here the Audi report makes suggestions on how it could be better.
The EU Commission has deceived the Parliament about the maturity of these countries to join, and in fact the Commissioner for Enlargement should draw consequences from this.
But we are concerned with the management of future accessions, and that is why this topic remains on the agenda.
Our group will grant discharge to the Commission, but personally I will therefore refuse discharge to the Commission.
Unfortunately, the Commission's desire for reform, which was again a small spark that could be seen last year, has already faded away.
Stillness in the fight against fraud, nothing on the subject of prevention, no more ethics desired, and so on.
The Commission, and especially Commissioner Callas, should be aware of one thing: if the new Commission wants to be involved, it will rely on the support of the Parliament.
Mr. President. Yes, we have a problem with copyright and we have a problem with the remuneration of artists.
That is correct, and we must also become active and do something.
But if we become active, it is about really responding to the challenges of the digital age and not saddling dead horses.
I will explain to you why I come to this word.
The proposal that is before us actually only fulfills one promise, and that is the promise to promote the music industry.
If we come to what happens to the artists themselves and their income, and we calculate that, then we also come to the conclusion that
such low average sums that it does not serve the livelihood of an artist in any way that he can make a profit from it.
Moreover, this money does not reach the artists directly.
And the fund is too small to achieve anything.
An artist I discussed with told me that there is a redistribution from the living to the dead.
I had to disagree with him. It is a redistribution from the artists to the producers, to the music industry, and only to the big ones.
All in all, Commissioner, this proposal is not suitable.
We have to find better ones.
For example, we need to create something like a flat rate.
The proposals you make regarding the Use it or Lose it clause remain theoretical law.
Please let us do something clever and well-founded, as the artists also recommended and requested in our hearing in the Legal Affairs Committee.
Mr. President. I regret, together with the rapporteur Gilles Sabery, that the Commission did not pursue its original plan for an integrated action plan.
There are many good reasons why all parties involved, from the municipalities to the European Union, are striving to improve urban traffic conditions.
We know that most people in Europe live in cities and that the current traffic conditions are anything but optimal.
Therefore, I basically agree with the plan and the report by Mr Savary to create corresponding integrated proposals here on the initiative of the Parliament.
I thank him for his commitment and also for the concrete proposals.
At the same time, I would like to signal in all clarity that what many fear or believe they have to fear will not happen.
Nobody wants to take away the right of the municipalities, nobody wants to take away the right of the local and regional authorities to shape their traffic conditions.
We only want to contribute from the European side to the fact that reasonable common rules are followed here, if a municipality, a city, or a regional unit considers it reasonable.
The principle of subsidiarity is not endangered.
What we want to do here is to protect this principle.
It remains that we strive in the interest of the citizens that when a citizen travels ten or twenty kilometres in Europe,
If he continues to travel to Europe, he will encounter a traffic-assured zone that he believes he knows from his hometown and find completely different rules for it.
Nobody wants to impose city tolls or other regulations on any municipalities, but if they are actually used here, they should also be made in a recognizable framework for the citizens.
For more than a hundred years we have agreed on the usefulness of common approaches when it comes to traffic signs.
This should also be the case with this topic in the future.
Mr. President. We have been dealing with urban traffic in the EU for a long time now.
Why actually?

We are not responsible at all. The responsibility was originally designed because about eighty percent of the population lives in urban areas, and because of the climate debate, they want to take on the matter now.
Fortunately, we were able to reduce these ambitions of the European Commission through our protest against an action plan for urban transport.
I thank Commissioner Tajani for his insight.
Subsidizing actually means supporting rather than prescribing, but he knows that better than I do as an Italian with only a big Latin.
It is important to me first and foremost that our report, the report of the Parliament, highlights the strict adherence to the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.
Legislative measures at European level are inadmissible for urban traffic.
Supporting measures that is our task.
A collection of ideas and the promotion of the exchange of best practices makes sense.
Not everyone has to reinvent the wheel.
Our cities need customized solutions, but they can only be developed by local actors, because only they know what is necessary.
The municipalities must be able to cope with very different situations. They therefore need sufficient room for manoeuvre, also to keep urban trade vital.
This is important for the attractiveness of a city.
It is therefore important not to exclude motorized individual traffic and to take more care of logistics in the city.
I would therefore like to see research on fine-tuning inner-city distribution promoted.
This relieves a city.
It is also important that demographic change is taken into account.
Our society is getting older and older after all.
The needs for mobility and living are changing.
We need a residential supply of goods that meet the daily needs of the population if we want to reduce traffic, and this is also a challenge for retail.
Anything else would only require the green meadow.
In conclusion, we do not need an observatory for urban traffic.
Such a place would cost a lot of money and produce a lot of paper that would only be unchecked in Brussels. Thank you.
Madam President, I fully support the Commission's goal of creating a legal framework for the coordinated introduction and use of intelligent traffic systems in road traffic.

My years of personal struggle for the serial introduction of eCall, the electronic emergency call system, make the urgency almost everyday clear to me. But intelligent traffic systems can do much more.
They serve environmental sustainability, increasing efficiency, safety gains and non-discriminatory competitiveness in road freight and passenger transport.

Furthermore, they support co-modality, among other things by developing interfaces with other modes of transport such as rail, waterway and air transport, where the introduction of intelligent transport systems has long begun.
All of this cannot be achieved by the member states alone, but only as a community task.

Intelligent traffic systems, based on EU-wide binding basic standards and minimum quality regulations, improve the environment for innovations and create planning security, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
I particularly welcome the planned open vehicle-integrated platform for intelligent traffic system services.
The action plan finally includes a timetable for the introduction of individual systems a for road safety such as ESP and eCall b for continuity in traffic management, for example, information on
Avoid toll fees or parking management search traffic. The use of road, traffic and travel data in real time will not only enrich professional drivers but all road users.

The directive serves to establish detailed requirements for the uniformly binding, coordinated introduction of intelligent traffic systems throughout the EU and their application in the member states.
It also ensures the handling of personal data.

But be careful, the introduction of intelligent traffic systems causes high costs, as infrastructures and vehicles must first be equipped with the necessary information and communication technologies.
We still know too little about the willingness and ability of potential users to pay.
Mr. President, dear colleagues. We clearly support help for people with rare diseases.
But Amendment 15 is completely unacceptable from an ethical point of view.
There must never be a debate in Europe about life worth living and life worth living.
There must be no political and social pressure on parents in Europe to consciously decide against a disabled child.
The selection of embryos would be a major ethical breakthrough.
Therefore, this amendment must be rejected, and it is not enough to just remove the word eradicate, which unfortunately corresponds to fascist language.
But it would still be about the selection of embryos.
And it would be unbearable if this amendment, which speaks of the selection of endemics, were to become a stepping stone for a new ethics in Europe.
We must definitely stand up against genetic discrimination.
Therefore, Amendment 15 must be rejected in its entirety. Otherwise, our group would unfortunately also be forced to vote against this report, which is otherwise quite positive.
Mr. President. I voted against the discharge for the Commission for the first time since I became a member of this house in the vote on discharge.
I will explain my reasons. I am mainly concerned with the way the European Commission has handled and managed the accessions of the two new countries Romania and Bulgaria.
We are dealing with a variety of problems in Romania and Bulgaria, with a high proportion of corruption, with a lot of money, with a lot of European money that has disappeared.
The European Commission only started to freeze these funds in 2008.
We lost a lot of money in 2007 and now we are dealing with hardly any control systems or control systems that only work in a gap.
In Romania we are dealing with a high rate of corruption and problems with the judiciary.
All of this is due to the pre-accession process.

I want to set a sign, also to tell the European Commission that it must proceed differently for future accessions and also to tell it that if it has been observed in other countries, it could certainly be more successful if it wants to.
I would like to ask the Commission to help both countries in building financial control systems that deserve this name and to help eliminate the systemic weaknesses in these two countries.
Otherwise we have a permanent problem and a permanent concern for the whole of Europe around our necks.

Madam President, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that behind me in the area of the right-wing radicals are people who are not members of parliament, and as far as I can see, they are very well using their voting card.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I expressly welcome Horst Schnellhardt's draft report and thank him for his good work.
After the numerous crises of the last years in connection with products of animal origin that pose a danger to the health of humans and animals, a comprehensive legal regulation is essential.
A revision of the current regulations has become necessary.
We still have to ensure a high level of security.
Although we basically agree with the report, I see some points that make me think.
The regulation has been made less strict in many points and thus the trade with animal by-products has been somewhat relaxed.
Some examples There is a permit for the use of certain category I materials in pet feed.
Materials of category two or three can be disposed of easily under official monitoring with a small amount of waste per week, regardless of their risk.
However, the risk of animal by-products of any category is only partially determined by the quantity.
It remains that the European Commission will issue the implementing regulation, and the draft contains, like the previous one, many powers for the Commission.

This means that the Commission can make comprehensive and fundamental regulations on the handling of animal by-products in the comitology procedure. This means that the Parliament is, as is unfortunately often the case, left out.
Mr. President, dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Afghanistan has had a difficult history behind it.
I believe that families are very strongly united there and that women play an important role in the family.
Therefore, economic development is also very important, namely the support of small and medium-sized enterprises should be promoted in particular.
And of course, a modern infrastructure is also necessary that helps the country to develop better.

I believe that infrastructure projects could help to create a greater understanding among each other and, of course, through the means of information and communication technology, a different worldview could slowly take hold there while fully preserving identity.

The pollution of the seas is always the focus of attention when a spectacular incident has occurred again, and then there is also a heated discussion about the threat to our seas by these ongoing pollutions.
But unfortunately, this is always put in the background in the meantime.
The constant and repeated violations, which contribute just as dramatically to the fact that not only our seas but also our coasts suffer from a threat, were to be taken seriously by us.
I would like to thank my colleagues with whom we were able to discuss that we all consistently represented the line that our sea should be protected.
I am speaking here as a member of an internal state, but as a European I feel responsible for protecting our seas from constant pollution from cheap economic
To protect the interests and to integrate the principles of the third maritime package, which is urgently necessary, as the Committee on Legal Affairs has also proposed.
Madam President, colleagues, I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur Obiol Sidjama on his very good report.
The respect for human rights is very bad in many countries worldwide.
But also here in Europe, when we think of Belarus, for example.
Therefore, the European Union must significantly increase its efforts by implementing human rights policy in all areas and setting clear standards.
In our understanding, human rights are indivisible.
This can be done, for example, during the negotiations for a new agreement with Russia through a binding human rights clause that has an impact on all negotiation fields.
Furthermore, I would like to once again advocate that the Subcommittee on Human Rights becomes a main committee.
Okay. The EPP/ED Group calls on the government and the Communist Party of China to conduct the upcoming human rights dialogue in a constructive manner.
This would make the relationship between the EU and China much more tense.
We have a real interest in improving bilateral relations.
But this dialogue must also be conducted honestly.
We will have to maintain our legitimate demands on China.
So, from our point of view, the civil rights activist must be released immediately.
So the talks with the Dalai Lama as the religious leader of Tibet need to be resumed.
And so the Chinese region of Tibet is immediately accessible to journalists and UN human rights experts.
In my opinion, the People's Republic of China has shown before the Olympic Games that it can grant more press freedom, for example, without jeopardizing the stability of the country.
Now she should have the courage to tackle new reforms: reforms on re-education camps, the rights of the accused, the death penalty, freedom of religion, freedom of assembly.
These human rights should really be addressed and we should have a dialogue with them.
Madam Vice President, we welcome and congratulate the Czech Senate on its decision today, which we welcome with great joy.
President Klaus reacted, among other things, by claiming that the Treaty of Lisbon was still dead because it was rejected by the referendum in Ireland.
As a political zombie, he is attacking the majority decisions of his own parliament and the Senate and confirms his dishonorable and sectarian attitude in other areas of politics as well.
Fortunately, after the positive votes, he only makes himself look ridiculous.
We Greens are positive and constructive about the European integration process, of course with critical remarks where necessary.
Once again, many thanks to the Czech Senate, Parliament and the government.
Mr. President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen. Last week, to my delight as a new member of parliament, we heard Mr. Mahmalbaff in the Foreign Policy Committee.
an Iranian film director who told us quite clearly that there was twenty democracy in Iran before this election, and after this election, which was a coup for him, there is no democracy at all.

Mr. President of the Council, I am particularly interested in one thing: there will be an official introduction for Mr. Ahmadinejad, re-elected in quotation marks.
What is currently being discussed in the Council and also with the member states?
Will there be an official, formal representation of the European Union and also of the member states?
I hope that this will not happen, because I think that after this election coup there should be no official representation of the European Union or even the
Member states, no matter how much I am in favor of further dialogue, but in this official introduction, no one should be officially represented by the European Union.
What is your position on this?
How is this currently being processed? Thank you.
Mr. President. The crisis in Europe did not only come about through unethical behavior on the financial markets, Mr. Barroso.

This is where the growing social inequality is, this is where the dangerous and unsolidarity macroeconomic imbalances between the member countries are, and this is where Europe's dependence on rising resource prices is.

The citizens of Europe deserve a Commission that keeps putting these deeper causes on the agenda, instead of tabooing them, instead of doing the opposite, instead of shifting the responsibility to the member states.
We need a real European coordination of economic and fiscal policy.
We need tax cooperation in Europe that puts an end to tax dumping.
Only then will it be possible to stop the social division and finance the necessary ecological investments.
We need a policy that consistently promotes green technologies and lifestyles in such a way that the EU's dependence on endless resources decreases sharply.
This is an ecological green revolution. I don't find all of this in your program, Mr. Barroso.
That is why I cannot elect you.

We need a revolution of democracy. Mr. Barroso, imagine that we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation where we are in a situation
If you were to stand in Europe in an election alone, no other candidate, how many percent of the votes would you get?
What would the citizens do?
You would have listened to you today and seen that you promised everything to everyone.
Hopefully you will also get the information about what you did five years ago.
You promised most of them a lot.
You have to compare what you have already promised, what you promise now and what to expect.
I think that is very, very little.
They stand for the old, for the failed Europe, for the contribution to the financial crisis because the Commission failed, for the lack of commitment to climate issues and, and, and.
I would stand on the side of the majority of European citizens, because I believe they would not get more than ten or twelve or fifteen percent of the votes.
I would like to speak out in favour of maintaining the new proposal, because it is clear that the negotiations in Honduras have failed.
There is no common proposal for this election.
This election is illegitimate because the current president has come to power through a coup.
That means I ask the plenary to give its consent to the proposal of the presidium for this change, that the elections are removed.
Democracy needs a revolution, and it is never wrong, Mr. Dartmouth, to speak out for transparency, Mr. Verhofstadt.
And you, in the Swedish Presidency, could be a shining example and really tell us how it went.
It is about the very unworthy positions of chess players in the top positions for the European project and also, Mr. Barroso could lead in the appointment of commissioners.
Germany and Austria are a negative example, but unfortunately others are too.
Qualified people are sitting here in the hall, but they have no chance to get in.

Please be brave now that the Lisbon Treaty has been passed and be honest and say that we need much clearer decision-making structures, transparent decision-making structures for the Commission and the top positions.
And it should be possible to find good people here in the European Parliament with so much expertise and not to build them up in some federal states.
Mr. President. The topic we are discussing here tonight has been on the agenda of the European Parliament several times.
As is known, the Commission is guided by the conditions of the International Monetary Fund when granting aid.
This has already been mentioned a few times.
Against this background, there have been repeated requests from the EP to the Commission.
In November 2008, the EP asked the Commission to present an analysis of the effects of the behavior of banks that transferred their assets from the member states that had just joined at the time.
On April 24 of this year, the EP repeated this demand.

Furthermore, the EP has demanded that the declarations of intent between the Commission and the Member States that receive subsidies be informed in detail and that the conditions for the subsidies be listed in detail.
As far as I know, these inquiries have not been answered to this day.
My first question is therefore: Is it true that these inquiries have not been answered so far?
If that is true, then my second question is: Why have these inquiries not been answered so far?
My third question is when can we expect an answer to these inquiries?
Ladies and gentlemen, the GUE/NGL group will not agree to this resolution.
The Stockholm Programme completely overlooks the real challenges of the present.
The core mistake is that a Europe of rights is being established, which is supposed to be granted to EU citizens, but not to other people living in Europe.
The same citizens and human rights should not be given.
On the one hand, the EU wants to join the human rights charter, which we welcome, but on the other hand, migrants are sorted according to the principle of legal or illegal.
So Frontex is being equipped to massively combat the so-called illegal migration, and I tell you that this completely shifts the focus to an unbiased immigration policy.
Here Stockholm fails.
Another problem is the completely unbalanced ratio of security and freedom.
Yes, there is no freedom without security, but there is also no security without freedom. Freedom is not a bargaining chip, but a universal right of every human being.

Stockholm, on the other hand, symbolizes the EU's security madness by creating huge supranational databases without sufficient control possibilities that bring together intelligence and police data across Europe.
This makes the right of people to information self-determination, the waste paper and the vision of a glass person actually reality.

Let me conclude by saying, as an East German Member of Parliament, that twenty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, it is unbearable for me to experience how Europe is becoming more and more a fortress.
Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, you are right. The railway system is a very safe system compared to other modes of transport.

However, in addition to many positive aspects, liberalization in the form of fragmentation of individual companies, separation of infrastructure and operation, outsourcing of maintenance work and leasing of material and personnel has brought some uncertainty.
In my opinion, it must be ensured that national safety authorities issue safety certificates and approvals in accordance with the ERA's regulations, i.e. the railway agency.
Are there enough controls?
For example, it is ensured that the training of the staff, the certifications and the working conditions are properly controlled.
What about the introduction of a uniform community certificate in this context?
What about the European driver's license?
The efforts concerning ERTMS must be further increased.
The recently created implementation plan you mentioned must be binding and must not be delayed by financial or national considerations.
Efforts concerning the introduction of TSI technical specifications must be continued and expanded.
This would be a huge step forward, especially in the homologation of the material, and a higher level of safety in the maintenance of the material.
Many of the recent railway accidents and near-accidents are due to inadequate maintenance.
For cost reasons, the intensity and intervals of maintenance work are particularly neglected.
What about a European-wide certification system for maintenance workshops?
In my opinion, everything must be done to avoid each individual member state returning to its old rules and acting differently and independently again.
Especially the border crossings between the individual member states are a security risk.
How does the Commission intend to deal with this problem in the short term?
And in the balance sheet you create, I would like you to take into account the social aspects. Thank you.
We need a revolution of democracy. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, good morning in this new world of the Treaty of Lisbon. This is an opportunity for you.
For eleven years I have been following your reports in this house, previously as a journalist, and ultimately they are very similar.
Now, however, you have the opportunity to look ahead.

Use the expertise of this house, which is not quite by chance gathered in the hall right now. I see colleague SÃ¶ndergaard, I see colleague Chaci Makakis, there is Mr. Staas, there is my colleague Mr. Ehrenhauser from our list, and re-establish the work of the Court of Auditors.
Look at what works elsewhere in Germany, where you can check the economy and sense of expenses in Austria, and work out
Do you have a concept, perhaps within the framework of an initiative report that will then come to the parliament, on how to do what you do much better, so that you can actually fulfill your tasks?
We need a revolution of democracy.
I remember very well that the debates, as we hear them today, started ten years ago in this house.
I would urge you, Commissioner, to really write into the book of directors, especially what comes from Arlem Desir, but also from the Greens and some left-wing members.

Don't you realize that with the approach with which the European Union has entered into negotiations, we cannot eliminate the imbalance as an honest broker? I think that in connection with what we are currently experiencing in these hours and days in Copenhagen, we really need a new approach.
Developing countries are no longer developing countries in many of the things they do today.
emerging economies, developed countries and very self-confident.
If the European side fails to dare to restart with fair guidelines, we will end up where we do not want to go, namely with protectionism and the following in 1933 in Europe.
Mr. President, I would like to use the blue card only to correct the situation.
Support in Austria is not only granted for one person.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. A microfinance instrument for the unemployed, those threatened by unemployment and especially for people who do not have access to normal credit markets is a good intention, a good intention and is supported by our group in principle.
However, what the Commission and the Council have done so far in terms of performance is simply insufficient, partly wrong and cannot be supported by our group.
First point of criticism: the question of financial resources.
What is on the table in terms of financial resources is not financial resources for a program to combat unemployment, it cannot be called a microfinance program, it is at most nanofinancing.
Secondly, we are fundamentally against doing such pocket-making tricks without any effect, which go at the expense of other programs and thus blow up endlessly.
Thirdly, also the view that the sustainability and success of such a program must include organic mentoring and coaching.
Many new start-ups, especially in the microfinance sector, fail, so this must also be ensured within the program.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in the member states are not cut for the use of this program, otherwise it will be ineffective.
This cannot be used to fight unemployment in a sustainable way.
We will reject it in this form.
Mr. President. Today, after eight years, we all know that the previous strategy of focusing on the military in Afghanistan has failed.

Mr. President. Regional structural funding is an essential instrument in European integration. In the past, the funding of Objective II has been perceived by people as a driver of structural and economic development on the ground in many regions.
It is an important element for managing structural change in the regions and also in the municipalities.
Here Europe is also really experientiable for the citizens on the ground, because it also works on the ground.
However, we need simpler, clearer and more transparent structures for the cohesion funds and better controls so that the funds are used sustainably and efficiently.
Cohesion, the convergence in social and economic development is a main goal in the EU, and that is why we must not weaken this instrument in the future, but we must strengthen it.
The cohesion policy in Europe needs more clarity, more transparency, efficiency and also the self-responsibility of the individual member states.
And that is why it is important to stick to the system of additional support.
But we don't want to renationalize structural funding.
Therefore, I would like to ask the Commission to meet these requirements from 2013 onwards.
