Madam President, it seems to me that it is a bit symptomatic for us, for the EU in general, but also for the Parliament in particular, that we reflexively discuss situations in countries whose situation is not new.
Unfortunately, it is the case that very often overnight events lead to us suddenly being flooded with political demands, which I sometimes find somewhat questionable.
I believe it is not good for us to see a failed plane crash alone as a general debate about Yemen.
I believe we should be aware that it is in our best interest to consider a strategy on how to deal with this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen needs a precise analysis, namely that it is a failed state in which a government is acting that no longer has control over large parts of the country, and we should analyze for ourselves what risks arise for Europe from this.
The risks seem to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks also seem to be emerging on the coast of Yemen, where piracy is obviously taking place.
That is why it is up to us and perhaps also to Mrs. Eschten to consider what we can do against these risks.
In my opinion, the answer can be mainly how we can strengthen the government in Yemen to regain control over the country and contain these risks.

Of course, all other discussions about the long-term development of the country must also be held, but I don't think it really makes sense and that we are taken seriously if we now initiate a catalogue of demands across all political issues, from media freedom to women's rights here in Parliament.
This will not lead to the goal in Yemen, but we should focus on what help we can provide in the current situation to solve an acute problem.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen. The massacre on November 23rd last year in the province of Magandinao in the Philippines was a black day for human rights and a barbaric act of terror.
Seven and fifty dead, raped women, injured, they speak a bloody language.
As a journalist, I notice that thirty journalists were among the dead.
According to the renowned International Crisis Group, no more journalists have ever been murdered at once in any documented case.
For this reason, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to find clear words, as we do today in the draft resolution.

However, we, as the EPP, demand that the present text be sharpened in three places by a separate vote. Because we should support the Philippine government in its fight against terrorism and violence and therefore refrain from accusatory remarks against the government.
Therefore, I request on behalf of the EPP to vote on recital F in particular. This accuses the Philippines of showing all signs of a non-functioning legal system.
In point two we would like to remove the assumption of so-called initial delays in clarification.
Finally, on point six, it is claimed that there are missing persons in Philippine prisons.
This is also an unproven assumption at the moment and should be deleted in our opinion. Thank you.

Policy coherence in the interest of development means that we do not take with one hand what we give with the other.
For example, it makes little sense to invest in the development of agriculture in developing countries if we simultaneously destroy local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.
We can also be even more committed to better healthcare if we hinder the trade in generics or drive the prices of medicines to unbearable levels through patent extensions.

And agrofuels may reduce CO2 emissions in the EU a bit, but in developing countries they lead to deforestation and land grabbing, and thus to more climate change, which we just wanted to avoid, not to mention the expulsion of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity and arable land for food.
Currently, we, that is the EU as such, are not particularly coherent.
The EU has theoretically recognized that political measures should not contradict each other.
The Treaty of Lisbon lays down the coherence of policy in the interest of development.
Article 208 states that when implementing political measures that can affect developing countries, the Union takes into account the goals of development cooperation.
We must be measured against this demand.
This year we will review the progress in achieving the Millennium Goals.
It is clear that without policy coherence we will not be able to keep our promises.

We all who pass and implement laws must become aware of this responsibility. Before we pass a measure, there must be an impact assessment, so that we can even recognize what negative effects European legislation can have on developing countries.
We need expertise in the Council, the Commission and the Parliament that recognizes inconsistencies.
The Commission's work programme on policy coherence is a good step in this.
Now it depends on how this plan is implemented.

Policy coherence in the interest of development means that we must take into account the interests of the local people more in the fisheries reform and not subordinate the interests of European fishing companies.
This means that we have to dry out tax havens, where money flows from developing countries.
This means that we cannot agree to ACTA if there is a suspicion that this agreement could disrupt access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
So far the Commission has not been able to clear up this suspicion.

Policy coherence also means that when creating the Foreign Service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy field and the competences of the Commissioner for Development must be extended and not restricted.
And it also includes, for example, enabling fair trade in the awarding of contracts in the municipalities, as my colleague Heide RÃ¼hle has proposed.
In many cases, we MEPs must keep a close eye on the Commission and the Council so that they can make policy coherent.
In many cases, however, it is also up to us, the members of parliament, to be coherent in the interest of development.
We need to network better between the committees, and we need a permanent rapporteur.
The report, which the Committee on Development unanimously adopted, makes many good proposals and brings us a big step forward.
I would like to thank all shadow rapporteurs, the Ombudsman and all NGOs for their help and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can also be adopted by the plenary tomorrow.

Madam President, dear colleagues. For months we have been discussing the issue of driving times and working hours in road traffic.
And I wonder what arguments are being used to prove that what we have been discussing for months is all nonsense.
The latest argument is that something must be changed here urgently so that nothing changes.
Don't you realize, dear Mrs. Bauer, how absurd this argumentation is now, how it is permeated by lies and half-truths?
This dispute is about nothing more than an extension of the working hours of the self-employed.
However, in the labor law, it has been about the question of protecting people from overly long working hours for one hundred and fifty years.
This applies to both the self-employed and the employed.
It doesn't matter at all whether it's an employee who is overworked or an employer who is overworking an employee driver.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessive working hours, partly also from employers and clients.
Secondly, in terms of road safety, it is claimed that nothing could happen.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not in the hobby construction market and we are not laymen. We cannot make laws according to the motto Let's see what comes out of it.
Everyone knows that overly long working hours are designed to be at risk of accidents, especially in road traffic with major consequences.
Third point: Who is supposed to control such a differentiated regulation as you imagine on our roads in the future?
Today, a state labor judge cannot check whether someone seems self-employed or is self-employed without extensive study of the files.
Let's leave this nonsense, it's about fair competition.
It is not about setting a precedent for the future dispute over the extension of working hours today or tomorrow.
Don't play such games with this house. Thank you.
Madam President. Today, as I have been advocating for road safety, improving the working conditions of our professional drivers and upgrading their professional skills for many years.

It is quite clear that today it is not about the regulations for driving and rest times relevant to road safety that all self-employed and employed professional drivers must comply with, today it is about the regulation of working time.

To restrict self-employed drivers, as in the future perhaps also self-employed craftsmen, architects or members of parliament, in their permissible working hours in this way is the wrong signal.

Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues. Just a few days ago we saw with shock in the TV images how vast areas of Poland and other Central European countries were flooded with water.
People have died in the floods, and the relatives have our full sympathy. Villages, cities, agricultural land and infrastructure have been destroyed.
The images on television have already been replaced by other images, but the enormous damage must first be laboriously removed.
In the elimination of damage of this magnitude, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the countries of the European Union.
After the flood disaster of 1997, Poland and this time other Central European states were again affected by a flood disaster.
We can't regulate the weather yet, and floods are a peculiar type of river at certain times.
But the questions we have to ask are whether, being aware that these natural events can always occur, the right measures are taken to prevent them.
whether damage was caused by such natural events and whether, for example, the issues of sustainable disaster protection were given due consideration in landscape planning.
If help is granted, it should first of all benefit those directly affected by the natural disaster to secure their livelihood.

But then more should be done in international cooperation, because natural disasters do not stop at state borders, for the prevention of damage by natural disasters by the member states in a coordinated manner at the European level.
The fact that jointly operated precautionary measures can provide protection is shown by the flood protection on the Oder, which has been jointly built by Polish and German authorities so far.
But we are not yet at the end.
We don't need European disaster protection.
Protecting a country from disasters should be the primary task of the government of a country, which should also include the drawing up of disaster plans.

But coordination of aid in the event of damage and accident should also experience efficient European coordination, and those organizations that provide quick and unbureaucratic aid on a voluntary basis should not remain at their own expense.
Therefore, I support the plans of Commissioner Georgieva that we will also implement them quickly.

Mr. President, first of all, a heartfelt thank you to Mathieu Grosch for this profound report and the enormous work he has done.

That Europe is without dividing borders, without a functioning transportation system, is not feasible, and the European economy would not be successful without a powerful transportation system, without powerful, future-proof transportation systems on land, on water and in the air, not even conceivable.
Especially in environmentally friendly rail transport, we need more community and less national egoism.
For a sustainable future of transportation, all modes of transportation must face the challenges in society, in the protection of the environment and in the economy.
The report provides valuable and guiding hints.
However, I cannot agree with the report on just one point: I cannot agree with the formation of a transport fund from the cohesion policy funds.
Why?
Transport is certainly a special carrier of cohesion in Europe. However, a separate fund from the cohesion policy funds would not meet the expectations it raises.
We should not unilaterally burden the cohesion fund and relieve the member states, which are particularly required to ensure a sustainable future for transport, too much.

And we have just set up a special committee in the parliament that debates what the cohesion and structural funds of the European Union will look like in the future. Its work should not be prejudiced.
Therefore, I ask you to agree to the amendment to the report.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. We do have a common internal market, but fragmented supervision.
It is obvious that this cannot work.
We need strong central European structures that use the expertise and detailed knowledge of the member states'organes, but also have the power of intervention in emergency situations.
I believe that the citizen expects, alone against the background of the enormous tax burden that has been exposed by this crisis, that decisions are made quickly, quickly and properly.
Citizens are not interested in power games being played at the national level, where it is exclusively about the question of who decides what.
What the citizen wants is that decisions are made effectively, that problems are solved.

And it is objectively the case that when it comes to measures in an emergency situation, this must be centrally regulated and decided at European level if the coordination between the member states is not sufficient and does not work.
This is not in line with the decisions of the G twenty, the G eight, the heads of state and government, unfortunately not at the level of the Council.
The Council is making a small, small carrot.
This is not an acceptable policy for the citizens.
We expect the Council to move.

Ladies and gentlemen commissioners, dear colleagues, one sometimes wonders what we have actually done for over a year in terms of discussions and debates, in many meetings in the trilogue, where I could have imagined something more beautiful than spending them there.

And at this point, more than a year after the European elections, where we have announced on the streets and squares how we want to control the financial markets, we are actually facing a very meager to non-existent result.
The problem has already been described.
We are dealing with markets that operate globally today.
The member states still believe that they are able to enforce the rules of the game with their national supervisory structures.
And exactly because it didn't work, it didn't trigger the financial crisis, but it contributed to it affecting Europe.

That is why I wonder when this insight, which is often formulated in Sunday speeches, will be implemented in political action, when it is suddenly about protecting stock exchanges, when it is about protecting banking structures and no longer protecting citizens.

As the European Parliament, we have dedicated ourselves to this task, and I hope that the member states will also dedicate themselves to this task, because they are co-responsible for implementing proper supervisory rules for the citizens, which ensure that the individual's savings are also permanently safe.
Of course, I wish, Commissioners, that the Commission would do everything to achieve a good result as quickly as possible in the interest of the people in Europe.
Mr. President, dear colleagues. We are in this European Parliament responsible for strong regulation of the financial markets.

The Council and the government do not want strong intervention rights.
Giegold is right when he describes what is currently happening as church tower thinking.
The intention seems to be not to create strict regulation, but just to make the system a little more free of failure.
We will get a fragmented supervisory structure that will not be able to carry out real control of the financial markets.
Insufficient consequences are being drawn from this financial crisis, from this economic crisis, and thus the next crisis is already being prepared.
Many national economies, including in Europe, will not survive the next blows with all the social and economic consequences for the people in Europe.
They also expect that this predator financial market capitalism will be captured again and the primacy of politics will be restored.
When the chairman of the board of the Unikreditbank Alessandro Profumo formulated over the weekend that we need a strong and uniform European financial supervision and a common rule for all
Member states and he pleads for stricter capital rules, then this is an appeal to this Parliament to really constitute these rules.
It is the task of this European Parliament to put pressure on the Council to urgently carry out effective regulation. It would only be the first step towards maintaining the status quo.
Let the full-fledged promises be followed by actions. My group stands for strong European regulation.
Anything else without regulation would be a danger for the Euro, for a common EU and for democracy. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. This is a bad timing for this debate.
I would have liked to see the Dutch team win again, even if it is the last time in this World Cup.
This is probably a bad omen, because we can't watch anymore, and then you probably won't win.

But on the subject, Commissioner, you are giving the right hand signal. Commissioner, Mr. President, we are concluding today or tomorrow, to be precise, a package of laws that we have been discussing for more than two years.
It is not only the controversy that is to blame, but also the intermediate European election and the entry into force of a new EU treaty that has led to the fact that we had to adapt some things.

But I believe that if we draw a conclusion from this debate today, I come to the conclusion that we are now voting on a compromise that is worth saying yes to, even if you do it with a clenched fist in your pocket at one point or another.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
One is the environmental requirements for industrial plants.
It is about us enforcing the best available technology in Europe better.
I believe that we have found an exception in the compromise now available, which gives the EU Commission, Mr. Potocnik, and this is quite clearly addressed to you, the tool in which

In the coming years, we will have to make more and better efforts than before to ensure that the about two and a half industrial plants in Europe ultimately use the best available technology better than they do today.
I have heard many arguments in this debate.
I would like to pick up on one thing and reflect it here, because I can't understand it at all.
I have often been told that the use of the best available technology is too expensive and that we are endangering the competitiveness of European industry, especially in times of crisis.
I don't like to remember my past, but I come from the former GDR, from East Germany.
The economic and ecological collapse of the GDR was also due to the fact that investments in the latest technology have been sleepwalking for decades.

I believe that every industry, every industrial operation is called upon to invest in the latest technology because of its existence, because otherwise it will lose competitiveness and, of course, reduce pollutant emissions.
I think we have the chance today to put a law into effect that improves this starting situation.
The second part of the directive, and this is a bit of the clenched fist I mentioned, are the large combustion plants.

We are talking once again, we have already done this in the last directive, about renewed exceptions until the year two thousand twenty, partly two thousand and twenty-three for large combustion plants that do not have to meet environmental requirements, especially air pollutant limits.
I am addressing the Council here, perhaps also a bit to all of us, that we must think very carefully about how sensible it actually is that we regularly
We welcome ambitious environmental goals, which are also discussed and welcomed here, but whenever it comes to implementing them, to put them into concrete legislation, a tragedy begins in Europe.
Then it suddenly becomes clear to the member states what it costs, what bills they have to pay, and then usually those who have gone into pre-performance are also punished.
There are a number of member states that already meet the requirements today and are left in the rain in the end.
And I say it again here: We are not talking about science fiction in both industrial plants and large combustion plants, which are essentially coal-fired power plants.
We are not talking about things that are not available, but it is the latest technology.
The best available techniques, what is available on the market in terms of competitiveness and costs, can be incorporated into these plants. Against this background, we conclude
Today we are voting on a legislative package that I believe is better compared to what is in force, and that is why I encourage us all to agree to it.

I also thank my colleagues who have contributed with very hard bandages over the last two years for their support, for their cooperation and above all for almost all the important factions signing this compromise.
Three interesting things happened while we were debating. Firstly, it is clear that Europe will become a world football champion.
I think that is a good omen.
We will see who it will be exactly.
I don't want to give any preferences now.
Secondly, Germany gets compliments from the UK.
Thank you. It doesn't happen every day.
It is worth noting this.
And thirdly, the world is still fine, even for the Greens, football is more important than environmental protection.
Unfortunately, our colleague Bas Aykut is also gone again.
But of course, congratulations to our Dutch friends.
I wanted to say two aspects about the debate that I was allowed to follow just now.
Firstly, I understand all the worries and needs of my Eastern European friends all too well.
As an East German, I am also a half East European.
And I understand that not every environmental step that has been taken in Western European countries in the last decades can be immediately followed in Eastern Europe.
Environmental protection at a high level must be affordable.
Yes, that's right.

But I believe that even if you consider this sentence, it is worth agreeing to this compromise, because it will do justice to the different starting situations in which many member states find themselves.
Secondly, the argument that the use of the best available techniques endangers competitiveness, especially compared to China. This argument is not only wrong, it is even dangerous.
We have to deal with the fact that industrial processes in Asia are definitely cheaper than ours.
But we will only be able to compete if we use the best available technology in all industries.
Whoever doesn't do that loses competitiveness.
Nobody is asking for this law to shut down an industrial plant tomorrow.
Nobody demands a jump from zero to one hundred to reach any pollutant limit within a week.
We have enough transition periods, but to say that we should do without them for competition reasons is wrong.
I believe that with the directive we have not only made an environmental policy, but also an industrial policy change, for which it is worth working in the coming years. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to start by thanking my colleagues from the other groups for drafting my report on Kosovo, including Mrs. Eva Maar, who has done very valuable work in the secretariat.

And I would also like to thank you, Commissioner, for the good cooperation, but also for what you mentioned, that it was important to you to go to the north of Kosovo, to spend even a night there and thus also to make it clear to the population that you also stand for this population there.
You gave a speech at the university, opening the EU house there.

I think this was an important sign to make clear what this European Parliament has already expressed in the past and also now, namely the support for the independent Kosovo on the path to the European Union.
We currently have a situation where there is once again an important crossroads for the citizens of Kosovo, especially all ethnic groups.
In a few weeks the International Court of Justice will give its opinion on the position on the declaration of independence more than two years ago.
I hope that this decision, this opinion, will then be an opportunity to put regional cooperation on a new basis, but from the perspective of self-governance.

Starting from Kosovo's independence, and making it clear that the common future for all states in the region, for Serbia, for Kosovo and all others, as a member of the European Union, and that the problems that still exist must be solved on the way there.
The text of the resolution is also one that makes it clear that the future of Kosovo lies in the European Union.

I am glad that we have a majority in favor of this, which also calls on the five member states that have not yet recognized it to do so soon, and that the Commission is also called upon once again to start visa liberalization as soon as possible.

Because the citizens of the country, especially the young people, must not have the impression that they live in an isolated state, that they cannot get out, while all the others in the surrounding area will soon have this future.
I think that is the task.
I hope that I will also find a large majority for this tomorrow in the plenary.

I have also submitted a new amendment that highlights strong regret over the outbreaks of violence in the last few days and hopes for a quick and independent investigation, and does not take this as a basis for a rise in emotions in the coming days and weeks.
Madam President, High Representative, Commissioner, dear colleagues. The recent events in Kyrgyzstan, the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people, the
The burning of houses and the flow of tens of thousands of refugees who left their homelands and tried to flee from violence shook me and caused compassion for the victims.
At the same time, these events in Kyrgyzstan also shed new light on the situation in Central Asia, which we in the European Parliament must not leave untouched.
On the contrary, we should devote all our attention to the countries of this region.

We should not only focus on the states that are rich in natural resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but also take all states into account equally within the framework of the Central Asia strategy decided in 2007.
That is our obligation.
The Central Asian states, which were liberated from the once tsarist and later Soviet rule less than twenty years ago, bear a heavy legacy.
The borders arbitrarily drawn by Stalin, without regard to the homeland of the peoples living there, make coexistence within and outside the borders of these states more difficult.
Poverty, corruption, disregard for human and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions, such as in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, hundreds of thousands in
Forcing labor immigration and, as is now the case in Kyrgyzstan, conflict resolution with the use of violence raises questions about the path of these states to the future.
Here the European Union must not just stand by and watch.
If we do not want to lead these states into fundamentalist structures, if we do not want to hand over the people there to permanent dictatorial regimes, it requires our full commitment.
In addition to the urgently needed material aid, we need contact with these states, active support for the democratic forces developing there.
Let us give Prime Minister Rosa Otunbayeva a chance in the pacification of Kyrgyzstan and on the path to stable political relations, let us let the debate on this and the vote tomorrow

The upcoming resolution should also be followed by actions, so that the people in Kyrgyzstan and other Central Asian states feel that we will not leave them alone on their way to the future or surrender to undemocratic forces.
The expectations of us Europeans in these countries are high, we should not disappoint them. Thank you.
I voted for this report for four reasons.
The architecture of the service has numerous weaknesses, whose fine details will still worry us greatly.
The second point is that the European ambassador will manage Commission funds in the future.
This exposes the funds to a variety of risks, and the safeguards for these risks are still absolutely unclear.
The third point is the abolition of the rights of this Parliament in a Council regulation.
We are in this procedure in the de facto codecision, and yet we have allowed the Council Regulation to anticipate parliamentary rights.
That is why I would like to say for my dossier, the budgetary rules, that I do not see myself bound by today's decisions.
The fourth point is the question of how we actually deal with each other in the parliament.
We decided on a parliamentary reform in the last period and we have now trampled on procedures, also with the approval of the presidium and also with the approval of the president.
Why do we make a parliamentary reform that prescribes procedures when we already violate them and do not comply with them when it comes to it?
For these reasons I cannot agree with this report. Thank you very much.
Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, I am very much in favor of green genetic engineering, but cloning is something else.
That can't be compared to anything at all.
Cloning is animal torture. Many colleagues have already said it here.
I also mentioned it in the discussion we had before the summer break: Only a fraction of the animal clones are actually viable.
And those who survive, many of them die very, very early and very painfully.
They suffer from malformation of the extremities of the organs.
They have immune weaknesses, they are susceptible to disease.
This means pain and suffering and this tormenting death.
How can we be responsible for that?
We are committed to animal welfare and then we want to support such a technique.
No, we don't want that, and that's why we decided in July that we don't want cloned meat or animal products from cloned animals.
That is only consistent.

Yes, we know that products from cloned animals or their descendants are probably not harmful to health, and I personally assume that they would actually be suitable for human nutrition. But there is actually no shortage of meat from conventional production.
Why should we get involved in this cloning?
It is completely unnecessary to practice this animal torture. The population does not want it either.
The population doesn't want these products, we don't need them either. There is no argument for cloned meat in the European Union.
And that is why we want a very clear regulation, explicitly for cloned animals and also for their offspring.
I want a ban on cloning and cloned products in the European Union, and I also believe that we can push this through.
Of course, this also has to apply to imports.
I want to make sure that cloned meat is not secretly pushed under my feet because it is not labeled, as has already happened here.
I don't think you can trace all the meat.
It may be possible with beef.
But with pork, due to the mass produced, it will not be possible to trace whether it was actually a clone in the ancestral line.
Basically, I think it is a fundamental question, it is an ethical question.
And other colleagues have said that we also have to deal with ethical questions, and we are also responsible for ethical questions.
Of course, there is the question of animal welfare, but there is another question.
Experience shows that all reproduction techniques, once they really worked in animal production, were ultimately applied to humans.
So today we have to ask ourselves: Do we want and can we accept cloning technology in the near future? Do we want and can we accept it in humans?
So I don't want that and I can't do that either.
And even if a spare part clone could possibly donate a vital organ to me in the future, a clone of myself, then I don't want that.
I don't think that's an exaggerated horror vision.
I believe that this would be possible in the not too distant future if we allowed cloning.
Therefore, we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on cloned animals and their offspring throughout the EU.
I am not afraid of the WTO.
We can push this through.
We don't have to copy everything that the USA is deceiving us with all the transatlantic friendship.
Mr. President. It is no coincidence that we cannot agree so easily in this case, because two incompatible matters are being mixed up here.
We would probably have been able to agree well on trademark protection if we had focused on it.
But the mixing with the subject matter of the Internet is also factually wrong, because new, different strategies are needed here than in substantive law.
This cannot be simply transferred.
Moreover, one must be aware that we pay for any online prosecution with interference in civil rights, because one cannot see or find out oneself.
The third thing is really clear to me: If I already put cultural enjoyment on the web under threat of punishment, so that I practically always feel like I am in a state of war.
If I find myself in prison when I look on the net, I will not be able to use the opportunities that the internet also offers for art, culture and creativity.
That is why my appeal Let's keep talking about it.
I'm going to tell you.
Mr. Chairman. Property, whether intellectual or physical property, is a cornerstone of the market economy.
Therefore, I believe it is important that we think about how we can regulate this issue in a good consensus.
We need a warning in any case.
It must be easier for consumers, for the self-employed, for small and medium-sized businesses to get the corresponding licenses here.
The availability of licenses for intellectual property rights valid throughout the EU is of particular importance.
We need an internal market for intellectual property.
We need above all the original language, so that it is available throughout Europe.
Every language is an important cultural asset, and it should be possible for licenses granted for a language to apply throughout Europe and therefore be used by all citizens.
We need interoperability and technical neutrality to be able to use this intellectual property accordingly.
And above all, we also need sanctions for those who violate competition and trade law.
Madam President, dear colleagues. I have taken note that the Council does not want to discuss the multiannual financial framework.

I would like to inform the Council that the European Parliament wants to discuss it and that the Council cannot behave like in kindergarten and say that it does not answer our questions and our proposals.
Secondly, I have to ask the Council in this context whether it wants Lisbon or not.
Lisbon is not a purely technical change, but means more tasks, more task fulfillment and also to answer related financial questions.
Furthermore, the Council has made decisions that lead to new financial expenses.
This has been said by many colleagues.

If the Council wants this and if the Council wants that no more money should be spent, then the Council must also say where it wants to save, how it wants to save, where it wants to reallocate exactly, and not just general

Proposing percentage shifts and then leaving it to the Parliament and the Commission to decide on the inconveniences, especially since the possibilities for reallocations and changes to the budget are extremely limited for us.

However, the tasks you have given us are so challenging that they do not include small, secondary sums, but I will only mention the areas of financial solidity of our states and their corresponding financial difficulties.
If the program needs to be used, then these are not small sums that could be reallocated in passing.

The same applies to ITER, the same applies to internal security issues, the same applies to major research issues, the same applies to issues when I address priority areas that the Parliament has, namely in the area of youth education and research.
We are dealing with a lack of implementation, and we are also dealing with a lack of transparency in the spending of funds.
All these questions must be dealt with and processed together, and not by silence from the Council.
Mr. President, dear Commissioner Hahn, colleagues. I have a problem with parts of the debate.
When we talk about mountains, islands and sparsely populated regions, I get the impression from individual contributions that they are extraterritorial and directly subject to the European Union.
But that is not the case.
Each of these areas belongs to a sovereign member state.
And the implementation of European decisions and goals is still the responsibility of the member states according to the principle of subsidiarity.

If I look at the European level, we have always paid special attention to these areas, mountain regions, sparsely populated areas, and islands, from the Commission's communication to the Lisbon Treaty.
Many decisions have been made here in Parliament to support this region.
When I hear many complaints here that there are still abuses in the areas, then the question arises for me: How have the member states dealt with the impulses we have sent from the European level?
And how did the regions themselves proceed and how did they use the European funding opportunities?
A new strategy is being called for here. I am sorry for the officials of DG Regio who are supposed to put the variety of problems of islands, mountains and sparsely populated areas into one strategy.

At the same time, we are experiencing an inflation of strategies for the Danube, the Baltic Sea, the Black Sea, climate change and the like, so we need both of them to have a strategy for the strategies, so that we can still keep an overview.

But, dear colleagues, let's leave the joke aside. I think what it is all about, and this has also been said today, and I am very grateful to Commissioner Hahn for mentioning this, is that we must fight for a cohesion policy and a regional policy at European level even after 2013.
This is the focus of our work, and we should also convince our colleagues in the parliament that this will be the case.
And in the continuation of the cohesion and regional policy beyond the year two thousand thirteen, mountains, islands and other areas will also find their place.
But we should not get bogged down with individual motions for resolutions on the subject, for which there is currently no reason. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues. First of all, thank you to the colleagues who have worked so intensively on this project, especially to colleague Vidal Quadras.
This is proof that European politics is able to respond to crises and offer solutions that help.
We have had this security of supply situation several times.
The problem of security of supply has become clearer and more distinct.
We were forced to act, and we did.

We have found solutions that were not easy, which also mean new instruments, and which, and I find that interesting, do not only create infrastructure standards in Europe, not only create common rules for prevention and emergency plans, not only the certainty, as the Commissioner just said.

The results of the work that has been done show that we can offer people thirty days of security in the future, but also that we are able to explore compromises that then lead to actionable solutions.

It was very laborious on the road, but it now shows that both the role and responsibility of the companies that build networks, which are responsible for networks, are at the center, but also the mobility of politics, which says we do not force things that then no longer pay off and are no longer wise.

For example, flexibility in the case of refunds, in the necessary refunds, but not to say everything and always and at any price, but also the necessity or the possibility to be able to assess individual cases, just as to strengthen cooperation in the regional area.

It is just as important to point out that the member states must also take their responsibility, but if the solutions cannot be found, the Commission gets an additional task, the Commission that is strengthened, but does not decide alone, but decides when other solutions are no longer possible or has the last word.
So flexibility, solutions that keep the burdens within manageable limits, but last but not least ensure that there are solutions, and that is the good news from Brussels for the people in Europe.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, esteemed Commissioners. I do not need to emphasize how important cohesion and regional policy is for coexistence and growing together in Europe.
But I also believe that the regional policy and cohesion policy of the future must be more focused on cities.
Because cities are an important engine in the development of Europe.
At the same time, however, they are currently feeling particularly ecological, economic and social problems.
Therefore, my very specific question to Commissioner Hahn: What possibilities do you see to highlight the urban dimensions?

To be more specific, Commissioner, you recently hinted at an event here in the House that you could imagine a certain percentage that is reserved from regional funds, precisely to highlight the urban dimension.
Are these considerations still relevant?
And if so, how high could this percentage possibly be?

Mr. President. First of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for starting a new debate here as a former Minister of Economy and Innovation, which can make a great contribution to growth in Europe.
If every small and medium-sized enterprise in Europe created an additional job, we would no longer have unemployed people in Europe.
We should also think about how we can enable small and medium-sized enterprises to hire new employees and become active on the international export markets accordingly.
But research infrastructure is also an important concern, as is infrastructure in the field of transport.
Here the Commission has big tasks ahead of it, especially to restructure the East-West connection, for example Paris Budapest or North-South.
Here additional jobs can be created, which we urgently need in Europe at the moment.

Madam President, dear colleagues. We have undoubtedly made progress in the last years in the equality of men and women. Nevertheless, there are still many women who are pushed into low-skilled employment.
This applies not only to activities that are traditionally performed within the family.
In the deregulation of the last years, social security-based employment has often been converted into atypical, precarious and insecure employment relationships.
especially women there.
The European employment development from two thousand to two thousand ten includes sixty new precarious and atypical employment relationships, mostly two thirds of which are women.
Women are often denied democratic participation through their part-time employment and precarious employment in companies.
However, women are much more committed and better educated today than in all generations before.
They still earn twenty-five percent less than men on average.

We have dealt with this topic very intensively in the Employment Committee, and good proposals for the issue of women's employment are being developed, including them regardless of the status of their work.
social security systems, the creation of childcare facilities, the alignment of pension and social systems with independent living and the design of work according to the principles of good work.
All of this has essentially been taken over in the report on precarious employment of women.
The Employment Committee is satisfied with the result of this work and asks for approval for the submitted report. Thank you.
Mr. President of the Council, landmines will probably still be a major problem in the distant future.
Do you think it is possible to initiate your own research programs to detect landmines?
This is not only a European problem, it is a global problem.
Can you imagine finding suitable institutions that deal with research programs in this area?

Colleagues, in the transatlantic dialogue there is much that unites us, these are fundamental values, fundamental rights of freedom and democracy. But there is also something that separates us, namely the application and concretization of these respective rights when it comes to transatlantic relations.
Especially when it comes to security issues, this contradiction always comes out quite clearly.
Data protection is a source of constant misunderstandings, we have known this for a long time.
That is why the framework agreement, if we manage to get a very good one, will be a very big step forward.
We need to find a solution here so that citizens on both sides of the Atlantic can assert their rights with the other partner.
A second important point where we have similar foundations but very different approaches is climate protection.
That is why I very much hope that it will become a topic and that it will be discussed clearly.
The European Union must not use the transatlantic dialogue to weaken its own promises and commitments.
For the first time, investment fund managers are experiencing a certain degree of transparency and rules in this opaque thickness of hedge funds and alternative investment funds.
Unfortunately, these rules have remained incomplete.
It is still possible to enter the common market with unregulated products within the framework of passive distribution.
Basically, market access for these products is not effectively restricted.
Europe has given a chance to expand its rules internationally and to come to a uniform regulation.
Secondly, unfortunately, there was no effective debt brake at European level for the funds, unlike the Parliament wanted.
It is still left to national rules to limit how high the debt of the funds can be, and that means that the consequences of the crisis are not drawn at this point.
There will be a national downward race in regulation.
What is crucial for us once again is that the plundering of companies by private equity funds is not effectively omitted.
Of course, there are private equity investments that are useful for companies.
But the rules that have been made so far are unfortunately far from sufficient.
The information rights of the employees, which they rightly expect, as well as the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises from this form of looting are not effective.
Therefore, it is very difficult to justify this to the voters in this case.
Unfortunately, the responsibility for this does not lie with the parliament, it lies especially with the intensive lobbying activity of the relevant industry, successful above all in the British

The government, the French government, but unfortunately I have to say also partly the German one, and we had a representation of these lobbies here in the parliament, rather in the form of the liberal group.
We cannot agree to this proposal, because it would be a precedent for the failure of the parliament to enforce effective rules.
It is not possible for us to stand up to our voters with our heads held high and say that we have managed to effectively regulate this shadow kingdom.
We hope that we will make progress in the revision of the directive.
Thank you again, especially for the cooperation with the colleagues in the parliament.
First of all, many thanks to colleague Balz for the cooperation.
I can only emphasize that it was a good cooperation even with different positions.
Many believed that the crisis in the Eurozone was over.
Ireland shows that this was not the case.
Europe still voluntarily surrenders to the financial markets.
The EU member states must continue to hide their national debt securities on the financial markets'basar and acquire the trust of speculators by saving by committing suicide.
On the weekend we had to observe again where this leads.

This time it was not the allegedly all-inclined Greeks to deception, but the model student Ireland, who was driven into the European rescue fund to save its banking system, which was also considered exemplary for a long time, and was deregulated exemplarily.
Meanwhile, the financial sector is already looking at the capitalization of Portugal, whose interest rates are rising further and further.
The ECB has a share of responsibility for this drama.
She has failed and continues to fail to offer a civilized alternative to the state casino by issuing Eurobonds.
While one half of Europe is recovering from the crisis, the ECB is watching calmly as the other half falls further and further into poverty and uncertainty.
The destruction of entire economies may be to the taste of European funds and bank giants, but neither Ireland, nor the monetary union, nor the ECB have been helped.
Mr. Trichet, don't listen to Mrs. Merkel's simple financial abc.
Secondly, if you want to save the economic and monetary union, do not let the European government bonds hang in the air.
Introduce Eurobonds before the next speculation victim falls.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Commissioner. If you consider how we discussed this proposal from the Commission in the last legislative period, from the total rejection to the jubilation of all the good things coming up about us, then I must say that I am excited about what is now before us.
And here I would like to thank the rapporteur and his co-rapporteurs for making this broad spectrum of opinions a proper opinion.
I believe the magic word for this lies in the patient-oriented approach.
So they didn't take the many side effects, but said, what does the patient need?
I believe it is right that we have decided that the patient can inform himself in different ways and not just in one way.
But I would like to emphasize that the doctor will have to remain the person of trust for the patient and will certainly have influence on crucial issues.
We guarantee this because we have banned advertising for this and the information the patient receives has been checked and approved by an authority.
This means that the information is first scientifically supported, and the patient can handle it safely.
Of course it is right that not everyone can investigate this.
We have different ways to do this, and I believe it is so widespread that we don't need to worry about it.
I only hope that the Council finally has the courage to take up this issue.
It is very important that we act quickly.
The patients expect that.
I think we have done a good job. Thank you.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. Coal is part of the energy supply, that is undeniable.
It is also undisputed that competitiveness must be secured and that subsidies cannot be the right way.
The question now is whether the date with two hundred and fourteen or two hundred and eighteen is the right one.
Colleague Rabke has presented a lot of clever arguments that I don't need to repeat.
My request to the Commission is actually only that there is obviously a large majority in all the committees involved in the Parliament to affirm that competitiveness must be the criterion.

But that in the question of the date, the necessary flexibility is simply created, which is secure, in order to also create the possibility that the member states can realize it and that the burdens for the people, for jobs, for economic structures remain manageable.

The only argument that was mentioned, which, incidentally, was also in contrast to the Commission's impact, which seemed to be in favor of 2018, was the argument that climate policy reasons could play a role here.
I want to emphasize this aspect again: It doesn't change whether you burn foreign coal or your own coal for the sake of the climate.

My request to the Commissioner is to think about whether this four-year period, if such a new argumentation arises in Parliament and in the Council, can lead to the Commission also becoming a bit more active.
I just understood the hint that the Commission is thinking about it, and I thank them for that.

Mr. President, Minister, Commissioner. If we have to learn a lesson from Copenhagen, where you, Commissioner, have the presidency, then it is that the European Union must speak with one voice at such conferences in the future.

We may have different opinions here or there, but if we Europeans speak with different voices there, then our weight will not be credible, and if we are not credible, then other people will not follow us.
Why should they?
That is why it is right that the numbers we decided on at the end of the year two thousand and two under Chancellor Merkel must basically be valid and represent the foundations of these negotiations.

I share your opinion that the ambitious goals of two degrees today should not be seriously questioned to a significantly lower number of degrees, because this makes the fulfillability of these goals extremely difficult and makes people run away from us.
I am very concerned that we are questioning our intellectual property.
So our industry invests money and manpower to develop things.
If we now loosen the fence around this intellectual property and leave the holes as they are at the moment, then the valuable parts, namely our property, will run away.
I am very much in favour of technology transfer, but our companies must also see a sense in investing in it, and that is why intellectual property must not be diluted.
As for the obligations, I also tend to demand serious obligations from our partners worldwide.
But they must be credible, and they must be feasible for these countries.
Otherwise we will do exactly the opposite of what we want, namely they will move away from us.
So, to appear credibly in Cancun is an important point.
The big decisions will be made later in Johannesburg, but in Cancun we should prepare the ground.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in order, nothing will happen with the harvest.
Let's focus on good academics.
Mr. President. There was an incident during the debate on the European Council this morning, which I myself do not want to address anymore, because I was the target of an insult.
But I want to say that there are levels at which I cannot be insulted and where I do not feel it as an insult, because to insult me you have to have a certain degree of seriousness.
However, I would like to thank you for the countless signs of solidarity that I have received here in this house since then.
I would like to thank you, dear colleagues from all the groups.
I think this is a sign of our common, democratic and pro-European conviction, which the overwhelming majority of this house shares.
For that, my heartfelt thanks.

Mr. President, dear Commissioner, dear Minister, dear Mr. Gosses, dear colleagues and shadow rapporteurs. I am pleased that we have now taken this step, that for the first time a sector of the European financial system is placed under European direct supervision.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe in an internal market, towards strong control over a sector that has contributed to the crisis.
I would like to make one more remark, dear Mr. Barnier. The selection processes for the new authorities are currently underway, and the new authorities are only as good as the staff.

I can only hope that the selection of staff will really be about expertise, independence from the financial industry they are supposed to control, and a clear service to the public interest, and that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process that go beyond these important criteria.
Furthermore, there is still much to be done in the area of rating agencies.

We still do not have proper transparency of the information that the rating agencies work with. We have far too much use of regulatory ratings in the financial sector and in the regulations on the financial industry.
We have serious conflicts of interest, we have a clear market power of three major providers, and we have no liability for negligently created ratings.
Therefore, I ask you, Commissioner, it is good that the consultation is now underway and we are eagerly awaiting the results.
I think that civil society should also participate in this consultation. But then it must also be about making a courageous proposal.
I am already looking forward to your suggestion.
Be as courageous as you have been so far and let us make legislation together next year that really solves the problems that still exist in the rating market at European level.
We owe this to the citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Barnier, colleagues. The damage that rating agencies can cause has been shown by the last few months since the beginning of this year.
There is an urgent need for action.
Therefore, I welcome the directive, or in this respect I also welcome the fact that the ESMA would transfer the supervision and registration of rating agencies.
I think this is an important and good step forward.
However, numerous good and further proposals were left out of the report during the negotiations.
I would like to point this out once again.
The mandate of the ESMA remains the only real and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public database for the creation of ratings have been dropped, and there is no reference to the establishment of a public rating agency.
The consistent and continuous review of the ratings created by the supervisory authorities has also been overlooked.

The Commission had continued to propose the promotion of unassigned ratings in order to overcome the disastrous issuer orders for the evaluation of financial market products, but nothing has remained of that either.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into account in the reports still pending on this topic, which Jean Paul Groset and you, Mr Barnier, have also spoken about. Thank you.
Mr. Chairman, Commissioner, dear colleagues. First of all, thank you to those who worked on this report, especially to colleague Benson.
I want to point out two aspects and perhaps make a little thought.
We agree that energy efficiency and energy-saving use are the solution, the simplest and most sensible.
The question is how we achieve this goal.
And I would like to ask the question: What has it actually brought that we in the parliament have repeatedly approached the people with new and higher percentages?
Have we really achieved more and moved more?
Or why and in which places has energy been handled more economically?
I learn that the industry that consumes a lot of energy is more economical with energy because it saves money and because it is cheap for them.
I learn that people, when they know that this device consumes more or less energy, when they see it and can decide for themselves an advantage, then they will decide for it.
Perhaps the method is not right to work with percentages, but the method is right to move forward with incentives.
Second question The Commissioner has just very clearly and convincingly presented how complicated the description of the term itself is. What is it actually?
How differently does this take place in the member states?
The colleague just pointed out that the member states also have very different situations economically and geographically, totally different.
Is it the right answer to work with a number, with a binding number, or do we need to come up with more?

I think we need to break away from the debate of the past in energy policy, which thinks that we can achieve something with simple numbers, binding targets and miracle solutions. Because obviously we haven't achieved enough.
Maybe we should try the other way of differentiated, different answers that take into account different situations and sensitivities, but then also achieve effects.
It depends on the effects, it doesn't depend on our sensitivity.
This regulation, which is being discussed today, has not received much attention in all committees for a long time.
Now, at the end, when the result was available, some people in this house have woken up.
Unfortunately, some have not appeared for the debate now. It would have been very exciting to hear their opinions as well.
As a former member of the Convention, the spirit of the Convention is still very clear to me.
who has clearly demanded in many areas that the European Parliament must be given certain rights in order to have and maintain its credibility within the institutions and towards the citizens.
In this respect, what the Convention has given us has not yet been given.
It was extremely difficult negotiations, especially led by the Belgian Presidency towards the Council, which made it possible to achieve some important progress.
I recall what colleague Lehne has already said, that was the question of the constant possibility of reviewing whether the Commission has exceeded its competences.
Of course, there are some not quite ideal regulations, such as international trade agreements, but I can still agree with the result.
I thank the Belgian Presidency.
She really pushed hard for something to happen and our rapporteur, who negotiated with heart and brain.
In 2013 I would like to make the following statement on behalf of our group. This is a motion that my colleague GÃ¶ran FÃ¤rm had made on behalf of our group in the Budget Committee.
We have not reintroduced this amendment, but the Green Party has reintroduced the amendment with forty signatures from Green Members.
We will abstain from this motion.
I also reached an understanding with my colleagues from the Greens. We are absolutely in agreement on this matter.
But since we have basically said that we will not submit any new amendments as a group, we will abstain.

But I would like to expressly say that we support this point of the financial transaction tax and hope that the colleagues on the other side of the house will support us in the votes in the next few days.
It is important that we do not use national tax systems against the internal market.
This is especially important for cross-border services. Equal treatment is required here.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retroactive price limits were used for crisis taxation.
This is not acceptable, especially the financial insurance and trading industry, but also energy is heavily affected here.
I hope that this will not be used in the area of health services in the future.
I would also like to ask President Orban to review these regulations, because they in themselves completely violate the internal market concept.
It is important that the EU deals with the problems of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has submitted corresponding proposals.
Currently, there is no precise analysis of the implementation of existing legal regulations.
There are hardly any mature calculations and analyses for the new proposals either.
I can say that the EPP is committed to the right to asylum and the right to protection for vulnerable people without restrictions.
However, looking at reality also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is used for completely different reasons or even targetedly abused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for the general immigration of the seven and twenty member states.
We also have to make sure that organized human traffickers do not get a chance to make their fortune billions of dollars from our asylum law on the fate of people.
Asylum procedures must be carried out in a qualified and careful manner.
The persecuted must have the guarantee to find protection in the EU.
Therefore, the Commission has provided for corresponding obligations in the new drafts.
I think many of them are right, such as interpreters, proper health care, and consideration of special vulnerability.
However, I also want to mention points that I consider problematic.
The authorities of the member states are given far too few opportunities to prevent abuse.
The possibility of carrying out accelerated procedures and border procedures should be restricted excessively.

If an applicant massively violates his obligations to participate, there are hardly any possibilities for sanctions, quite the opposite. If he disappears illegally, the member state should no longer be able to end his procedure negatively, and if he reappears, he should be given an extended range of procedural possibilities.
Even if there is obvious unfoundedness, an accelerated procedure should be possible after the second follow-up request.
This means considerable cost increases.
Also, free legal advice in the form of a lawyer is currently a significant cost increase for the states according to the Commission's draft.
I simply ask the Commission to reconsider the consequences of its proposals on the practical reality, the financial implications and the problems for the administrations of the member states.
We want a high standard, but it must also be feasible and must not put particularly burdened member states in front of completely impossible tasks.
Mr. President, thank you for allowing me to speak again.
I have a big request for you, Commissioner FÃ¼hle.
I want to start by saying that false assumptions lead to false cost estimates.
We currently have no decreasing numbers in the area of asylum seekers, but clearly increasing numbers.
This has to do with visa facilitation for Serbia and Macedonia, for example.
We are currently also experiencing a massive increase in the abuse of the right to asylum in an attempt to enter a country of the European Union.

If one assumes that the initial procedure would be disputed in a higher qualified form, which would save costs in further instances, one automatically assumes that all member states have a bad initial procedure.
But that is not the case.
If you increase the standards overall, it will consequently lead to cost increases.
I am happy to discuss the increase in quality standards for everyone and also the complication of procedures in practical reality, which leads to more costs.
Therefore, I would like to ask once again to take the concerns of the countries seriously, because the practical reports from the countries are partly there and are also given.
Mr. President, dear colleagues. This report certifies the Commission's successful competition policy.
However, it should not be forgotten that unregulated competition can also contribute to an increase in unemployment and a growing gap between the poor and the rich.
Unhindered competition still ranks in the European Union before the social needs of the people.
The credo for free markets cannot overestimate the fact that they not only fail again and again, but are also unable to permanently establish social justice.
A few procedures for distortion of competition and price agreements do not solve this problem.
A fair and at the same time social internal market only works with strong and fair regulation.
More is urgently needed for this.
For example, it is not acceptable to always subject public services to private competition.
The report formulates indications for the Commission's future competition policy.
Much stronger consumer protection, the removal of public services from competition rules and the control of cartels, all of this is urgently needed.
Furthermore, a contractual clause for secure social progress would be necessary, which is at least on an equal footing with the competition rules in Europe.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is a really important hour that we are remembering the Holocaust of Roma and Sinti for the first time in the European Parliament.
Let me start with the farewell letter that a fourteen-year-old boy Robert Reinhardt wrote in 1943 before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz.
He wrote, I have found my parents again.
We are on the way to the concentration camp.
I have struggled so much inside that I can endure death.
I thank you once again for everything you have provided me.
Greetings to everyone, goodbye in heaven.
Your Robert.

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return like five hundred other Roma and Sinti. Although Roma and Sinti, together with Jews, became the first victims of factory-based mass killings, today, sixty-six years later, the full truth about it is still unspoken.
And the complicity of the majority society is often covered up.
We need the whole truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust against Roma and Sinti must be punished and recognized as a crime against humanity, so that this story does not happen again.
We must fight the prejudices against these people with passion.
We must put an end to racist hostilities and violence, such as those that took place in Hungary the year before last, and we must do so with civil courage.
Freedom, equality and solidarity are not privileges of individuals, but the right of all, because human and civil rights are indivisible.
Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues. In my view, it is now about really taking advantage of the possibilities of the law.
To exploit this in the sense of strong financial supervision in Europe. We have doubts whether these possibilities are really exploited institutionally.
We see shortcomings in the procedure. We have not received the candidate list as a parliament in advance, but only the final result.
It would be easy to send them to us now for the executive directors.

We have a clear lack of gender justice in the filling of positions, and due to certain incidents in the process, we have doubts that the member states really fill these institutions in the European interest.
This and the other points in our letter legitimize asking a fundamental question.
But beyond that, of course, it is about the suitability of the individual persons, and each person must be judged individually and according to their competences.
There we see two major problems.
We saw in the hearing that one of the candidates denied that it was a European institution, but spoke of a network of supervisory authorities and was not willing to correct it even on request.
We have not received any clear statements on the question of whether you are willing to make all lobby contacts with the financial industry transparent.
We sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us the outcome of the vote depends on whether we get clear and comprehensive answers to it.
Mr. President. As a social democratic group, we have to submit the same request.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and the House that we be a bit more precise.
We are dealing with a very enormous influx.

And Italy is, like any other country in the Mediterranean region, certainly overwhelmed to cope with the current problem alone. And Italy will certainly not be the only country that will be confronted with the massive influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece and Spain will also be confronted with the problem in the foreseeable future.

Therefore, our request would be that we formulate the title of the debate very precisely, namely a statement by the Commission on the immediate measures of the European Union to support Italy and other EU countries that are affected in dealing with the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I expressly welcome the result of the conciliation procedure.

With the implementation of the regulation, it will be possible to achieve a high level of protection for all passengers, including those with limited mobility, in the area of bus transport, which is comparable to the standard of other modes of transport.
Secondly, a high level of general consumer protection is ensured, and thirdly, the specifics are taken into account, as it is a transport sector dominated by small and medium-sized enterprises.

This would have made the extreme demands that would have made bus transport almost impossible due to excessive demands just as much off the table as demands in which the majority of the member states would have been completely excluded from the scope of the regulation.
Bus services that benefit citizens in general must also offer high quality to disabled people and people with limited mobility.
They should be entitled to help, and for the sake of social integration, it should be free.
Madam Chair. I would like to congratulate everyone, especially my colleague Kancian, for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy work of drafting a compromise on this difficult dossier.
There were successes that have already been listed, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope and other trickery that have already been presented.
With this compromise for bus transport, we have covered passenger rights for all modes of transport.
The next necessary step is to create a common, coherent and efficient framework program for all passenger rights.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the credibility of the EU among European citizens.
And in order to be credible, the coherence of the rights for the different modes of transport must be respected.
It is no different that fundamentally different criteria apply to the rights of airline passengers than, for example, train passengers.

Therefore, it is particularly important that we do not lose sight of the lowest and weakest standards when drawing up a framework programme, but that we do not lose sight of ambitious goals in the interest of the citizens.

Madam President, dear colleagues. We are in a major economic crisis, we have been talking about it for months, that is all true, but we usually talk in headlines and then decide here more cheerfully than if nothing had happened.
I think it is because we in the parliament are not behaving specifically enough and honestly enough, but this is a headline policy that is happening.
What is really being done to promote growth and stability?
Do we also contribute to handling finances more properly and wisely?
Do we really have a critical examination of whether we are making the right expenses, or does not every day of us have a new idea where we can still spend money?

If we do not have the strength to concentrate the financial resources on future projects, that is, disputes and conflict and decisions, then it makes no sense to talk about innovation and research, but not to make the resources available for it.
That is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, we also have to make a policy that stimulates the economy and does not think from morning to night about how we can disrupt industry or the economy.
We are making more decisions with enthusiasm, and we are constantly demanding new decisions today that are disturbing the economy in its development.
Does anyone believe that the issue of binding energy efficiency targets, to name just one example, contributes to the promotion of the economy?
Do you really think that with our decisions, which we have often made in connection with energy, we have stimulated the economy?
Or did we disturb you?
I would like us to talk about this a bit more honestly and then make a few fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that really make progress.
This is more exhausting, more laborious, it will also mean disputes, but that is the meaning of democracy.
Mr. President. Colleagues. The demand for a financial transaction tax is not new. For several years, opponents of globalization have been calling for such a tax.
But even five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be enforced in the foreseeable future.
But this week it is on the agenda in the European Parliament, along with a CO2 tax and Euro bonds, and I think that is a good thing.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments that Anni Podimata proposes in her report, and I think we will also vote accordingly.
These are urgently needed instruments.
The consolidation of public budgets has so far focused solely on cutting spending.
However, the reduction of public spending primarily affects workers, pensioners and the poor, i.e. those who are dependent on the welfare state.
The income side of the public sector has been completely overlooked so far.
It is the second screw that can be turned to consolidate public budgets.
But above all, the main causes of the public debt crisis can also be adequately involved in the repayment of public debt through the revenue side.
To consolidate public budgets, an increase in tax revenues is simply essential.

In fact, the high debt of public budgets is mainly a consequence of the nationalization of private debt, namely the takeover of debt by private banks and the financing of the consequences of the financial crisis by the public sector.
The responsibility for the debt crisis is by no means borne by the states alone.
It is therefore not only obvious, but also politically necessary to ask the financial sector to pay.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally become the main cause of public debt and be involved in the payment of these debts.
This is an important political signal that comes from this report if it is adopted as it has been presented.
But we also consider Eurobonds to be a sensible and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to the reduction of debt than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice.

The complaints of some surplus countries that their interest burden is increasing through Eurobonds are not acceptable, because at the same time these surplus countries also earn through their exports to deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
But whoever wants a social Europe, whoever wants the EU to remain together in the future, must at least agree to a transfer union in principle.
Finally, I would like to say to the Commission that I hope that it will finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax that have been demanded for over a year.
Mr. President, the rescue packages should protect the EU member states from insolvency.
But they overpower people with brutal austerity programs and leave the cause parts untouched. In addition, the Commission is now also interfering in national wage policies.
Dear Mr. Hahn, it is absurd and it drives tears in your eyes when you hear this formal argumentation that it was not meant to be social policy at all.
This position is completely unacceptable. Wage policy is not the EU's business. This Commission policy is in blatant contradiction with the idea of this European Union.
The European Union has never been a project for downward wage competition and social dumping.
There is talk of rigidity, of wages that are to be reduced.
That means that wages should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, blind people talk about color. People who formulate such things have no idea about collective bargaining systems.
They interfere with collective bargaining autonomy and introduce the much-awaited autonomy of the social partners and social dialogue to the point of absurdity.

I want to make it clear that this Parliament is required to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, to protect social dialogue and to prevent further reduction of social security.
We need measures against a counterproductive austerity policy and punitive measures. Thank you.
Mr. Barroso, you are a clever man, but you didn't answer my question.
