Therefore, I ask again: When Mr Oettinger says that we currently suspect that certain plants that are on the network will not survive our stress tests, do I interpret that you are aware that these plants are so poorly secured that they do not meet the criteria?
Why don't you intervene today?
Because in my eyes this is a real danger.
Mrs. Gabriele Zimmer has the floor. I would like to ask the two representatives of the Council and the Commission why they believe they have to come up with speech bubbles on this topic.
I believe it doesn't help anyone if it is not stated quite specifically that the member states of the European Union and the European Union are preparing for the Istanbul Conference.
It must finally fully comply with its obligations for development aid, and it cannot be tolerated in any way that member states increasingly evade this obligation.
It is unacceptable that a billion people still go hungry every day and that most of them live in the LDCs, the poorest countries in the world.

It is unacceptable that a large part of our development aid does not go to the promotion and development of agricultural structures, but that this share has rapidly decreased in recent years, that among a billion starving people
And then to talk about it, we hope that the LDCs will become more shock-resistant, I think that is already cynical.
I call on you to address the problems in a concrete and clear manner and to take on concrete commitments to actually help the LDCs.
In the context of the internal market, public procurement law and the awarding of public contracts are an essential component.

Mr. Barnier, if you say you also want to promote social integration in this context, then I have to ask you, I have heard little about the protection of social rights, I have heard little about the protection of collective agreements.
This is one of the basic rules that you, as you say, do not want to question yourself.

If you want to protect basic rules, you have to ensure that basic social standards are protected in the future when awarding public contracts, that collective agreements are not eroded and that wage dumping is prevented.
This is part of a modernized public procurement law.
I say explicitly that social fundamental rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe or we want a permanent conflict with the people who turn away from this Europe, in which they do not see their livelihood interests safeguarded.
Madam President, Commissioner Kruse, radio frequencies are a precious and limited asset that must be managed with care, foresight and from an overall societal perspective.
Therefore, the Radio Spectrum Policy Programme is of particular importance.
Radio frequencies must be used efficiently taking into account economic, social and cultural aspects.
To do this, the technical possibilities must be used to the fullest extent in all band areas in order to generate the greatest possible efficiency.

The basis of the radio frequency policy must be the telecommunications package adopted last year, because it was also established that the radio frequency management of the EU and its member states must equally meet cultural, social and economic interests.
This must be taken into account especially when harmonizing frequency use in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend I has been implemented at very different speeds in the member states so far.
Therefore, further opening of the UAF band, especially below eight hundred megahertz, should only be considered taking into account the experience of clearing this band.
Many technical and financial issues have not yet been finally resolved.

The interference issue and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities in the technical retrofitting, for example in the area of radio microphones, have not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
When distributing the frequency bands, the different interests must be weighed responsibly.

On the one hand, the comprehensive supply of mobile broadband networks is a basic requirement in the interest of European citizens. At the same time, however, development in the area of public and private broadcasting as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity must continue to be taken into account.
We must set the course for the technical development of Europe's positioning in the field of digital information technology and cultural diversity.
Mr. President, dear Mr. Rehn. I would like to say first of all, as you have described, the situation has worsened.
The Eurozone, the gap between countries that are recovering and countries that are weaker.
And the costs of supporting weaker countries are always rising.

In this situation, I have some questions for you. As the ECB's currency commissioner, I ask you: On the ECB's day two accounts, liabilities and claims between central banks in the amount of over four hundred billion euros have accumulated.
This is because banks are still not sufficiently financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these liabilities not provided for in the Eurosystem?
Then the big problem, why we are not making progress with the restructuring of the debt, is that the banking system, as Mrs. Ford also said, is not set up correctly.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When will the Commission present this?
And how do you, as Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, assess this delay?
What are you doing to make it faster?
Then we saw, as we Greens had already predicted for a long time, that the measures against Greece and Portugal would not work as long as the macroeconomic conditions in the Eurozone were not better.
We still have absolutely rising interest burden macroeconomically for these countries.
during increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries.
And we still have a lack of demand from several European partner countries, especially from the strong Euro countries.
And we have rising resources and food prices, at least if you calculate the latest up and downs.

I wonder, in addition to the bailout for these countries, in addition to the aid on the financing side, what measures are being taken so that the weaker countries get relief on these fronts, taxes, on the front demand from outside, on the question of interest?
And you?
I would therefore encourage you to propose a strong package that improves the macroeconomic conditions of these countries in the Eurozone.

And lastly, in my view, the measures have been against the spirit of the EU treaty in the countries of Greece, Portugal, Spain, especially the weakest, while the stronger, the wealthy, have not been used to share the burden so far.
What measures are you taking to ensure that the wealthy are also used to contribute to the costs of this crisis?
Mr. President. Mrs. Kinga GÃ¶nz is a member of my group.
You can be against Ferenc Joachani, you can be for Ferenc Joachani.
One can reject or be in favor of Kinga GÃ¶nz as a politician.
It is certainly free and independent for everyone to determine whether or not they are for or against a person's political beliefs.
The debate we are having here is about the last dictatorship that exists in Europe.
And we are leading them over one of the most brutal and bloodiest dictatorships that exist on the European continent.
I find it absolutely unacceptable that a freely elected democratic member of my group is compared to a bloodthirsty dictator.

I think that the parliament must also reject this, especially from the representative of a party that is characterized by the fact that it overwhelms the Roma minority in Hungary with a hatred and persecution that is similar to it in Europe.
If a person does not have the right to criticize Mrs. Kinga GÃ¶nz, then it is Mrs. Mauvin.
Mrs. von der Leyen has the floor, Mr. President, dear colleagues, dear visitors. The cultural diversity of Europe is an important asset that must be preserved and expanded in the future.
In order to make this possible, we must face the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the cultural and creative sector.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, but it also represents a significant economic factor.
In the EU, about five million people are employed in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to about two and a half percent of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that is developing faster than many areas of the rest of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is being driven by the content offered by the cultural sector, just as the type and quality of content has changed and evolved through technology.
Therefore, we need framework conditions for the cultural and creative industries in which they can develop sustainably in view of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
The cultural and creative industries are a driving force for Europe.
Therefore, we must also pay attention to this area in the area of school and vocational education.
We must convey cultural and creative competences to young people and also in the offers of lifelong learning.
But we also need to strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural creators, and not only entrepreneurial competences, but also good media competence in the field of new technologies.
We need framework conditions in which cultural creators can secure their livelihood.

Therefore, we will have to deal intensively with the issues of copyright, social security and intellectual property, as well as open access to information and content, in order to be able to continue developing.

to secure the creative and cultural industry in a digital environment in the future as well, and to be able to preserve the cultural diversity and cultural heritage of Europe as a key feature of the European Union.
Mr. President, dear colleague Kellam, dear colleagues from the Baltic countries, dear colleagues. Today we commemorate in particular the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These expulsions are among the darkest events in European history.
In fact, the last century was not only and not least because of this, and not unjustly, called a century of expulsions.
And today we all bow before the victims of these inhumane actions.
In this context, we demand a complete explanation of Soviet history and in particular the atrocities of Stalinism.

Today's Russia should not see this as a political attack, but as support for the processing of its own history, which is characterized by sunny and shadowy times, just like the history of other European countries.
But just as we think of the victims from the Baltic countries, we think of the Armenians who were driven out of Turkey at the beginning of the last century.
We remember the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
Deportations in Europe reached a special peak in the middle of the century due to the Nazi regime and the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The expulsions after the Second World War also dealt deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav war.
But we must not forget that many colonial rule was marked by expulsions.
We must demand a serious deal with the various forms of expulsions and fake justifications.
And this also includes clarifying the guilt and punishing the guilty, as far as possible, as is the case with Mladic, for example.

But the decisive answer is European unification, especially through and with the independent Baltic countries, and a clear commitment to the continuation of the European unification process that has not yet been completed.
This historical task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but especially to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many politicians from all European countries, from East and West, have worked on it.
For example, let's think of the Danzig Declaration signed by Polish President Wojciechowski and German Federal President Rau.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must be vigilant, also with regard to the first approaches of expulsion, such as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all statements, such as the idea that Arab immigrants should be sent back across the Mediterranean in boats, and we must defend ourselves if some want to repeal the achievements of Europe without borders and return to a new narrow nationalism.
Let us bow in reverence to all the victims of the expulsion and deportation, but let us unanimously commit to continuing European unification as the only real guarantee against a

This is a policy that has brought so much misfortune to people in Europe, but also beyond, in the last century. Never forget, never again were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have not lost any of their validity, they are best lifted in a common Europe.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues. As an election observer of the Parliament, I had the opportunity to experience the referendum on the independence of South Sudan, and I was impressed by the great consent of the South Sudanese to want to determine the fate of their country themselves in the future.
I also saw the high expectations among the people who saw the independence of their country as a liberation from slavery.

Thousands, maybe tens of so-called internally displaced persons who drove the decades-long fighting in the south into the refugee camps in the north made their way to their former South Sudanese homeland.

And of course, the people of South Sudan want to take a path to a happier future, especially in peace, after all the decades of war conflicts in which millions of South Sudanese had to lose their lives.
On July 9th, the new state of South Sudan is to become officially independent and expand the family of states of our world.
The starting conditions are conceivably bad, and a lot has already been said about this.
Seventy percent of people live as urbanizing cattle breeders, eighty percent are illiterate. The conflict over AbiyÃ© is expanding into a military conflict.
There were already dead and wounded there.

As if that were not enough, the rivalries between the tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also increasing, and according to observers, more than one thousand people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and the defiled are hardly counted.
Sudan was already one of the failed states.
There is a danger that the state of South Sudan will already begin as a failed state.
I am firmly convinced that there is a great commitment from Europe to this region.
In view of the colonial past of the countries there. Together with the UN and the African Union, a common European foreign policy is required here, and it can also prove itself here.
It is not just about money, but also about supporting the delicate, emerging civil society.

And we must negotiate hard with those who share the fate of the country, namely the tribal leaders led by the military groups, so that they do not disappoint the hopes of their people in the country. Thank you.
Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. I am very grateful to my colleague Bartolozzi for making Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament with the initiative of this request.
While the former Soviet states of Central Asia are now being discussed in the parliament from different perspectives, Mongolia and its situation here have only found a very sparse echo.
It was Mongolia, which as a state of the former communist bloc used its independence quite early on and took a path towards the democratization of its society, very rightly so.

As early as 1992, the Mongols gave themselves a democratic constitution, and since then several elections have taken place, which, according to observers, have all been democratic and correct, which is not a given for the states in this region.

The Mongolian government has been trying to fight corruption by law for several years and has issued a moratorium on the death penalty in 2010, which even some large democratic states have not yet managed to do.
Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this large country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, are suffering from the consequences of a transformation process that is still ongoing.
And so a rural population that has so far still been predominantly nomadic is pushing into the few cities that are not infrastructurally prepared for it.
The country's mineral resources are not being mined in an environmentally friendly way.
Energy problems make civil and economic life more difficult.
Crammed between the large neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia is threatened to become even more dependent than before.

The efforts and successes of Mongolia and here I see the glass half full and not half empty in the democratization of society should be recognized, as they are exemplary for this region and show what is possible despite a difficult past.
Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only within the framework of aid programs, but also by the European Union being directly present in the Mongolian capital with its own
Representation as a sign that the fate of Mongolia is not indifferent to us Europeans and that European interests are no longer perceived by the representation in Beijing. One more sentence, please.
I regret very much that the Conference of Presidents was not willing to give this concern even more emphasis by adopting a resolution of the Parliament.
But, dear colleague, of course I recognize this right.
I only assume and hope that you also recognize the right that the position of the Dutch government is not announced ex cathedra, but is released for discussion in a multinational democracy.
I have absolute respect for Mr. RÃ¼the, who is in favor of a two point seven percent increase in the EU budget.
I have taken note of that and I am glad that you listened to me carefully, because in this Parliament the attitudes of all governments are openly discussed.
In this respect, I didn't quite understand the meaning of your question, but what I thought I heard was that you also commit to democracy.
This is already a step forward.

Firstly, I reacted so excitedly because I am still annoyed that we did not manage to get a joint resolution on security here, because the absolutization of a position was more important than the unity.

Secondly, I explained in the debate at the time and I will explain it again now, that I also learned and today I see that we must do more in the area of more safety regulations for European nuclear power plants, we must exert more pressure, we must show more initiative.
This is exactly why I was in favour of the joint resolution, and that is why I am in favour of strengthening the Commissioner's back and not constantly attacking him.

Mr. President, regarding the intermediate category. I could have imagined other solutions at the beginning, for example, after the regions that have had the highest requirements so far and will no longer have them after 2013 receive a transitional arrangement.
However, the discussion showed that we have to consider other regions, especially those affected by the crisis.
We are currently talking about fifty-one regions.
And in view of so many affected regions, it would be downright negligent not to establish an intermediate category.
Only in this way can a reliable framework for the responsible promotion of these regions, which must reduce their own development backlogs.
Otherwise, there is a lot of light and a lot of shadow to be seen in the Pieper report.

We criticize, among other things, that there is no clear commitment to a much more decisive fight against poverty and consider formulations, such as those contained here, to link cohesion policy with conditionalities that force member states to carry out reforms, to be unclear and very broadly interpretable.
The point is that cohesion policy must remain an instrument of social balance and solidarity in all regions.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues. In the future, interregional cooperation will become more and more important.
Cross-border cooperation and macro-regional cooperation are extremely important for achieving the goals of 2020 in a growing Europe.
Border regions still face special challenges today.

Cross-border concepts and projects, such as in the areas of infrastructure, business cooperation, research cooperation, labor market development and further education, are the engine for large parts of the European Union.
We need clear and simplified structures in the handling of interregional projects.
Different national requirements for project partners often make it difficult to cooperate and implement concrete, sustainable projects.
It is an important step that the Pieper report includes the demand for an increase in the share for interregional cooperation target three to seven, and I would like to strongly support this.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. After almost three years of intensive work, after far more than three amendments, after countless conversations, discussions,

After the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogues, the political package, the great compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers on the future labelling of foodstuffs, is now up for a vote.
This regulation is intended to provide the consumer with more and better information about food, so that he can make a targeted purchasing decision.
But that is not all. The European food industry should also benefit.
The goal is legal certainty, deregulation and better lawmaking.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises, and it must be known that the food sector in the European Union consists of SMEs to over eighty percent.
At the same time, this labeling must be suitable for every food and every alcohol-free drink, from basic food to highly processed ready-made dishes.
That is why mandatory labelling in traffic light colors is not possible, because this labelling does not fit basic foodstuffs.

Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political and ideological differences in the parliament, despite all the national egoisms of the member states, the compromise that has now been reached can be seen.
Allergens will be recognizable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is indicated.
There is an origin marking for pork, poultry, sheep and goat meat.

For other products, an impact assessment will show whether and how the origin can be indicated, for example for milk and dairy products, single ingredients, i.e. products that consist of a main ingredient, meat in processed
Products etc. Imitations will have to be clearly labeled on the front, and the same applies to meat and fish, made of small pieces.
A packaging must not give the impression that there is something in it that is not in it.
If a picture of fruits is on a yogurt, there must also be fruits in it, not just color and flavorings.
Additionally, there is the mandatory indication of the most important nutrients, always per one hundred grams or one hundred milliliters, for reasons of comparability.
Added water in meat must be marked, the date of the first deep-sea freeze in meat and fish, and many more details.
But the most important thing is that all information must be legible.

We have defined readability, we have set a minimum font size and we have instructed the Commission to establish binding rules for further factors, such as the contrast between the font and the background.
At the same time, we protect the craft from too high costs and bureaucracy.
Unpackaged fresh products must provide allergens, but not complete nutritional information, which can be determined by expensive analyses.
The Commission originally wanted this, but it would have destroyed our national and regional specialties and specialties, it would have led to European unification, and that is why we prevented it.
But now we have all agreed, and the serious consumer protectors are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

I would like to thank all those involved, the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission, especially Commissioner Dalli, for his explanations, which he will hopefully give soon, and with which he will break the knot that has formed in our political discourse.

And I would like to thank the Hungarian Presidency of the Council, which has achieved something that was almost not to be expected, almost the quadrature of the circle, the agreement on this regulation. Thank you very much.
Mr. Chairman, dear Commissioner, dear Polish Presidency of the Council, allow me to join your thanks to the rapporteur, Mrs. Ayala Sender.
As already mentioned, the Council has been blocking progress on this dossier since 2008 until a compromise could finally be reached under the Belgian Presidency.
As mentioned, improved data exchange between member states should enable cross-border prosecution of various traffic offences throughout Europe in the future.
The top goal must be to increase road safety and reduce the number of traffic fatalities and injuries.

Together with Dieter Koch's initiative report on road safety, which makes a number of very concrete proposals, this directive can also contribute to better compliance with these rules through its repressive nature.
I don't need to go into the rules anymore, they have already been presented positively here.
The change of the legal basis from European transport policy to police cooperation has finally allowed the Council to draft a common position.
However, this means that some countries such as the UK, Ireland and Denmark are excluded.
Accordingly, not all European citizens are equal once again.
Citizens must be aware of the rights they have in terms of data protection.
We have tried to strengthen this aspect so that access to the collected data, their transmission and storage are regulated as strictly as possible.
The information was also very important to us.
Although the current text does not fully meet the expectations of the Parliament, I am still optimistic that this is a first step in the right direction.
I hope that we can build on this basis in the coming years in order to take a step towards a stronger harmonization of European traffic regulations.
The revision clause inserted by the parliament would in any case allow such a procedure.
I very much regret that this text has now gotten into the whirlpool of the institutional conflict between the Council and Parliament over the correlation tables.
We agreed during the trilogues to find a common compromise on this issue with the joint declaration.
I would like to briefly remind you that tomorrow the European Road Traffic Association will be in charge of the transport of goods and services.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. First of all, many thanks to Mrs Matthias for this report.

I would also like to thank my colleagues who have prepared reports before, Mrs. Merkis and Mrs. Carvalho. This is a consequence, and the day is approaching when we will not only make political decisions.
But we also have to prove that we are serious about the reference to research and innovation, which is the crucial question for the future ability of the European Union.
Therefore, I am very grateful that the representative of the Budget Committee also pointed out that sufficient and good financial resources in this area are an important issue.
We will soon have to fight this dispute about whether we have the strength to provide the necessary financial resources so that this area of research and innovation really gains central importance.
It is of central importance for the question of whether and how Europe will develop in the future.
Then, by the way, small and big Sunday speeches are no longer enough, but facts must be delivered.
Second remark We ourselves will not be able to get around it, and this is very nicely worked out in the report, to also take a close look at whether we can use our resources more effectively.
How can we simplify the procedure?
How do we get speed?
How can we make research funding more effective?
How can we get a stronger structure and simplification out of the somewhat unclear labyrinth of different research funding?
Sometimes less is more. Few projects, but a lot of money invested, have a higher effect in the end.
Therefore, I am grateful that we have taken a step further in this report as well.

Of course, the European Research Council, the European Institute of Innovation and Technology will play a special role, and of course, the area of small and medium-sized enterprises is an area that is important.

And last but not least, we also need a solution for the states that must remain the only principle in the promotion of excellence, which is right, compulsory and must remain so in the future. We also need an answer for the states that are not yet so far.
And in this report, the idea of a possible competition also appears, with which one can perhaps also push forward new top research centers in disadvantaged regions.
And that is an important task that still needs to be solved.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. In view of the current extraordinary situation as a result of the financial, economic and budgetary crisis, decisions at European level should focus on urgent and essential issues.
Only in this way can our citizens restore confidence in the seriousness of our actions.
My report is about the strategy to avoid endless human suffering, resulting in about five and thirty deaths and over one point one hundred and fifty deaths per year.
one point five million often serious injuries as a result of road accidents, as well as to avoid the associated economic damage of one hundred and thirty billion euros annually.
The number of fatalities alone corresponds to the number that would be lamented in the crash of two hundred and fifty fully occupied medium-sized traffic planes.
What wouldn't we do to prevent this?
The accident follow-up costs exceed the annual total budget of the European Union considerably.
Therefore, I am sure that we are doing well to act sustainably in this area.

Thanks to the constructive cooperation of all shadow rapporteurs and many colleagues, we have managed to develop a uniform, holistic and coherent approach to improving road safety for the first time with the report.

It takes into account the content of the UN Charter for Road Safety from 2010 to 2020 as well as the content and goals of the road safety work of the EU member states and broad circles of civil society.
Firstly, it includes ambitious but realistic goals for the time until 2020 and with the vision zero for the period beyond.
So it is necessary to reduce the number of accident fatalities by fifty percent by 2020, the number of children killed by sixty percent and the number of seriously injured by forty percent.
This is in the most important interest of each of our people, but also in our economy.
We recommend that the member states break down targets and methods on their territory and expect their own road safety action programs.
Secondly, it includes who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is by far not just the European Union.

In the sense of subsidiarity, the holistic approach means that the member states, regional or municipal authorities, companies, and even every single road user, in the sense of their duty to participate, must take responsibility.
And thirdly, it includes how, with what instruments, activities and measures the goals are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are only one strategy.
We cannot and do not want to do without guidelines, recommendations and orders.
In this context, subsidiarity has been given special attention, which means that responsibilities and competences have been clearly named, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the varied activities of the Commission.

But since they come from the most diverse directorates general, such as transport, economy, consumer protection, environment, communication, research and development, internal market and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes they contradict each other.
Therefore, we propose the establishment of a coordinator for road safety within the European Commission.
This avoids the sustainable establishment of a road safety agency, but it increases the efficiency of the European Commission enormously.
Both the choice of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically based approach based on comparable, high-quality data, definitions and statistics.
We therefore demand, among other things, a harmonized analysis of injury and accident causes, as well as the EU-wide exchange of data while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six main fields of action were identified.
They concern people as road users, road traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructures, their intelligent networking, as well as the special consideration of weaker road users.
I ask for your consent tomorrow.
Dear Chairwoman, dear colleagues. Yes, we should focus on urgent and essential issues in road safety.
I am very convinced of this, and in my view, this primarily concerns the two biggest attention-raisers in traffic, which are alcohol and speeding.
The European Union must also say something about this and not just propose technical measures, which in my view are good, but by far not sufficient.
Especially in cities, the lack of attention makes the problem of inattentive drivers particularly dramatic.
That is why the speed must be reduced here.
I was very positively surprised that there was a broad majority in favor of Tempo thirty as a recommendation.

This must be taken into account in particular, and I think it is important and good that weak road users finally get to the center of attention, and I hope that these measures will finally be implemented.
Mr. President, it seems to me to be pointless, but I would like to extend an invitation to you.
I have never seen him in the consultations about Rio or other major global conferences, but I have always heard him speak here in the plenary.
I would really like to ask you, colleague, to come to the committee.
Deal with us, offer us your offers, and then we will continue to talk to you. Thank you for your comments.
And the contribution you just made, there is nothing you can do about it.
Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your fundamental remarks.
However, these fundamental statements are not an answer to the questions that were asked.
Because the questions are about Is it secured that we will also quickly achieve results?
The industries that we want to exempt from these additional burdens or where we want to create fair conditions need planning security.
Therefore, we need decisions soon.
We need quick decisions, reliable decisions and also clear statements from the Commission.
This process has been going on for a very long time.

We all knew that this was a very complicated procedure that we had to undertake, but at the time we also said in the compromise on the emissions trading directive that we would do it with the emissions trading directive.
On the condition that the industries in Europe that are overburdened can experience a relief, because otherwise they cannot compete with other areas of the world.
I expect that what was the basis for the rules of procedure at the time, the basis for the decision in the parliament, with the council, with the commission, will also be realized in this way.
I am a bit worried that the circle of those affected will become smaller and smaller over time, that the view will become more and more petty, that more and more areas will be excluded.
It's not just about steel, it's about aluminum, you know, it's about many other areas, chemistry and so on, and that you simply don't implement what was the political basis of the decision back then.
Mr Commissioner, you have rightly pointed out that the situation for industry in Europe has not become easier since this decision, but rather more difficult.
We have a completely new situation, we have a much bigger competitive situation.
We all fight for this and explain here in Sunday speeches that industries are a very important area for the future development of Europe.
Yesterday we heard wise speeches again.

I expect the parliament to expect that what was agreed upon back then will be implemented now, and that it will be in the interest of the industries, not the industries, but the people who work in these companies, the jobs and thus also the future opportunities of Europe.
Mr. Commissioner, do you know any example that would actually justify the cost of spending many millions, billions, to develop these body scanners?
Are there examples that prove that this has increased safety?
Mr. President. I would like to start by thanking the Council representative for the very clear description of the current situation.
We have constantly heard in this debate that it is about improving the situation for women who are to decide to have a child.
In my opinion, the directive focuses too much on increasing maternity protection to twenty weeks.
But do we really believe that the decision for one child can be reduced to twenty weeks of maternity protection?

As a mother of three children, I know very well that overall concepts for offers and good offers for families are necessary to positively influence the decision for a child and to create equal opportunities for women.
The present draft directive does not adequately meet the different, some of them very good, offer concepts and overall concepts in some member states.
We need flexible solutions that meet the situation in the member states and societies and the resulting needs of families.
Maximum demands and wish concert do not lead to a solution here.
Therefore, we must first develop a solid and realistic basis for negotiations here in Parliament.
The comprehensive protection of mothers and the well-being of children are of the highest priority.
This can be ensured in different ways with different models.
Whoever wants to crash their head through the wall doesn't necessarily get to the goal faster.
Lack of willingness to compromise does not open doors and does not build bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution for more maternity protection to move forward here.

I believe that we really need to look for an approach based on the Commission's draft directive with more flexibility for different concepts in the individual member states, here to significantly improve maternity protection for women and also protection for children in the first months of life.
This doesn't work with the draft that is available here today, and which certainly didn't have the large majority that some colleagues tried to make clear today.
I would like to see a bit more flexibility, a bit more realism and a bit better insight into what the member states have already achieved today, without questioning our basic demand for this.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to make a few remarks on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have already done.
Instead of putting a stop to tax evasion, which would make sense, instead of plugging loopholes for tax broadcasters, a Swiss cheese with large holes was produced here.
The planned five-month transition period gives taxpayers a lot of time to transfer money from Switzerland to other tax havens.
Since foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is also sufficient to convert the assets stored in Switzerland into foundation assets.
The corresponding forms are available in Swiss banks.
Some time ago, the German tax investigation was informed about several tax evaders who had their assets hidden in Switzerland.
The agreement now grants these individuals an amnesty, and taxpayers are no longer allowed to use the information available to them.
What kind of agreement is this that puts tax evasion in the chain?
In a commercial video of Swiss banks, it is stated accordingly about this agreement that customers will also benefit even better from the values of the Swiss financial market in the future.

This agreement obviously lacks not only the necessary coordination at the EU level, but also the EU's efforts to create more transparency in tax matters, to make tax collection more efficient in the member states and above all to combat and prevent tax fraud.
Therefore, this cannot be acceptable from our point of view.
We ask the EU to take a stand against it in case of doubt.
Mr. President, thank you. According to the rules of procedure of our house and in consultation with the factions, I request the referral of this work back to the committees.
Madam President. I am pleased that we have managed to bring together a sustainable, effective directive with the report by Roberta Angelilli, and I would like to thank her for that.
The directive represents a significant step in the fight against child abuse.
However, we must not lose sight of one thing: the vast majority of crimes still take place in the closest social environment of children.
The perpetrators are found in families, schools and circles of acquaintances.
And here we are still at the beginning of our educational work.

That is why our children must be strong enough to have the courage to trust a nearby person in a serious case, but also strong enough to recognize dangers such as grooming when dealing with the Internet.
We must therefore ensure together that a sense of responsibility in dealing with media plays a greater role in the education of our children.
Education is of the utmost importance, as many teachers and parents do not even know what can be done with their children's computers or mobile phones.
I believe that there is a lot to catch up on.

It is therefore to be welcomed that the present report also places great emphasis on prevention, as authorities, but also schools and families must do everything to prevent such abhorrent crimes from happening in the first place.
Therefore, better negotiation strategies of the EU with third countries such as the USA and Russia are also needed.

And pages stored outside the EU can only be deleted effectively and quickly if we also work closely with these countries in the search for the perpetrators and jointly send a clear signal to the exposure of child sexual abuse.
Once the perpetrator is caught, the legislator has unfortunately often been surprisingly lenient so far and has only put the majority of the crimes on probation.
Here, the severity of the crime should be taken into account more strongly in the future.
However, it is important that the public debate continues, as the topic has the most diverse dimensions.

Prevention, victim protection, technical development, as well as deletion from blocking, judicial enlightenment and intensive scientific documentation of the facts must also be further promoted after tomorrow's vote.
It is so that we must not sit back and do nothing.
Rather, we must all accept the mandate of each of us and ensure prevention and enlightenment.
Mr. President. For years the volume of the EU budget has been at about the same level.
The tasks of the EU have been constantly expanding and the financial needs have increased significantly.
So new necessary institutions have been created with financial market supervision.
However, in order to be able to effectively perform their tasks, these institutions need good financial resources.
As a result of the financial and banking crisis, the economic weaknesses of some EU member states have become unpredictable.
A comprehensive economic stimulus program would be necessary to strengthen the economy of these countries.
Some economic experts even speak of the need for a Marshall Plan for the EU countries that have been shaken by the crisis.
The EU does not need growth-destroying austerity programs, but a growth-promoting spending program that secures work and income for workers and young people in the EU.
But what does the Council do in this situation?
He is cutting back on the Commission proposal, which is far behind the necessities.

If in the current political situation an appropriate increase in the budget is not feasible, then the Parliament and the Commission should do everything to at least reject the cuts proposed by the Council.
This makes it more difficult. Thank you, Mrs. Zimmer. Right now, in the crisis, it is clear what kind of European Union we really want.
Do we want a Union in which the KIT actually exists as a binding link, that we say it doesn't matter to us whether people have to live in poverty in any member state of the European Union?
We see ourselves in the shared responsibility to fight against poverty and social exclusion.
Or do we decide for a union, as it has just been outlined by the colleagues of the right-wing extremist groups of this Parliament?

Sometimes I think that with the attitude of the member states and especially some governments of these member states, we are dangerously close to this vision of a European Union, as it has been formulated by the extreme right.
Do nothing together, do not set common instruments, do not set common indicators, only vague formulations where it is possible.
The third report makes this very clear in many things, and I believe we need to become much stronger here.
What we need is an immediate stop to the sale of public goods, the sale of social security systems.
We need social and ecological minimum standards.
In view of the upcoming winter, it must not happen again that people end up on the streets, are evicted and ultimately freeze due to rising energy prices.
Here we bear a shared responsibility, the responsibility as the European Union.
We must stand up for this and not for this nationalist wash that we have heard from the right side.

What would we have advised our colleagues in 1931 or 1938 when they were in a depression, when the financial markets had already undermined democracies at that time and when they were heading towards wars?
Two things would be necessary, two emergency measures. We need something like a transitional government.
Do what you have to do quickly, don't let yourself be slowed down, regulate every product, every institution and every player like that.
Mrs. Merkel said that a transitional government alone that enforces the financial emergency program cannot have a future if there is no democracy emergency program.
And that means, in this case, of course we need a European community, of course we need other treaties, of course we need a work that works, but only then gets legitimacy when there are referendums.

And for this we must already advocate that the situation has become so dramatic that a very big change of thinking must come before the right, before the national divisors get the upper hand again over something that was actually already built.
Madam Chair. There is no doubt that this House is committed to transparency and openness to the citizen.
Of course, my EPP group does the same.
But the present report goes far beyond the actual goal.
Existing legislation and inter-institutional agreements are ignored, the protection of competition procedures, sensitive and personal data is disregarded.
This is a massive violation of data protection, for which we always fight so hard elsewhere.
Should we now disclose the privacy of the world public?
This is exactly the danger with the present report, because administrative processes and decisions, which also include personnel issues, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information in the context of approval procedures, court proceedings and competition proceedings.

With its vague, unclear, far too broad definitions, the report allows public access to such documents as well. Because as a document, all data and content are defined that are in any connection with the policies, measures, decisions of all EU bodies and institutions.
This largely includes preparatory, confidential and secret documents as well as all related information.
And this definition includes not only documents, but also information.
Information from ongoing inter-institutional procedures, such as informal trilogue negotiations, would also have to be published.
Mr. Rapporteur, do you really know what that means?

It means public access to the procedure, it means public influence on the decision-making process, then we could immediately bring the lobbyists to the table and have them negotiate. Does the citizen want that?
I can't imagine it.
Additionally, documents related to non-legislative procedures, measures of internal administrative organizations, etc. are also to be published. Where is the public interest?
Or would it rather hinder our work?
I think this report is not in the interest of our citizens.
He would bring about a flood of useless information.
It would make our work impossible, and above all, you have heard it from the Commissioner, he is not acceptable to the other institutions because he violates the applicable rules and laws.
You know that, Mr. Rapporteur, and basically you are working against further transparency and against the citizen.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. In such an important and comprehensive topic as the White Paper on the future of transport, there is always a great risk that you end up with a Christmas tree where everyone tries to accommodate their two or three wish topics.
If you look at the result that is to be voted on tomorrow, you can certainly congratulate our rapporteur Mathieu Grosch.

He managed to work out a good, coherent and manageable result from several hundred proposed amendments, which sets the main emphasis for the transport of the future on safety, environmental protection, energy and technology.
I expressly welcome the fact that such important issues as the social, health and labor conditions of employees are also adequately mentioned here.

This is especially important in view of the threatening shortage of skilled workers in the transport sector, which must be actively addressed if you want to prevent bottlenecks in well-trained skilled workers in the future.
Further opening of cabotage in road transport is only possible if social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given an important place here.
Safety on our roads is a topic that must continue to concern us in the future.
I see other points rather critically.
So I would have liked a statement on the model shift, where more traffic would be shifted from the road to the rail and waterways.
For this reason, I do not think the discussion about the gigaliners is the best solution for more sustainability.
Equally critical is the further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening of national passenger transport, one should wait and reconsider.
There is still technical harmonization and fair competition conditions to be solved here.

But as I said in this report, I hope that the expectations of the Parliament are expressed here, that it does not remain a pious wish list, but that a goal is achieved by two thousand twenty and our proposals have become reality. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, it has been twenty years since the Central Asian states gained their state independence as a result of the collapse of the Soviet Union.
After coming out of a dictatorship, the development of democratic and rule of law structures in these states remains a permanent challenge.
Nevertheless, these states are important trading partners of the EU and its member states due to their wealth of mineral resources and raw materials.
It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU's relations with these states within the framework of partnership and cooperation agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements should serve cooperation and lead to partnership action, but not to one-sided stigmatization.
Child labor, and especially forced labor of children, is unfortunately still a widespread evil in many countries of the world that must be fought.

However, I do admit that in many agriculturally-principled European regions it was common to extend the school holidays of children during harvest time and give children from farming families the opportunity to help with harvesting, which no one would call forced labor today.
However, if there are signs of child labor in Uzbekistan during cotton harvesting, consequences must be drawn.

The same consequence must then apply to all other states where child labor still exists, including those where we pursue economic interests of a completely different magnitude, such as in India or China.
We should not apply double standards here.
Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, dear colleagues. I can only join those who have congratulated the Presidency of the Council.
They were not only an honest broker in difficult times, but also a European broker.

I think it was very pleasant to feel this in these difficult times, when we have political tendencies in a variety of member states that suggest to people that we could achieve more alone than together.
You have put the commonality in the center.
It was also very refreshing to see that you also found approval from the people in Poland in the domestic political debate with this clear European agenda.
It wasn't entirely easy in this context.
and also the highest respect for what they have done.
We were able to achieve a lot in this half year, especially in the area of financial market regulation.

If I may pick out just one area that I was allowed to negotiate myself, namely the question of regulation in short sales and uncovered credit default insurance in government bonds, where the Commission did not dare to propose a strict regulation, where we were all

Member states were told that they would not prevail, and thanks to the Polish Presidency of the Council, it was possible to sanction a highly speculative instrument and, where necessary, to prohibit it, so that we can contribute to more stability in the financial markets.
I would like to expressly thank your Minister of Finance and the Secretary of State, who have initiated this in a laborious discussion process between Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of how we can do something together in the interest of security and stability in Europe.
Mr. Fischer, thank you for that.
Mr. President. Since yesterday, colleagues, the new monitoring mechanism for economic imbalances has been in force.
Meanwhile, the specific content regulations are also available.
Secondly, which development does the Commission now consider dangerous, and which economic problems does it want to correct?
The Commission considers a problem that the growth of wage costs in euro countries is more than three per year.
However, a limit for decreasing wages is not provided.
Cheap, dear Commission, does not mean good at once.
It is not enough to force the member states to achieve prosperity at the expense of their trading partners.
Without investments in education, health and energy efficiency, we can exploit our employees a bit to the bone, but we won't write economic success stories like that.
Another example from the scoreboard The loss of export market shares is to be checked and sanctioned.
That is nonsense.
In the case of increasing world trade, Europe's share is inevitably decreasing statistically.
The indicator therefore punishes the countries that are already intertwined in world trade.
Therefore, we believe that the Commission should withdraw this scoreboard and subject it to a general overhaul. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would like to start by thanking our rapporteur and all those who have contributed to the report, because it is not a routine, even if one has to deal with competition policy for the fortieth time on the basis of a report from the Commission.

I would like to thank the Commissioner very much, because the year two thousand ten was the year when you were fully responsible for competition policy for the first time, for the very comprehensive presentation.

But I would like to express the request, and you have just mentioned it in your contribution, that we should work on a certain processing, especially in the area of subsidies, public subsidies in the banking sector.
should come, because now, due to the new stress test of the European banking supervision, a new capitalization in the banking sector is being called for again.
I don't think that all of this contributes to the stability of the banking system if we still have a multitude of unanswered or unfinished old cases on the one hand.
We have and in fact new cases are already arising because the corresponding pressure is being built up to increase the equity ratio, especially in the area of private banks.

So here is my urgent request, Commissioner, to come to a quick solution that also contributes to stabilizing the banking sector so that it can also face the challenges in the international environment.
The second major topic, the fusion control, will also move us even more in the coming years.
Here too I can only urge to continue the clear and transparent path that the Commission has taken so far in the context of merger control.
I believe that it is in the interest of all parties involved, especially consumers, that we ensure that competition is possible in larger or other structures in the area of merger control.
In this sense, thank you to everyone who has worked here, and I hope, Commissioner, that we will soon come to a solution in the area of banks.

Mr. Commissioner, I believe you have hit the nail on the head by stating together that we are able to start a third industrial revolution in Europe if we understand that we perceive the sustainability opportunities as an industrial opportunity.
Then you also spoke of resources, and that brings me to a thought that I have completely forgotten today.
I forgot the human resources in my office.
Mrs. Philipp, please allow me to say that you have worked like a horse, wonderful successes, you were a very leading person in this matter.
I would like to thank you for that.
Mr. President. To ensure freedom of speech in the parliament, you also need a functioning microphone system.
My button to turn on the microphone broke.
I would ask that a technician restore freedom of speech.
Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. I am astonished that we have to remind ourselves again and again what is actually meant by structural and cohesion policy.

Cohesion and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union, and it is intended to serve the consolidation of economic and social cohesion in the community by definition, but in particular to promote growth and employment in underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of the cohesion and structural policy has been proven especially in the years of the crisis.
In many regions it would be even more difficult in terms of economic development if these funds were not available.
The implementation of structural fund support is based on operational programs, as already mentioned, which describe the support strategy of the respective region.
The European Union, member states and regions work together in partnership here and thus create a true European added value.
The success of the cohesion and structural policy is also based on the reliability of the programs and the available and standing funds.
Therefore, I am very surprised when, as we can see now, member states and the Commission are trying to use the structural fund resources as a safety net for all sorts of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the sense and purpose of the cohesion policy and also makes the actors in the regions uncertain, who are already working on achieving the goal on the basis of long-term strategies and contracts.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and commitment to economic growth is an important goal.
However, this will only be achieved if the partnership cooperation between the regions, the member states and the Commission is maintained and the actors in the regions are involved and remain.
Because only they have the knowledge of what needs to be done in their regions.
Cohesion and structural policy is the unifying, partnership and solidarity bond of action between the individual policy levels in the European Union.
In it, the solidarity Europe becomes visible on the ground in the regions, and it should not be abandoned lightly due to political quick shots.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I support the compromise found in the trialogue, which is intended to strengthen the negotiating power of dairy farmers and the processing industry, although I know that it does not solve all the problems that dairy farmers are currently facing in some member states.
Even Commissioner Mantzol had planned preferential measures for the creation of producer communities within the framework of the CAP fifty years ago.
In my country, Luxembourg, the dairy industry is also the main pillar of our agriculture due to the high proportion of grassland.
Our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to join together in a cooperative that takes over the processing of the milk itself.
Five member states voted against the compromise in the Council for this very reason, which does not meet its requirements as a soft landing instrument.

The European Commission has the right of initiative when it comes to legislative proposals, and therefore I would like to ask you to submit a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament in 2012 to correct this obvious and costly error in the system.

A linear reduction of the super levy for every kilogram of milk delivered until 2015 or the abolition of the fat correction could at least mitigate the negative effects of the expiring regulation without harming the non-affected member states.
However, the present milk package is also understood as the final report of the high-level group, which is intended to bring the milk quota exit to a gentle landing.
It is astonishing that there is no mention of milk quotas in this report.
The young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and in four other member states are trying to prepare for the liberalization of the milk market and expand their production.
In order to be able to keep up with the world market after 2015, they can only do this by buying quotas even now, just before the end of the milk quota system.
This is an enormous additional and unnecessary capital expense that disadvantages you compared to your colleagues in twenty-two member states. Thank you.
So, please, Bibelukat. A question: Do you know that we have community bonds for a long time?
and that the resolution does not even speak generally about Euro bonds, but about very different options.
And is it known to you that not all of these options require a treaty change?
I find it questionable that you have again separated generalities about Euro bonds.
We should not give up the exact differentiation that we have achieved with the good proposal by Mrs. Goulart.
I would like to hear a bit more differentiation in your statements and I am curious to hear what you have to say about it.
I will just say briefly, dear colleague Goulart, it is not an evaluation that I have made here.
I just want to point out that the last Italian government bond before Italy joined the Euro has paid off by ten percent.
And there was no outcry in Italy, and nobody said that other countries should take over now.
It was self-evident that high interest rates were paid.

And now suddenly, because you had low interest rates for ten years and got into debt over all measures, because money became cheap for investments as well as for public hands, then you want to prolong it with Euro bonds.
This is a trap we cannot get out of, and I stand by it.
Mr. President. Thank you very much. Commissioner, your answer really disappointed me to some extent.

They obviously want to stick to the old system, where complicated negotiations have to be conducted per country, and where no further access to literature is granted, so that no more opportunities are created for the blind and visually impaired.
This is all the more sad for me because the European Union is now blocking a step forward in the WIPO, while all other or many other contracting parties are willing to move forward.
A huge opportunity is being missed here.

They are not fighting here for more rights for authors, but they are fighting against people to whom the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is intended to guarantee equal access to cultural goods and that they can also participate fully in these cultural goods.
I appeal to you, please break down barriers and vote for a binding treaty.

Madam President, dear colleagues. The discussion here in this house shows that we actually represent the entire range on the one hand those who do not want any restrictions, on the other hand those who connect every form of immigration with the danger of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this house.
I believe that family reunification must be viewed with great reason and also with rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed problems in member states where too restrictive measures are taken.
Because family reunification cannot be burdened with so many obstacles that in the end no one can be reunited at all.

On the other hand, it is completely justified that member states, for example, require language skills, that they require integration, but also that they require the willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, the member states have the right, and we should not push these problems aside, to formulate the problems that arise in family reunification.
If countries like Greece, Malta, Romania or Italy are no longer allowed to formulate what problems they have in this context, then I no longer know if we are democratic if we simply ignore problems.
I don't think we need a new directive again now.
We should discuss the problems carefully and then think about how we can eliminate them.
The constant re-production of guidelines does not lead to improvements in the guidelines and their implementation.
We currently have some implementation problems.

But I also fully understand that we must first deal with the fact that we do not want to make a new directive again and put something on it before we have even finished discussing the old directive in its problematic form.
I am in favour of listening to the member states and at the same time respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
If you do this with reason and common sense, then I also believe that we will come to a good path.
Mr. President. Think before you think, demands the Polish aphorist StanisÅaw JÃ¼rgelewicz, and this recommendation would sometimes be good for us in this Parliament as well.

A few weeks after the resolution on the Central Asia Strategy adopted in this house, in which censorship was granted to the Central Asian states, strike events in Jarnao Zed are now also being discussed.
in Kazakhstan, without waiting for the results of the ongoing investigations, which are being carried out with international participation.
So much so that the dead are mournable, the injured and the detainees have the right to process the events as a result of these events, the background remains unclear.

Even Vladimir Kosselow, chairman of the unregistered opposition party ALGA, said that it was a group of other people, the unrest is not in the interest of the strikers, because that only provides the reason to take violent action against them.
Central Asia expert Arkadi Dubnov also said, quote, It is not excluded that parts of the Kazakh opposition living abroad will also get involved.
On the other hand, it could fit someone in the Kazakh capital Astana quite well into the concept of maintaining tensions.
Finally, the power elites of Kazakhstan are already fighting for the succession of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
We had the opportunity to speak with the Kazakh opposition in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador here in the parliament.

UN Special Representative Miroslav Jenszak announced today that he is impressed by the Kazakh government's observation of the events in Jana Ozen, and that it is necessary to uncover the true background of the UN.
We should take the Kashmiri authorities to heart, measure them by their actions, but not come to reflexive prejudices.
If I understood correctly, the statement you made today is Yes, the Commission is fighting for the continuation of the food program for the most needy people in the European Union.
She will do everything to put concrete ideas on the table in the foreseeable future a where the program is exactly located and how funding should take place.
I think this is urgently necessary and I think we have a shared responsibility to ensure that this food program actually becomes a reality.
Not because I think it is the ultima ratio, but because it is a signal from my point of view to show people that we still have a basic feeling for the necessary solidarity with the

the living conditions of people in the European Union who unfortunately could not participate in a development and who have become the first victims and the biggest victims of the way the European Union has fought the crisis.
I am thinking of Greece, I am thinking of Spain, I am thinking of other countries where exactly what we do as the European Union is done primarily at the expense of the poorest, the poor.
We are setting a sign, but unfortunately it is no more.
I therefore think that it is urgently necessary that we not only do this for the eighteen million people in the European Union who are currently dependent on food being available to them.
It must not only be made available, but it must be about the fact that we want to continue to put the fight against poverty or even put it at the top of our own agenda.
We have not conveyed this signal so far.

But in my view, this is the crucial point if we want to make progress here and if we also want to gain trust among the citizens of our European Union that we are really creating a social and solidarity-based Union.
In this sense, you have our support.
But we ourselves, dear colleagues, are also called upon to do something so that the governments that have been blocking so far must give up this attitude.
I think that is also a piece of self-commitment for us.
Dear Mr. Daul, I listened to you carefully.
What you are proposing, in parallel with the subsidiarity check, is to provide a growth check for all expenses, which means to narrow the targets to growth.
I would like to know from you how you can reconcile this with the claim of a Christian Democratic group, which still has goals beyond growth.
It must be generally known that the economy does not bring children into the world, does not grow up and cannot allow them to live in an intact nature.
This also speaks in favor of the priorities being changed by the Commission and also by the Council, that they are being reconsidered.
As a group, we will examine very carefully whether what you presented this morning actually corresponds to a change in priorities.
So far the motto was First the economy, it needs functioning financial markets.
And that was the first thing to do, to restore public finances, to reduce debts and to keep the markets calm.
And Mr. Dohl, who unfortunately is not present now, I just wanted to tell him that I would think the same way as Georges Machet.
I didn't understand his answer, but I would disagree with him.
I think the measures that have been initiated were just wrong.
They were not right. It was not right to focus exclusively on the rehabilitation of the economy and completely ignore what was happening to the people.
It was not right to put the stability of the Euro above everything and to say that we don't care what happens to the people.
It has to be the other way around. First it is about the people, then we can continue to talk about the stabilization of the Euro.

The speculative attacks on Spain brought the interest rates for Spanish government bonds to over six percent and more, and thus also close to the interest rate level, where other states such as Greece, Portugal or Ireland have taken up the support of the rescue fund.
The austerity policy imposed by the EU, the ECB and the IMF on the member states, with drastic cuts in all kinds of public spending, is also a problem.
Reducing wages and pensions, increasing VAT and much more has placed the burden on citizens and has not prevented the recurring spiral.
Strict cuts in state spending exacerbate the downturn, drive the debt ratio of states up, and this must be our common insight.
When Mr Draghi recently said that the European social model is at an end, then I am glad, Mr Barroso, when you say, No, we in the Commission do not think that way.
But then I also expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece, Portugal, Ireland and to register exactly what is happening there.
What happens to the people who are currently struggling to survive?
What happens or what do we do together so that this suicide spiral, which has set in motion, especially in the most affected debt countries, is finally broken?
It can't be that we just stand by and watch.
And we are not interested in social policy programs that will take effect at some point when other measures have taken effect.
We must act now. Where have your objectives from the 2020 strategy for combating poverty gone?
What has become of the European Poverty Platform?
It has been set aside.
That was before the crisis.
But now, in the middle of the crisis, people need help, they need support and they need the action of the European Union.
You don't need empty promises.
We need concrete ideas about what should be done now.
If you do that, you will get support from my group.
Support all those who have recognized the signs of time within the Commission and want to change things.
But please don't just keep going and say it's already happening.
Nothing will happen if this continues. I urge you to present a concrete project, a concrete program, on how we can really help the people in the affected countries now.
Do something about it.
We will have to do this in our countries so that it is not blocked that the funds for the ESF are cut from 2013 or 2014 to 2020 or for the other programs.
that the member states fulfill their responsibilities.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues. The current state of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a fiscal fairy tale hour.
The situation in the Council is quite simple: little progress is being made on tax policy proposals.
Why?
because some countries are against further tax cooperation.
They profit from aggressive tax planning, they are tax havens themselves.
And the treaties clearly state unanimity in tax matters.
Therefore, the EU Commission has suffered shipwreck in the past with its proposals.
They are being watered down, they are not moving forward, as with the interest directive, and with newer proposals, nothing more demanding was proposed in advance obedience.

I therefore ask you, Mr Schemeter, I know that your job is not easy in this regard, change the strategy, present sharp measures and then focus on increased cooperation to end the blocking position in the Council.
Mr. President, dear colleagues. With the present proposal on risk-sharing instruments, it will certainly not be possible to prevent state bankruptcy where it should occur.
But doing something is still better than doing nothing at all.
And extraordinary situations sometimes require extraordinary measures.

The budget and debt crisis in some states led to such an extraordinary situation that important projects and measures within the framework of cohesion and structural policy can no longer be carried out, because the banking sector is failing as a financier and private investors are no longer available.
I see an extraordinary measure in the present proposal to create risk-sharing instruments for the further financing of projects in structural policy.
The cohesion and structural policy funds available to countries that want to use these division instruments can be used to secure financial projects already underway.

I am very grateful to the rapporteur Danuta HÃ¼bner for her great contribution to the clarification of the Commission proposal and for once again clearly highlighting when and how these instruments should be used.
However, I also believe that these risk-sharing instruments should only be due to the current situation and should not be a prejudice for the future funding period.
When the last amendment to the regulation on biometric passports in 2009 called for a review to be carried out after three years and four studies to be presented, our group supported this.
And also because she had repeatedly raised great concerns for data protection reasons and also because of the overestimation of the benefits of biometric data in passports.
The belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this tool and, as a result, the underestimation of other links in the security chain are really problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this great error, namely the assumption that they are unchangeable and most trustworthy.
And that is just not the case.
These data can also be changed throughout life.
They look different in children than in old age.
And that is why reliable and serious studies and conclusions are necessary.
Counterfeiting is still being done diligently.
We have now been able to determine that.
As has been proven time and time again in the UK and other countries, the chips are not at all safe against misuse.
They are happily cracked and can cause permanent damage to those affected.
The standards within the EU are also extremely different.
The error rate is very high, as in France and the Netherlands.
The question must be asked again and again what use biometric data is when documents are forged and in circulation.
If a link in the chain is forged, the starting documents are inconsistent, biometric data should not help us.
One last thing: The Chaos Computer Club in Germany only needed a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

For this, the friends of the Chaos Computer Club needed the lid of a plastic bottle, a second glue, a digital camera and a bit of wood glue. In a few minutes they had cracked the chip. So much for the supposed security.
We expect the Commission to present the studies and, of course, the results and consequences that derive from them. Thank you.
Dear Council, the Commission is unfortunately not sufficiently represented today, as I would have liked, out of respect for the Parliament.

As a member of parliament from a region that is massively affected by the planned changes, namely the Eifel, after carefully following the debate, the question arises for me whether the unfortunately only unsuitable experiments

A standardization of the criteria for disadvantaged areas really meets the needs in these regions, especially since the necessary information is not available for a meaningful and responsible decision.
Above all, I wonder if a sufficient impact assessment was actually carried out.
