To do justice to the farmers, we need not only biophysical criteria, but also socio-economic criteria.

Therefore, I call on the Commission to reconsider this important aspect with the necessary time, separated from the overall package of the CAP reform and above all after the submission of the necessary documents and a careful analysis of the effects on the criteria.
I believe that we must also work together with the Asylum Support Office and the Greek authorities to identify more quickly which people who have come to Greece could possibly actually be

They can also be transferred to other countries of the European Union, because firstly they will definitely never be able to return to their home country, and secondly they may also bring potential and qualifications that can be meaningful and effective for everyone.
But essentially it is also about helping the Greeks to enable registration and identification faster in order to allow faster aid processes to progress.
to return those who do not have the qualifications or the right to stay in Greece or the European Union, because they could have actually stayed in their own home countries.
Thank you, Mr. President, Minister, Commissioner, and also to the rapporteur for her always very committed and exemplary work.
I can share many of the criticism expressed by Sophie Infeld, and I have also supported some of it.
But then there is always the point where you have to take responsibility.
And for the EPP or for myself, I therefore also claim that we must now deal with the realities and cannot withdraw to ideological or theoretical positions.
The fact is that the USA has been collecting this PNR data for ten years, and there has not been a single complaint.
The fact is that we all do not want data traffic to be stopped even with a rejecting attitude.
You had just explained that.
The fact is also that we do not want air traffic between Europe and the USA to come to a standstill.
And it is also a fact that the USA has the right to know who is coming to their country.
And in my opinion, the fact is that the legal services have all expressed to us verbally that this agreement is better than the other agreement, than the alternatives.
Therefore, one must also take responsibility here.
And that is why we were elected.
Responsibility for the citizens, who would otherwise be left alone and with less protection and rights.
Responsibility for the airlines, which would otherwise be left in absolute legal uncertainty, and the Commissioner had also explained this.
Responsibility also for the EU as a contracting party in matters of data protection and security, but also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
Therefore, we are also in favour of agreeing to this agreement, taking into account that this agreement is not perfect.
If you want to better protect the citizens and if you also want to give them better data protection, you also take on this responsibility here and agree to this agreement. Thank you.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. You have given us some enlightening explanations.
Thank you very much for that.

The numbers sometimes say more than just big words, and to this day, the European Parliament has also mentioned the European Patent Office, pardon, has granted almost two patents on plants and almost twelve hundred patents on animals, which have been created with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I would like to mention two outstanding examples: the approval of patents on genetically modified and breeding-modified barley, which applies to the entire chain from seeds to the plant.
Therefore, our farmers are just as affected as our brewers, producers, and we, consumers.
And this example shows, in my opinion, a devastating extent of patenting.
Second example: the so-called long-life tomato, not to be confused with the long-life oil you have in your diesel engines.
With this trick by the applicant US corporation Arcadia, this patent was obtained bypassing the valid EU rules.
The tomato was not patented, but its genetic material, namely selected enzymes.

This shows the trick used here, and that, although, as you said, Commissioner, the biopatent directive of 1998 clearly states in Article four that plant varieties and animal breeds A and B are essentially biological processes for breeding plants or animals,
We believe that this definition needs to be clarified, it needs to be interpreted more precisely.
Technical procedures used to support conventional breeding must not lead to overall patentability.
We are not saying a patent on life.
And we need a clear signal here for more ethics and more honesty in dealing with creation, once again against patentability of life throughout Europe.
Therefore, Commissioner, we demand the Commission's clear statement that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are and remain in Europe.
Secondly, we demand a clear position on Article four of the Bio Patent Directive No patent on life.
Thirdly, Commissioner, we demand on behalf of many farmers and breeders in Europe a clear establishment of the breeder and the farmer's privilege in the entire legislation. Thank you.
Madam Chair. I am taking a position on the discharge of Europol and Eurojust.
There is little to object to at all here.

The annual financial statement reflects the financial situation in 2010 in all essential aspects, and all the underlying transactions are in accordance with the regulations and thus also legally binding.
Only the high transfers are noticeable in relation to the overall low costs incurred.
Europol reflects this back on the relocation to a new headquarters, which is of course understandable.
But Europol agrees to take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
Furthermore, Europol wants to commit to monitoring the budget execution monthly from 2012.
I recommend that we follow this up, whether this really happens.
Against this background, I recommend the discharge of Europol.
Regarding Eurojust, the annual financial statement also reflects the financial situation in all essential aspects in 2010.
All transactions are also legal and prescriptive here.
But here too, high operating expenses were transferred to the year 2011.
After the establishment of Eurojust, this was mainly due to an organizational structure project, a new computer infrastructure and costs related to data processing.
It is announced that all of this will be improved in the future, and that the tender requirements will be better met.
I recommend that we also check this in the future and above all check whether all vacancies will actually be filled in the future.
This has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, then we almost had to consider cutting funds, and that would be negative for Orius.
I still recommend discharge. Thank you.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. What must frighten and panic us is not the sheer number of youth unemployed in Europe alone, but the development.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of unemployed young people increased by twenty-five percent, as the International Labour Organization has noted.
It is this development that urgently requires measures. We are not only disconnecting an entire generation from the labor market, we are disconnecting an entire generation from a livable future.
If we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that young people turn away from this EU because they do not have reasonable work and life prospects.

Mr. Commissioner, I urge you to ensure that decisive countermeasures are initiated. I can already see some things, but please ensure that the long-standing spiritual silence does not turn into operational hustle and bustle now.
When I read that the Commission is starting a program to financially support young people when they apply abroad, we are organizing a tourist circus that does not solve the problem.
On the contrary, it becomes counterproductive, and then technicians, doctors, engineers and nursing staff are recruited from the richer states that are not in this crisis.
In this crisis, which is the cause of this development, offensive measures are needed, namely the reduction of this austerity craze that is stifling the economy in Europe.
We need a targeted growth policy, we need a strengthening of the domestic purchasing power, public investments in education, research, alternative energies.
That would be the way.
With the combination of European funding, it would then be possible to actually develop an integrated concept that creates a perspective for young people.
Last remark: With this youth unemployment, it is also not a foolish idea to want to raise the retirement age for people to seventy.
We need a different policy that gives young people access to the job market.
That is why I urgently ask for it. Thank you.
Colleague, you just said that everything that would speak in favor of the financial transaction tax is speculation, and then you came up with very speculative examples.

I would like to know from you what you think about these investigations and the study of the Commission, which very clearly states that the real economy has been involved far too little in its dependence on

The financial markets, that is, ninety-five percent of companies, are by no means dependent on it when it comes to taking out money, and that one can very well turn a negative growth effect, which has been discussed so far, into a positive one by spending corresponding growth-promoting public investments.
Is this just speculation for you, or would you say that such a well-founded, broad-based study by the Commission already has its justification and is a strong argument?

Colleagues, the financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been discussed and debated for many years, but I think it includes essential elements of the Tobin tax.
She at least accepts the idea of involving the financial markets in taxation and, above all, in the costs of the crisis.
I think this is a very important signal to the financial markets.
But this is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.
There have been a number of actions, petitions and written appeals to politicians in a number of member states to finally introduce a financial transaction tax at European level.
I think that the parliament has achieved a great success with the majority that is emerging here for this report, for this tax.
Certainly, this is not enough to stabilize and restrict the financial markets as it might be necessary, but I think it is a really important step that has been taken here.
I would like to expressly appeal to the Council to take the voices of the citizens and voters seriously and to stand up for them.
that there is a real introduction, that the introduction of this tax is not blocked in the Council due to the British position or other positions.
I think it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I think it is a great responsibility.

It is now up to the Council to take action here, and I would like to use my speaking time to appeal to the Council to do everything to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality.

Mr. President, dear colleagues. I think that with all the detailed problems that can be discussed and that still need to be discussed in the further legislative process, we should be concerned about one thing.

We have to be clear. Financial markets cannot function according to the model: If everything goes well, the banks collect the profits, and if something goes wrong, the taxpayers keep their heads above it.
And that is why it makes sense to also tax financial transactions.
And it makes sense to do this across borders.

In Europe or at least in the Eurozone, we will not have distortions, but we will contribute to a stable financial market that generates what financial markets are actually intended for, namely that companies

Access to capital, that the saver has the possibility to save something away or to put it aside for retirement provision, and that the financial markets fulfill the task for which they were once created, namely to provide added value for the real economy.
All that drove us into the financial crisis were products that did not create any value for the real economy.
That is why it makes sense to contribute to a tax that punishes this highly, that it is sanctioned, that it is controlled in the sense that capital fulfills its task again.
That is why I am advocating for this proposal today with a large majority.
Mr. President. The reform of the general preferential system was quite necessary.
It is now good that there are longer terms and that there is more security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the Committee on Development has already said.
Unfortunately, the Commission only refers to the World Bank rating.
In the past, the Parliament has dealt with the gross domestic product as the only criterion, and repeatedly very critically.
The definition of countries with high middle income can refer to countries with four or up to twelve dollars of gross domestic product.
This is a huge and far too wide range, and it does not do justice to the realities on the ground in any way.
We certainly do not find it worrying that countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are flying out.
The reform in this regard was good.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China are countries with a high middle income, and we certainly don't have to worry about their withdrawal from the GSP.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer countries, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
So far, the Commission had at least also used the vulnerability criterion, i.e. countries that export little or only export very few goods.
This at least allows countries that are less dependent on exporting products and are very vulnerable to being ranked too high.
Why did the Commission then highlight this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, the Fiji Islands, Gabon and Botswana will thus fall out, although their economy falls under the criterion of vulnerability.
Why didn't the Commission continue the old criteria, which were already somewhat insufficient?
The suspicion arises that the Commission wants to force poorer countries into free trade agreements that are more unfavorable for them.

However, the preferential system is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development path of a country or a region no longer plays any role at all.
Fortunately, there will still be the possibility for the colleagues in the plenary to agree to our amendment, which includes vulnerability as a criterion.
But the new regulation also leads to the disintegration of trade regions.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
The Commission should take into account developing regions more strongly instead of individual countries.
Here too, we Greens have tabled an amendment that will hopefully find a lot of support.
It is also problematic if countries that benefited from the GSP yesterday are to be excluded from the program overnight.
There must be transition periods, and we see in our own countries that not just a few months are enough for economic development.
In the end, we MEPs must also consider whether we should only focus on speed in all legislative projects and then work with windy compromises, or whether we should rather involve the entire plenary.

I think that the whole parliament is important for legislation, and for democracy, and it is not the speed that is important, but it takes time and democracy to enforce and to pass laws properly. Thank you.

Mr. President, High Representative. I was also a member of the European Parliament's election observation mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to see how much hope and expectation the people had for a better future at the polling stations and were waiting to cast their vote.
We know today that these expectations were not met.
Although the Congo is called democratic, these elections were not fair and not democratic either.
We must address this offensively, as colleague Nedelcheva has also done in her report.
The previous president Josef Kabila has been appointed as the winner of the election. The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have resurfaced, and it remains unclear whether third countries like Rwanda are involved.
The civilian population is the most affected in any case, who have not been able to live in peace and quiet for decades.
The country's wealth is being squandered in a swamp of corruption, and the Congo remains in one of the last places in all international evaluations.

The international community, and especially the European Union, must increase pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow real democracy in his country. He has the opportunity to do so in the next regional elections.
I appeal to the Congolese army not to harass the civilian population, but to finally arrest internationally wanted criminals against humanity, such as Mbosco and Ndapganga, and bring them to justice.
Internationally, all states should finally commit not to supply more weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Mr. President. Colleagues, the Tupac is intended to create further rights of intervention against crisis countries in the Eurozone.
The European Semester, which was created as a framework for the necessary and better coordination of financial and economic policy, is to be given teeth.
According to the Commission's will, member states should be able to be forced to accept financial aid.
The Sixpack has already created extensive sanction possibilities that can be imposed on euro states with financial problems.
The European Semester is already perceived by citizens as more than a bureaucratic dismantling, a meaningful economic policy coordination instrument.
At the same time, the German government openly threatens Greek citizens with a Eurozone throwing away if they make the wrong decision in the election on Sunday.
Why don't we stop with these humiliating and undemocratic threats?
In a situation where the Euro crisis has once again dramatically worsened, I am thinking of Spain and Cyprus, it does not help us to put member states that are in crisis in the pillory.
We should finally develop solutions. The rapporteurs of the Tupac have developed quite sensible approaches to this.
Elisa Ferreira has certainly pointed out the redemption fund as a worthwhile and sensible measure to combat debt.
But perhaps Jean Paul Gauzet's proposal for an orderly state insolvency is also enough.
However, it is essential that Europe makes a joint and solidarity-based effort to bring the Eurozone back on a growth course.
The strong countries in Europe must stop pointing fingers at their partner countries with their self-satisfaction.
You have to start doing your homework, invest in growth and take responsibility.
Merkel's one-sided austerity policy has simply failed as a crisis solution.
Mr. Chairman, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues. In June 2010, the EU heads of government finally realized that the European Community needs a better coordinated financial and economic policy.
At the summit, they invented the European Semester, so to speak.
It is absolutely right that the members of an economic and monetary union should not only pay attention to how their policies affect companies, employees and consumers in their own country.
A European perspective is needed.

An internal market without coordination in economic, wage and social policy presents the member states with a great temptation, namely to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can bring the monetary union to a breakdown economically, but also politically.
And the EU is currently facing exactly such a situation.

The German economy has been digging up water for its neighbors for years, no impulses through investments and wage growth, instead Berlin has driven the Eurozone into ruin with a decade of aggressive export policy.

Therefore, it is pleasing that the Commission is now slowly coming to the bottom of this core problem of the Euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and making corresponding recommendations.

The Federal Republic is rightly called upon to invest more in education, research and childcare, and the Commission is rightly called upon to stop the misuse of mini jobs and to adjust wage growth to productivity growth.
This is a late but important realization.
I hope, Commissioner, Mr Rehn, that you will vehemently represent this demand towards the German government, even if there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, I would like to thank the Commission, especially Commissioner Barnier, for the very simple reason that the experience from the last legislative period, which was before 2009,

It was that, with the exception of a very short moment of awakening when the proposal of the European private company came, the predecessor of Commissioner Barnier, Commissioner McCreevy, actually let the company law fall asleep. We have not been able to solve this important issue in these five years, which is also important for the internal market.
have made progress.
Thank God that has changed fundamentally.

Meanwhile, there are a variety of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group that has developed on the issue of the further development of company law, and we now have a very current consultation, which we are of course also dealing with as a parliament.
The Legal Affairs Committee decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report would require additional time and, of course, be a bit more detailed.

We have chosen the means of the oral question to the Commission, in order to be able to discuss this topic with the Commission, with Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time also to make our position as a Parliament on what is to happen now clear in a subsequent resolution.
I believe it is necessary, similar to what we had about ten years ago, to develop a new action plan for European company law, and for many reasons.
There are gaps within European company law, real gaps, which basically lead to the fact that the internal market is not created.
I would like to mention as an example the lack of the fourteenth directive on the relocation of seats, which in my opinion is a very typical example of such a gap.
The Parliament has demanded this twice in legislative initiative reports, that concrete proposals from the European Commission come to the table.
There is also the expert committee, which the European Commission itself has appointed, which also has the same opinion on the matter.
It is simply one of the basic freedoms in the internal market that a company must be able to move within the internal market also with regard to its registered office.
This possibility does not exist today or only under extremely difficult conditions.

Against this background, I must also criticize that the European Commission's previous statement on the fourteenth directive actually lags far behind the expectations of the Parliament and, in our opinion, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
But we are in good spirits that in the course of further work, when it comes to the action plan, this proposal will hopefully be reflected in the action plan.
Another important point in company law is the question of the further development of company law with the aim of reducing the burden on companies.
Here we already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example on the topic of
Accounting, but I believe that there is still more to be done and there are other aspects that will now also be clarified within the framework of the consultation.
Here we also expect further proposals from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the topic of the European private company, which is currently stuck in the Council.

If there are individual member states, I can say this from my own opinion, if there are individual member states in the EU that are not able to eliminate the deadlock here due to a lack of their own determination.

To advance Europe, we must think about using the instrument of enhanced cooperation, as with other projects, such as the patent or family law, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this opportunity.
I would ask the Commission to think about this question more intensively.
Another open problem is the question of applicable law, i.e. a kind of Rome Regulation for cross-border problems in company law.
I also think that this question needs further investigation and discussion, and I would ask the Commission to do so.
This is also closely related to the fact that
We have the insolvency law, but it has been announced that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the foreseeable future.
You see, there is a lot to be done in company law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken the initiative again and that it is clear that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can then also represent progress in the design of the internal market.
The Parliament supports this in principle and in the approach.
Of course, we will still have to discuss the details, and we will certainly have to do that.
But that is why I also want to thank the Commission.
Now we would of course be pleased if the Commission would actually take up our initiatives and turn them into concrete proposals.
Dear Commissioner, I very much appreciate your proposal regarding productivity-oriented wage policy.
But you have made a mistake with Mrs. Merkel when it comes to the minimum wage, and I don't believe you when it comes to employment in the health sector.
How can new jobs be created there when the Commission has already forced southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by up to half?
How can employment in the health sector be created if in the new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester the Commission forces some member states to further reduce health spending?
I fear that this point in this plan is pure announcement policy, not a real initiative for new work.
On the contrary, there is already a lack of remedies and medicines today, not only in Greece, due to austerity measures.
I think that whoever constantly puts on new rescue packages for banks must now fight for a rescue package for people, especially for securing medical care in crisis countries. Thank you.
Mr. President. The mood is one of fear and horror among countless pro-Europeans like me about what is happening in Europe at the moment.
It is at least pleasing that it is now much clearer what we are dealing with and that the eyes are not closed to Italy either.

You know yourself that you are stuck in a series of traps, not only in the trap of debt and growth, but also in the trap of trust and in the trap of power, esteemed Commission, and also addressed to the Council.
Unfortunately, they have so far neglected to actually address the central issue of distancing the financial sector from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here is always accounted for by experts as if there is no serious limit to shadow banking.
Furthermore, we are dealing with systemic risks, the question of too big to fail is not addressed accordingly, and there is hardly a word to be lost about the rating agencies.

I can only urge you, if you are now working towards the Council summit, and also advise you to restore credibility in Europe by seriously raising this question of power between the real and financial economy.
to the point that you finally work credibly before the Europeans to ensure that the banks are put in the spotlight and that the citizens do not always have to bear the burden.
Mr. FÃ¤rm, you come from a country that has rejected the Euro, but with the central reason that you want to preserve the flexibility of devaluation, especially for social policy reasons.

In light of the experiences you have now made in Sweden, would you recommend that the Greeks also leave the Eurozone in order to be able to actively use this social policy instrument of devaluations accordingly?
Thank you, Mr. President. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur.
We adopted this report in the Environment Committee with a large majority, with two and sixty votes, zero votes against and no abstentions.
This shows that we are actually very, very close together, also when it comes to compromises.
And the top priority must of course be a high level of protection, a high level of consumer protection, especially for the little ones in our society, for vulnerable children.
As for gluten intolerance, this is a problem, especially in kindergartens.
If you look around, I have two children at this age, what allergies and intolerances prevail there, I think we were right.
We should also discuss this with each other in the second reading, with the Council, with the Commission.
I think we will then also come to a good result.
Mr. President. A report about a traffic accident over the weekend with a truck driver who fell asleep from exhaustion and drove into a road ditch has once again confirmed to me how necessary it is.
A clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest times and their control through a digital tachograph is important for us, for road safety, but also for the affected persons themselves.
The digital tachograph means a certain innovation. It has new problems, but also old problems.
New problems arise in new manipulation possibilities, which we also need to get a technical grip on.
The old problems are those that we can already observe in the control or lack of control in various member states.
What we are regulating now is essential to consider in my view, firstly, that not every time a trip is not recorded, a rest period is automatically introduced.
Because many drivers have to load and unload, and that is of course also to be considered as working time.
The second problem is that the records of speed were removed from the dossier.
I think that is wrong, because there are also great dangers of accidents here.
We also want weight sensors and we also want a hotline so that you can report fraud, which is anonymous and can be prosecuted.
What I will also bring up is a request that animal transport control be included in this regulation.
I think this is important because this is also a very central element of our legislation.

Madam President, many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not have any remaining disabilities if professional medical help had been provided quickly enough, that is, within the first so-called golden hour, after their accident.
We would be a lot closer to the vision zero.
Well, the eCall system we are talking about today cannot avoid accidents. It also does not exempt anyone from the first aid duty.
It only serves to automatically inform an emergency call manager in the event of a serious accident.
This must also establish linguistic contact with the vehicle in order to avoid abuse and overload by minor accidents.
Only when the emergency call is confirmed or no one answers anymore, emergency doctors are sent to the accident site equipped with little but vital information.
The responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies subsidiarily with the member states.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system is sleeping, so it does not send any signals or data and is not on the spot.
It is also far superior to a mobile phone in terms of data protection.
The system will only become active with automatic sensor-controlled wake-up calls or conscious manual triggering.
It then sends an agreed minimum set of information to a rescue center.
Uniform standards and specifications throughout Europe will ensure that this data is recognized, evaluated and processed as an emergency call upon arrival.
Therefore, the member states must also equip and expand their rescue service chains accordingly.

We want this eCall emergency call system to be based on the uniform EU emergency number one hundred and two, to be free for the user, to function everywhere in the EU and to be compatible with the emergency call systems of neighboring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable technology, neutral, open system architecture.
Later, other intelligent public transportation services such as real-time traffic information or availability of parking spaces can also be offered.

In recognition of the great performance of the automotive industry in providing private emergency call systems, these should retain their justification in parallel with the public one hundred and two eCall.
Users can also choose such a system based on detailed information.
This may go hand in hand with the costs if necessary.
Mandatory use of data for workshops, insurance, towing services or other service providers.
A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme shows a small problem that we have created for ourselves today.

Because if this brewery or the beverage dealer is one hundred and seven kilometers away from my place of residence, I have no chance that he will continue to offer me his goods in the future without having to buy a new tachograph, without there being new bureaucracy.

Therefore, dear colleagues, I voted against this resolution today, because I believe that we should not impose too much burden on our small and medium-sized enterprises. There were many points that we got in, which were positive, thank God.
It was planned to accept fifty kilometers only in the vicinity of a regional provider.
That was completely absurd from the EU Commission.
So a hundred kilometers are still possible.
But what if it goes beyond that?
I think it is exaggerated.
And one last aspect as a representative of an employee organization in the CSU, I also say that with this regulation we create complete control of employees.
Wagon?
Because, for example, the person who offers his goods for construction or for the drinks, for the breweries, is completely controlled via GPS for the entire working day.
I also consider what we have decided today to be highly questionable for data protection reasons, and I would like to stress once again why I voted against it.
Thank you very much for this question.
Why am I not waiting for this decision?
I was waiting for the approval of the European People's Party in the Legal Affairs Committee when we asked the necessary questions about legal certainty with regard to ACTA during the process.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
That is not what they wanted. Now it is obvious that the ECJ should be used to delay, that is clear.
Why did I say that with the wide scope of interpretation?
Because you asked two questions, I have to answer both, unfortunately.
because you can read and interpret everything from these broad formulations, the monitoring of the Internet, the auxiliary police ISPs.
And that means legal uncertainty. Legal uncertainty does not help our economy either, dear colleagues.
Mr. Leichtfried, I would like to ask you: Are you in favor of discussing the modernization of copyright at the European level?
Or are you completely against the rejection of any intellectual property?
And how do you imagine the e-commerce directive will be adapted to modern circumstances in the future?
From your statement I understand that you reject a debate on these things at all and do not stand for intellectual property.
Is that true or how do you see it?
Mr. President. It is not about individual facts that we need to discuss, but about the basic question: How do we stand with democracy and with freedoms?
And if we look at the ACTA, we find that it is somewhat symbolic of lack of transparency, lack of democracy, and violation of fundamental rights, because it was secretly negotiated.

And it came about in a way that was undemocratic, because the free use of the Internet would simply no longer be possible afterwards, and also the freedom to use generics to the extent that it has been so far.
These are the reasons why millions of people have taken to the streets and have long since voted on ACTA.
Yes, the ACTA has been voted on on the streets, on the internet, in relation to the Petitions Committee, in many countries, not only within the EU, but also outside.
Even outside the EU. We must not ignore this vote. It is a vote of direct democracy of many citizens who elected us.
I can only tell you to put ACTA in the files, that would be decent.

Madam President of the Council, as rapporteur of the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have completed two procedures under your presidency: the budgetary rules, which provide a set of rules for the upcoming MFF period, and the OLAF procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation has been in the Council in the waiting line, and you have brought this procedure to a conclusion based on the results of the Polish Presidency.
I would like to thank you for two really very committed financial officials who have worked on these dossiers, and also Ambassador Trankom.
I will miss him. We will miss his efficiency as a negotiator.
They have really taken care of the financial interests of the European Union.
Thank you very much.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen. I am speaking here as a representative of my group and would like to support the motion by my colleague Mr. Fellner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This requires careful handling of the issue of intellectual property rights.
The European Commission has submitted this proposal to the European Court of Justice with a request for an opinion to clarify the remaining open questions.
I believe that we should wait for this decision, with all due respect to the Supreme Court of the European Union.
There is no factual reason to make this decision today.
Nobody is prevented from voting against it when the court has submitted its decision and its opinion.
But the decision that is made then takes place in a different awareness, in a different understanding than today.
I don't think the ghost drivers on the internet highway should determine our policy, and that's why I ask you to support this motion. Thank you.
Mr. President. As always, when colleague Turmes speaks, it is very clever, and one would wish that what he says would have much more influence on European politics.
I wanted to follow up on that.
Of course, these project bonds are a smart thing, but only if they are sustainable and if political foundations are created for them.
We are in danger of securing risks through guarantees that we cannot control politically.

Specifically, the energy transition in Germany: 3800 kilometers of road network would be necessary, only 100 kilometers of these corresponding telecommunications networks have been built, because it also fails on the resistance of the citizens, by the way, very ecologically oriented citizens.
We have to come up with something about politics.

One idea would be to create common TEN corridors, so not only to combine high-speed tracks on the railways and broadband networks, but perhaps to construct the corresponding transmission networks on top of that, also next to the highway.
However, this requires a much more comprehensive plan than has been planned so far, but I would like to suggest this at least at this point.

Mr. President, dear colleagues. I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements that exist in the European Union. But I also know that the borders of a country are always a very sensitive issue for our member states and will always remain so.
I am aware that the problems that exist between the member states with regard to Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
There are various problems.
And ignoring doesn't make the problems better and doesn't solve them better either.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and nobody would come up with the idea to close the border again just because we have problems.
But I also ask the Commission in this area for support and not for restrictions and rejection.
The veil investigation has been anchored because we want to ensure safety while maintaining freedom of travel.
And if we successfully carry out the veil investigation, I take the example of the Czech Republic, where one or another drug dealer not only in a few cases, but in many

If they try to make a transition in some cases, I think it would be good if the German Federal Minister of the Interior and the Czech one came together to solve the problems that exist at the border together.
The Commission should not regulate this, but rather have a positive and supportive effect.

We want to put the populists in the crosshairs, but we want to solve the real problems together. That is why I also ask the Council to look for a solution together with the Parliament, so that we can successfully adopt the Schengen dossiers, so that we have freedom of travel and at the same time ensure the safety of the citizens.
Mr. President. The cases of disproportionate border controls that the Parliament lists in its question also show why the Council actually wants to leave the Parliament out of Schengen.
The Council wants to continue to undermine the freedom of travel without the Parliament being involved or without any form of parliamentary control, without any form of publicity.
No wonder you prefer to pat yourself on the back with uncomfortable questions in the back rooms.
No wonder the German government wants to completely rule out an evaluation of the internal borders without evaluation and thus does not want to look at how much the freedom of travel is restricted.
But Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people in Europe and therefore also belongs to the European Parliament. Thank you.

Mr. President of the Council of the European Union, Mr. Dimitris Christofias, it is a special moment for me and for my group to welcome you here in your capacity as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also pleased that for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person is at the head of the EU, whom we count as our political family.
They take over the presidency at a time when the European Union is facing huge challenges. It is necessary to set the course whether the European Union
whether the Union will actually have a future or whether it will prove to be a historical defeat in my view.
I know from the conversations we had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the chairmen of the factions and parties in your country, that you have focused on this
that you have prepared your presidency excellently and that you are also aware of the scope of your task.
But you have also made this clear here today: You want to deliberately draw the attention of the rulers to the living situation of the people.
I can tell you here that after all that I have heard in the last few years, it is the first time that a president of the European Union does exactly that and announces and says, This tone

I have missed this in official speeches for a long time, that it is said that it is about the people, it is about those who are not responsible for the fact that we are in this crisis, but who have to bear the most burdens.
It will be difficult to implement exactly this approach.
But I think a lot would have been gained, and you will do that, I am very sure of that, if you encourage people with your presidency and the way you do it.
to exercise that they stand up for their rights and that they contribute to the fact that the Council, that the European institutions are exactly aware of this task.
We keep talking about the Euro and its stability, about the necessity, which I also see, that they are important for the functioning of the European Union and for the Eurozone.
But this is an instrument.
There were political conditions for this, which were defined.

It can never be the goal of the European Union to accept that people in the European Union have to starve, that health systems collapse, that municipal administrations have to stop their work for the functioning of the Euro.
Something has gotten out of hand here.
It is not what we can call the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support you in your demand that it must be about social cohesion, about solidarity between the individual member states, but also between the most diverse population groups.
The European Union must not simply be used as an instrument or as a spokesperson for a small, specific layer of the population or present itself in this way.

And one last point I would like to address, of course, to emphasize that everything you have mentioned in your priorities is important to us and that we will also support the points that go in this direction, as I have just defined them.
Please do something so that people are no longer afraid.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
I think that some decisions in the last weeks and months, especially in the elections in Greece, in the votes for the referendum in Ireland, were also marked by fear.
And if the governments in the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their free decision, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Good luck with your work.
Mr. President. Dear colleagues, I believe we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-rapporteurs together.
It will be very important for the colleague to work on this dossier quickly and reliably in the coming weeks and months.
The eyes are currently on us and the Council to take this step to overcome the crisis of banks in Europe through another step of Europeanization, namely through a European banking union.
It must be said that the parliament demanded this with a broad majority two years ago.
We have conducted twenty-six trilogues.
We have taken a step in this direction, but unfortunately not as far as it would have been necessary.
This has led to further billion-dollar bills.
It is good that the Council has now drawn the consequences and wants to further deepen this step for the Eurozone.
It is commendable that the Commission has worked out the proposals so quickly.
However, the Council's decision that the ECB should become the place of the Eurozone supervisor involves some difficulties.
This leads to unanimity in the Council, and it means that the Parliament is not in codecision on this dossier.
According to the experiences with the supervisory package, this is not acceptable.

Therefore, it is important that we work quickly here, but that we also negotiate this proposal for changes in the ECB with the necessary changes in the existing supervisory regime as a package and in fact establish the principle of democratic participation of the Parliament.
Democratically, there are also other challenges.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has no tasks so far.

If she is now responsible for banking supervision, the parliament needs full budgetary rights, full control rights, questions, appointment rights, and I am sure that the parliament will also grant itself these in a broad majority.
We will have to discuss the complicated questions beyond the internal market, consumer protection and the balance between European power and financial responsibility in detail in the coming weeks.
Mr. President. With the proposal to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is trying to push these countries into free trade agreements.
These freedom-like relationships, as the term economic partnerships suggests, are only about the interests of the EU and not about the development interests of the partner countries.
This completely goes against the EU's goal of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments with it.
Countries like Cameroon, the Ivory Coast and Namibia would be massively affected by this restriction.
Regional integration projects, such as in Southeast Africa, would break down if Kenya were to agree to such an agreement.
South-South cooperation would be over.
We cannot advocate for free trade in the world and thereby only mean that other countries should buy our goods.
If the Commission really believes that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The Development Committee of this House has recommended rejecting the Commission proposal.
We should agree with that in the plenary.
Madam President. There are an enormous number of human rights problems in Central America, Peru and Colombia.
And we as MEPs cannot simply close our eyes to it.
We will examine the roadmap for human rights, which the EP has demanded in the case of Colombia and Peru, in detail when it is drawn up.
It must have substance and be binding, and include first results such as the conviction of perpetrators and a safe return of displaced persons to their country.
And of course, it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.
We Greens think it is right that the Trade Committee demands environmental and social standards in the proposed regulation on the safeguard clauses and not just tonne restrictions for bananas.
But the trilogue must also confirm this, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
The EU must do much more to keep an eye on the situation on the ground and especially the impact on the local population.
That is why we Greens demand a proper impact assessment before any negotiation, which not only examines the economic impact on the EU, but also the impact on human rights.
Mr. Barroso, I had already made it clear in the first round what I wanted to focus on.
I am concerned about the expectation of my group to the Commission that it will fulfill its responsibility in the relevant bodies again, in order to make it clear and explicit that we as

As the Commission, as European institutions, we must ensure that people are not driven into even greater poverty, that working hours are not shortened, and that ecological and social standards are not undermined.
That is your task.

If we succeed in making this clear, we will also send a signal to the people who are protesting in these days, who have taken to the streets and with whom we as a group also declare ourselves in solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or in Barcelona.
I heard the news this morning that in Greece the cancer patients are protesting and going on strike.
Where have we ended up, that people who are in deep social and personal distress can no longer receive any help and support because the health system has collapsed?
We must finally take action here.
And I will say one more thing: An approach that is in the minds of many responsible people is that the people in Greece and in other states have lived through their conditions.
They have to be punished today and have to endure sanctions.
It is unsuitable to strengthen a European community, a community of solidarity.
I do not assume that you do, Mr. Barroso, but this is an approach that is also being implemented in many countries and, unfortunately, for example, in my approach, it is always being repeated.
Mr. Chairman, I admit I made a mistake.
I do not want to give an explanation on this report, but on the Moreira report on the agreement on immediate autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan.
I ask you to call me again.

Madam President. The new directive creates a basis for dealing with books, newspapers, works of art, films, music, and TV productions, which are copyrighted, but for which the rightful owner cannot be identified or found.
Accordingly, books, films, photos or other intellectual creations for which no longer a right holder can be found should also be made available to the public.
And so a cultural treasure is raised.
For us in the Committee on Culture, it was particularly important to highlight the special importance of the diversity of the European Union's cultural heritage in this legislative initiative.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting companies there are countless unused works, and just because the rights holder is not known, they are not supposed to be available yet.
This changes with the directive.
It will enable the use of this cultural asset in the future, if it is ensured that a careful search is also prior to the publication.
This is a very important point, so that it is not simply said that we do not find the right holders.
Because a balance had to be found between the real rights of the creators of works and the need of the public to be able to use works where the legal situation is not clarifiable.
A special focus for us was that we had to ensure that both known and unknown rights holders were fully protected.
And where the rights holders cannot be found, the draft makes it possible to use the digitization of orphaned works.
Projects like Europeana and other large European digitalization projects, but also our museums, archives and educational institutions as well as public broadcasting will flourish.
In the future, however, it must also be about opening the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers to the public.
This draft directive and the compromise that has now been found is, in my opinion, a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the cultural treasure that is to come has enormous potential.
And we should also continue to work on this in the revision of the directive in two years. Thank you.
Mr. Chairman, dear Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council. I would be pleased if we also had clear goals in the proposal from two thousand thirteen.
We would see signals from the Council on how we can expand the growth and competitiveness potential in Europe and, above all, how we could give young people employment again.
Could you please tell us in which budget lines you plan to promote youth employment and focus on entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises?
We know that the ZIP program is the essential prerequisite for this. I only see cuts by the Council here.
or the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs program or the program for media plurality, there are only cuts here.
Do you think we can master the crisis in Europe by making cuts in those points that guarantee growth and employment?
I have heard that a growth and employment package is to be proposed by the Council.
Where can this be found in this budget, which has been presented by the Council?
The North Sea Works in Emmen had to declare bankruptcy last Wednesday because a guarantee from the Lower Saxony state government was not surprisingly extended.
This company with seven hundred qualified jobs is in the process of transformation from a shipyard to a supplier of offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be saved by a mass loan and that jobs can also be saved, because the seven hundred colleagues at SIAC and the North Sea Works have already had to accept significant cuts in wages.

Therefore, I ask the Commission to examine this procedure in a benevolent but also timely manner, so that these seven hundred jobs are not put at risk, because these seven hundred jobs are needed to organize the energy transition and to organize sustainable energy on the seas of Europe.
Please do not let your colleagues suffer from the poor crisis management of the state government.
Dual-use goods often look harmless, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes that can control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile software from Nokia Siemens Network that played into the hands of Iranian security forces when the green protest wave was shot down.
Protesters were massively kidnapped, arrested, tortured and sentenced to death.
And this is just one example of many.
In addition, the Commission promotes these dubious dual-use goods with the catalogue of measures for innovative and competitive security industries.
The goal is to create a better use of synergies between security and defense technologies.
We run the risk of selling human rights, but also our security interests, proverbially, for the benefit of a questionable industrial policy.
That is why I would like to ask you to agree to the amendments from us and the Social Democrats and ALDE.
I would like to ask Mrs. Regner what do you think the trade unions could do to fight youth unemployment in Spain and Portugal, for example?
Demonstrations will be too few.
What active policy could the internal market provide here?
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I think that with today's debate on MIFID we are entering the core area of financial market regulation.
We have made progress in this legislative period, it is about regulating the financial markets and not just looking at individual products, as we have done in the past.
I just want to mention a few keywords.
We didn't make our work together very easy last year.

We conducted a hearing in the committee, we consulted all stakeholders, all interested groups and on the basis of this, we developed a result with various processes, working documents and the like, which we will present to the plenary for voting today and tomorrow.
I want to highlight a few points.
Topic number one: Market structure.

On the one hand, we must of course already note that a lot has happened in the area of financial markets in recent years, but it is in our interest as a parliament that every financial sector trading that takes place takes place within the MIFID rules, which is why we also have a new category under many conditions

who have agreed to the so-called organized trading facilities, where only non-equities are to be traded, where self-trade is to be prohibited and where, according to the execution, a corresponding execution can take place at one's own discretion with regard to the execution and transaction and interaction of the customers.
I think that we are making an important contribution to the fact that the whole area of OTC securities traded within the MIFID world is traded.
Another major topic that was not yet considered in the last MIFID is the so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.

Here too, we wanted to establish clear rules of the game, so that this area, which can be very dangerous and can be used in a manipulative way, is subject to strict regimes with minimum detention periods,

With the possibility of trade interruptions, with the possibility of testing algorithms, with the possibility of looking at algorithms in the supervisory structure, with the introduction of a so-called tick size regime, a minimum price size and through corresponding fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of forward-looking markets.

I believe that we have a special responsibility here when it comes to limiting the speculative share in the commodity futures markets in such a way that we do not contribute to the fact that people in the third and fourth world can no longer buy food through wrong regulations.
We have therefore chosen a two-part approach with the aim of curbing speculation, but not harming the real economy.
We want to achieve this with position limits, with strict ceilings for the number of contracts or positions.
But we also want to ensure that those who can prove that they really need a product with a so-called position check system do not suddenly intervene speculatively in this market.
Another topic that is very close to our hearts is the area of investor protection.
I would just like to point out that we have chosen a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
It is about identifying the needs of certain customer groups.
Not every small saver has to have access to all highly complex papers.

It is about defining corresponding products for target groups, carrying out product tests, phone recordings, corresponding consultations, disclosure obligations, but I also want to briefly indicate this in the area of commissions, to make subsidiarity.
The member states should have the possibility to make corresponding adjustments according to their structures.
I think we are on the right track.
After my time is up, I would like to thank everyone who has contributed here.
I think it's a shame that you only get four minutes of speaking time for such a difficult dossier.
I would like to thank all my colleagues who have contributed here, and the Commission for its very constructive role in the last weeks and months.

I hope that with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council in order to be able to conclude this important dossier as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, thank you for the overall good cooperation on this report.
We have been able to further improve a Commission proposal at central points, which has already brought great steps in the right direction.
In the area of market structures, there will be more transparency, there will be more comprehensive transparency, especially in the area of derivatives trading.

Under the framework of the MIFID, the decisions in the area of high-frequency trading of our compromise go much further than what the Commission originally proposed and deserve the support of the Parliament as a whole.
And even on the topics that have caused a lot of public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

In the area of commodity and food speculation, after large and difficult debates, it must also be said that it is now much stronger than the Commission's decisions, because position limits are now set as binding.
However, we still need further changes in this area to close the gaps.
I also hope for additions here through the plenary vote and finally also in the trialogue.
And it is gratifying that Mr Barnier has already signalled his support for the Parliament's further proposal.
However, where the report has weaknesses is in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the possibility to ban products, which is a step forward, but we still have no changes in the area of commission-driven consulting.
The distribution of financial products is still not primarily oriented towards the interests of customers, but is strongly dominated by the product for which there are the most commissions.
Especially in Germany, but also everywhere in the EU, consumers have lost a lot of money.
Think of the open real estate funds.
For citizens in France, Italy, Spain and Germany, unfortunately, not much will change even after our compromise.
The basic principle will continue to be commission orientation.
Referring to subsidiarity here is a bit easy.
Here I would have liked stronger rules.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. Yes, what takes a long time, finally takes good, I can only say.
The report on the type approval of L category vehicles has ultimately become a good report.
The work took longer than we all thought and, above all, than we had hoped, and there were many more fallouts than we would have liked in the end.
But at this point I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr van de Kamp once again for the really cooperative and good cooperation.
Together we were still able to achieve a lot in the negotiations with the member states.
As the rapporteur of my group, I recommend that you agree to this report, however it could have been much better.
And by better, my esteemed colleagues, I mean safer.
For us social democrats, the safety of vehicles and thus the safety of drivers was the main focus from the beginning, especially the safety of scooter drivers and motorcycle drivers.
The number of motorcyclists who have been injured has remained constant for years.
In general, the number of accident fatalities in Europe is decreasing, but not in the case of motorcycle accidents.
Reducing the number of motorcyclists and scooters killed is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on European roads, that was and that is my goal.
Every death is one too many.
This topic must be worked on intensively, especially in a regulation that is so beneficial for the internal market.
I am still convinced that this can be done through effective technologies of anti-locking systems, i.e. ABS.
And I am just as convinced of cost-effectiveness.
It is not true that ABS is too expensive.
We have still achieved that from 2016 all new and from 2017 all existing types of engines must be equipped with ABS from 125 cubic meters by the manufacturer.
For motorcycle scooters, ABS or combined braking systems can be equipped by manufacturers.
Unfortunately, we have to admit that we have not achieved any improvements to the Commission proposal on this point.
I would have liked to see a lot more here, but the Commission and the Member States have shown themselves to be very cumbersome, to put it mildly.
We have still managed to get the Commission to present a report in 2019.
The report must be fed by traffic accident data from the member states and should examine the mandatory installation of ABS on scooters.
Furthermore, it will be sent to the Parliament and the Council.
On the basis of this report, the Commission should then consider making the installation of ABS in rollers mandatory.
You see, the topic remains very, very alive.
Therefore, we will try to close the binding gap in legislation from 2019.
I am sure that the data collected will agree with me.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for two-wheel drivers in Europe and that the number of accidents will decrease in the future.
Mr. President. There is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
I believe that this also applies to what we are discussing here today.
I am very much in favor of discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new access to the energy markets through unconventional resources, both in the case of gas, but also in the case of oil.

I believe it is neither appropriate to fall into great euphoria about the great gas future, nor, as some of my colleagues from the Greens and the Left have done here, to paint great horror and scary scenarios on the wall that have nothing to do with reality.

I think we have to keep in mind that these unconventional resources have the tools to change all the energy supply relationships we know between suppliers and demand, and that the economic calculations of previous energy sources are also questioned.
We should face development.

I think we should take note that this can also be an opportunity for Europe and not just a risk. We should prepare ourselves to positively use and use new technologies, to weigh opportunities and risks fairly and not to fall into ideological debates. Thank you.
Mr. Commissioner, for your answer. It doesn't quite satisfy me.
Because I think it is a very long period, one year between the notification that the complaint has been received and possibly getting an answer so late.
I believe that a complainant who makes the effort and has mostly already gone through the entire legal process in his member state deserves more.
We depend on citizens to commit to the European Union.
If you do it in this form, we should treat you accordingly.

I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long run that we have a procedure here that is clearly formalized and clearly regulates the rights. This is now a declaration about how the Commission wants to handle this.
On another point, I have nothing against trying to bring about some kind of consensual clarification with the member state.
But that won't always be enough.
We observe that, for example, in economic matters, it goes relatively smoothly when a company sues another company for a breach of EU law.
But when it comes to environmental issues and similar issues, where many citizens demand the activities of the European Union or even social rights, then it is already a bit more laborious.
I believe that these facts must also be taken into consideration.
I would like to see a clear formalization of the rights of the complainant to the Commission in your next report, which are also clear and well communicated.
If we really want European law to be applied, after we have had so many procedures here in the European Parliament, in the Council,
If we have decided on this together, we must inform those who care about it, who are really committed to Europe, as well and as precisely as possible.
This is a very big concern for me.
And I will also observe it closely again next time, what has developed here. Thank you.
Mr. President, colleagues. Five years ago, the EU's Central Asia strategy was launched.
If you ask today about the balance of this strategy, the assessment is ambiguous.
We see how the member states individually strive for good economic relations, especially with the raw material-rich countries of this region, but on the other hand, the efforts are not progressing.
to accompany these states in their transformation process towards modern democratic societies or, as the recent events in Kazakhstan show, the development is even marked by setbacks.

Nevertheless, or precisely for this reason, the European Union and the member states must express their influence in this region more strongly together, also and especially towards Kazakhstan, which has become a major supplier for several EU states.

The EU's isolation of Kazakhstan would only lead to the competitors for influence in this geopolitically important country, for whom the pressure to respect civil and human rights is not so important, having even more influence than before.
The linking of economic interests with the commitment to the protection of civil rights is the core of the Central Asia strategy.
This should also be the basis for further negotiations for a partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan.
The present report provides a good direction for this. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council not present, perhaps you are following us via the Parliament's video stream, as you obviously do not have the capacity or the desire to talk to us live.
I consider the Council's absence here and today to be a gross disregard for Parliament.
Instead of avoiding this debate, you should rather uncover your secret, why you refuse any improvement in the protection of personal data in the field of police and justice through a directive.

We have known for years that the police and the judiciary are an Eldorado of data protection violations, not only in the case of SWIFT, but also in the daily lives of citizens who demonstrate against Nazis, for example, who are unlawfully collected and stored.
We need equal protection standards for the public and private sectors, as well as for the police and the judiciary, in order to guarantee civil rights.
If the Council demands that the Parliament participate constructively in data protection regulations such as the EU PNR or Europol, then the same must probably apply to the Council.
That is why I demand that you finally put an end to the blockade policy in the area of data protection.
